headline: 5 New Designers to Watch This Season
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'London Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: Hailing from New York, London and Paris, these emerging talents will show their debut collections this month.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in upstate New York, Graham Tyler Baldwin was fascinated by art galleries. His parents organized family trips to the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C., where the young art aficionado teared up the first time he saw a room full of pieces by Alexander Calder. Now 24, Baldwin will debut his first ready-to-wear collection during New York fashion week, inspired by his memories of these expeditions. “Spring 2019 is from the perspective of myself as a child, dreaming after an art museum visit,” Baldwin says. “The collection seeks to replicate that childhood experience of first encountering the color field paintings of Brice Marden and Ellsworth Kelly.” Baldwin originally studied sculpture at the Cleveland Institute of Art and landed an apprenticeship in 2013 with the milliner Marta Glazen. “I became interested in headwear as a form of intimate sculpture on the body,” he says. When he moved to New York City in 2015, he made custom headwear on his own for clients such as Lady Gaga, MAC and Barneys New York, and later for fashion brands such as Adam Selman and Polo Ralph Lauren. Making so many hats for so many labels, Baldwin wanted to finally create a brand under his vision. This coming collection, his first foray into ready-to-wear, will include a moiré evening vest based on a small drawing by Ellsworth Kelly, a silk organza trench coat and, of course, beautiful headwear to top it all off.

abstract: These books for the under-4 set brim with humor, great illustrations, lively storytelling and cheerful surprises.
lead_paragraph: It’s possible there has never been a better time to be a toddler. True, you have to put up with grown-ups crashing playtime — today’s parents can often be spotted in sandboxes, solemnly instructing their offspring to scoop and dump sand — but on the plus side, the books currently being made for the preschool (and pre-preschool) crowd are setting a new standard for delightfulness, cleverness and flat-out fun.

headline: Albany to City: Drop Dead
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures', 'Law and Legislation', 'Local Government']
abstract: The convoluted and baldly political history of “home rule,” the legal quirk that allows the state to make decisions for New York City.
lead_paragraph: Regardless of where you stand on banning plastic bags, regulating speeding cars near schools, or how to fix the subways, most New York City residents are probably asking the same question: Why are those decisions being made in Albany by the governor and the state Legislature instead of in City Hall by the mayor and the City Council?

headline: Many Major Airports Are Near Sea Level. A Disaster in Japan Shows What Can Go Wrong.
abstract: Airports in Shanghai, Rome, New York and other major cities, often designed before global warming was fully understood, face a threat from rising seas and extreme weather.
lead_paragraph: As a powerful typhoon tore through Japan this week, travelers at Kansai International Airport looked out on a terrifying void: Where they should have seen the runway, they saw only the sea.

headline: College Football’s Craziest Weekend Arrives
abstract: Championships won’t get locked up for another three months, but Week 2 is college football’s nuttiest.
lead_paragraph: An eventual national champion sustains its only loss of the year. A Mid-American Conference team goes on the road and scores twice as many points as its Big Ten opponent. A celebrated former player who is now the athletic director materializes on the sideline and argues with the referees. A lower-tier team accomplishes one of the biggest upsets in history.

headline: How Aicha Cherif, Student Activist, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Besides making videos for the Love Vote, a new nonprofit, the high school senior likes to stroll and eat dumplings in Chinatown.
lead_paragraph: Aicha Cherif, 17, just started her senior year at School of the Future in Manhattan. But her responsibilities don’t stop with homework; she is also the outreach director for the Love Vote, which provides a platform for people who can’t vote to encourage those that can to do so. It is understandable why the teenager was drawn to the nonprofit: Ms. Cherif herself will not be eligible to vote when she turns 18 next May. When she was a baby, her family immigrated to the United States from Guinea. Now a permanent resident, Ms. Cherif has recruited 100 people to vote so far. She lives with her grandparents, Aissatou Toure and Zakaria Fofana, on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

headline: The Rage and Tenderness of David Wojnarowicz’s Art
abstract: At a retrospective at the Whitney Museum, the life and work of the artist and AIDS activist are a model for making art out of political anger.
lead_paragraph: If you know one work by David Wojnarowicz, it is probably “One Day This Kid,” a black-and-white self-portrait of the artist as a prepubescent, surrounded by text. This kid is wearing suspenders and a gee-whiz face, all forehead and chin and two buck teeth. His ears stick out like satellite dishes. It’s the early ’60s, and Wojnarowicz looks as if he walked into the Sears photo studio directly from the set of “Leave it to Beaver.” Then you read the words.

headline: Which Drug for Erectile Dysfunction Is Better: Viagra or Cialis?
abstract: Four drugs have been approved for erectile dysfunction. Which is best depends on your individual needs and desires.
lead_paragraph: Q. Which is better: Viagra or Cialis?

headline: 2 States Had Primary Elections This Week. Here’s What We Learned.
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: An incumbent congressman was unseated in Massachusetts on Tuesday, and a senator beat back a challenger in Delaware on Thursday in two of the final primaries of the 2018 midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: Labor Day has come and gone, the children are all back to school, and primary season is finally winding down. There are still a few states left to vote next week — we see you, New Hampshire, New York and Rhode Island — but the contours of this year’s nominating contests have been well formed.

headline: Seth Meyers Taunts Trump After Publication of Anonymous Op-Ed
abstract: Seth Meyers and James Corden had fun watching President Trump squirm after the publication of a scathing Op-Ed column in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Duterte Backs Down on Arresting Fierce Critic, a Philippine Senator
abstract: President Rodrigo Duterte will let the courts decide the fate of Senator Antonio Trillanes, his spokesman said Friday.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — President Rodrigo Duterte has backed down from his order to arrest a senator who is a leading critic of his war on drugs, his spokesman said Friday, just as the lawmaker was poised to be arrested in his Senate office.

headline: Brett Kavanaugh, Burt Reynolds, North Korea: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Corrupt Bargain of the Adults in the Room
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: They’re not restraining Trump. They’re making him more powerful.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the second day of Brett Kavanaugh’s Supreme Court confirmation hearing, Senator Kamala Harris, Democrat of California, asked him a straightforward question about Robert Mueller, the special counsel. “Have you discussed Mueller or his investigation with anyone at Kasowitz Benson and Torres, the law firm founded by Marc Kasowitz, President Trump’s personal lawyer?” Harris asked.

headline: A Cheer for Trump’s Outreach to the Taliban
abstract: Direct talks between America and the insurgents would be the best way to start diplomacy that might end the war in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: In July, The Times reported that the Trump administration directed the State Department to open direct talks with the Afghan Taliban, to see whether formal talks between the Afghan government and the Taliban are possible. Taliban officials soon claimed to have met with American diplomats, an assertion that American officials have not publicly commented on. This week, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced while on his way to Pakistan that Zalmay Khalilzad, a former ambassador to Afghanistan, would become an adviser on achieving reconciliation there.

headline: Love Not Lost: Two Childhood Cancer Survivors Marry at St. Jude
abstract: They first saw each other 30 years ago under desperate conditions. Life went on, but they never forgot each other.
lead_paragraph: Lindsey Wilkerson was given a tour when she first began working in the event and patient-liaison department at St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital in Memphis more than 14 years ago.

headline: New York Today: Where Are We on Fixing the Subway?
abstract: Friday: Updates on urban mass-transit, and free boating across the boroughs.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this comparatively cooler Friday.

headline: California Teenagers Could Sleep Later Under School Start Bill
abstract: More than three million students go to public middle and high schools in the state. If Gov. Jerry Brown signs the bill, the vast majority would not start class until 8:30 a.m. or later.
lead_paragraph: We all know a teenager who is nearly impossible to get out of bed in the morning. And research provides some relatively simple answers why: Sleep cycles make it hard for teenagers to fall asleep before 11 p.m. — and that does not leave them enough time to get a full night’s rest before school starts the next morning.

headline: The Big Myth About Teenage Anxiety
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Smartphones', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Parenting']
abstract: Relax: The digital age is not wrecking your kid's brain.
lead_paragraph: We hear a lot these days that modern digital technology is rewiring the brains of our teenagers, making them anxious, worried and unable to focus.

headline: Will Saudi Arabia Cease to Be the Center of Islam?
abstract: Saudi Arabia, or the Arabian Peninsula before the formation of the modern kingdom, has been and remains a place both central and marginal to Muslims around the world.
lead_paragraph: An Urdu novel published in 1869 by Nazir Ahmad, a writer in Delhi, portrays two young Muslim girls at their geography lesson. As they identify various countries on a map, the girls come across the Arabian Peninsula. Their teacher describes it as an empty space infested by marauding Bedouin, one whose only significance lay in its historical role as the site of Islam’s birth.

headline: After Two Hit Operas, a Composer Takes on the Bleak Prairie
abstract: In “Proving Up,” Missy Mazzoli tries to meet the high expectations set by her seething adaptation of the film “Breaking the Waves.”
lead_paragraph: With the New York premiere of “Proving Up,” at the Miller Theater on Sept. 26 and 28, the composer Missy Mazzoli has that contemporary musical miracle: a hotly anticipated third opera, a voice intriguing enough to seek out again and again.

headline: A Birthday Tribute to the Other Ingmar Bergman
abstract: A theater festival presented works he directed, stage adaptations of his films, and creations he influenced. Even a “Seventh Seal” for kids.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — Ingmar Bergman’s ghostly presence permeates the Royal Dramatic Theater here, where he directed dozens of plays over decades. So much so that when I got stuck in an elevator for 30 minutes after a backstage tour, I felt as if I were in an immersive production of one of his claustrophobic dramas. Who among our stranded group, I wondered, would have an existential crisis?

headline: The Kavanaugh Documents
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Executive Privilege, Doctrine of', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'ABORTION']

lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Slavery Was Part of Barbados Life for Centuries. But Its History Can Be Hard to Find.
abstract: There are important monuments, plaques and sites on the island. It requires effort to see many of them. Will that change?
lead_paragraph: A slender bronze sculpture representing an African couple and their child dominates a modest concrete plaza above a colorful jumble of houses in Rock Hall Freedom Village, Barbados, about a half-hour’s drive north of the island’s capital, Bridgetown.

headline: What Paul Scheer Can’t Travel Without
abstract: The actor and comedian always takes a real camera, a Kindle Oasis and recording equipment for his podcast “How Did This Get Made?”
lead_paragraph: The actor and comedian Paul Scheer’s engaging, gaptoothed grin has popped up on shows from “30 Rock” and “Veep” to, currently, “The Amazing Gayl Pile,” for which he also serves as executive producer.

abstract: Investors who worry about the Tesla C.E.O.’s erratic behavior and drug use are not having their concerns allayed.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday. Want this in your inbox every morning? Sign up here.

headline: Will the Year of the Woman Include Cynthia Nixon?
keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'Women and Girls', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Around the country, novice female candidates with progressive messaging are beating the odds. New York’s Democratic primary for governor is the next test.
lead_paragraph: By the reverse logic of the current election season, Cynthia Nixon ought to win the Democratic primary race on Sept. 13, to become the next governor of New York.

headline: Fight for Cash Goes On for N.F.L.’s Longtime Retirees
abstract: There are two classes of retired N.F.L. players — those who played recently and receive decent benefits, and those who played a long time ago and do not.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. loves to honor its retired “legends” and praise them for making the league what it is today.

abstract: Our roundup of the news stories and features about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
lead_paragraph: The start of the new school year brings the return of Teenagers in The Times, a roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com. During the school year, we publish a new edition on the first Friday of each month. Here is August’s edition. It might be especially useful if you are participating in our new challenge, Show Us Your Generation: A Photo Contest for Teenagers.

abstract: See Donald Glover as his musical alter ego before he makes good on his promise of retiring it; and watch Eddie Izzard as he workshops new material.

headline: Smoking May Increase Dementia Risk
abstract: Quitting smoking, or smoking less, might be helpful in reducing the risk.
lead_paragraph: Yet another reason to stop smoking: It may reduce your risk for dementia.

keywords: ['United States National Anthem Protests (2016- )', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Polls and Public Opinion']

abstract: Corin Hardy narrates a sequence from his horror film.
lead_paragraph: Corin Hardy narrates a sequence from his horror film.

headline: How ‘The Nun’ Buries You Alive
abstract: The director Corin Hardy narrates a scene that brings one of many people’s worst fears to reality.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Opera in Film Takes On a New Note in ‘Bel Canto’ (It’s Not Evil)
abstract: “Bel Canto,” starring Julianne Moore, is the rare movie not to use opera ironically, or to signal depravity, or as mushy mood music.
lead_paragraph: Classical music often gets a bad rap in movies. When you hear Mozart in a James Bond film, chances are the villain is using his trusty feed-foes-to-the-sharks contraption. Wagner is a soundtrack for violence. Bach? Dinner music. For Hannibal Lecter.

headline: The Week in Tech: Silicon Valley Goes to Washington. Again.
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Politics and Government', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Was it the pathetic moment we deserve? Twitter’s Jack Dorsey and Facebook’s Sheryl Sandberg testified on Capitol Hill. A cast of characters joined them.
lead_paragraph: Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: The Mistakes We Make When Moving
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Moving and Moving Industry']
abstract: How to make sure breakables like dishes and that leg lamp make it to your new home intact.
lead_paragraph: Moving to a new home can be intensely stressful and throw your life into chaos. But the process is old hat to a sometimes invisible group of people who have seen it all: the movers.

headline: Rebecca Lynn of Canvas Ventures on Nuclear Reactors, Failure and Asking Questions
abstract: The venture capitalist talks about going from “being a player on the field to being a coach” and what it’s like to see your company lose 98 percent of its value in one day.
lead_paragraph: As an undergraduate at the University of Missouri, from which she graduated in 1996, Rebecca Lynn had an unusual campus job: she worked at the local nuclear reactor. She says her time there — assisting with cancer research — helped inspire her ultimate career trajectory.

headline: California Today: Amid Another Blaze, Firefighters Ask for More Funding
abstract: Friday: Cal Fire says it has only $10 million left, Burt Reynolds has died, and scientists find an omnivorous shark.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

abstract: Plus: The triumph of Ayanna Pressley and a long-overdue obituary for Melitta Bentz, inventor of the coffee filter.
lead_paragraph: Gender Letter helps you keep up with the world, and the women shaping it. Tell me what you think at dearmaya@nytimes.com.

headline: The Economy Needs More Workers. Last Month, It Got Fewer.
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: The August jobs numbers suggest an economy that is starting to strain at its capacity, as the labor force shrank and wages rose.
lead_paragraph: The headlines for the August job numbers released this morning are nothing but good. Employers added a robust 201,000 jobs, the unemployment rate remained at the rock-bottom level of 3.9 percent, and wages grew the fastest they have in nine years.

headline: A Security Expert Tied to WikiLeaks Vanishes, and the Internet Is Abuzz
keywords: ['Missing Persons', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Arjen Kamphuis was last seen on Aug. 20 in a remote Arctic town in Norway. Online theories range from C.I.A. abduction to a secret mission for Julian Assange.
lead_paragraph: OSLO — In a remote Norwegian town north of the Arctic Circle, a cybersecurity expert with ties to WikiLeaks checked out of a hotel, dressed in khaki hiking gear and carrying heavy baggage.

headline: Keegan-Michael Key Puts Comedy Aside and Shoots for His Dreams
abstract: Mr. Key talks about transforming into an action figure for Shane Black’s “The Predator,” life beyond “Key & Peele” and why he doesn’t miss what he had.
lead_paragraph: Keegan-Michael Key likes to tell the story of how three years back, when the end came for “Key & Peele” — his socially provocative, deeply hilarious Comedy Central sketch show with Jordan Peele — the friend who would eventually become his wife asked him a simple question: “What do you want to do?”

headline: Netflix Roulette, Where the Movies Never End
abstract: Is “binge-watching” actually a good idea? One viewer finds out after he willingly subjects himself to Netflix’s algorithms.
lead_paragraph: In David Foster Wallace’s 1996 novel “Infinite Jest,” a filmmaker creates a movie so entertaining that it reduces viewers to dribbling catatonia. In the 1999 movie “The Matrix,” humanity is enslaved by machines that maintain a simulation of reality to keep everyone compliant. Nightmare visions in which slick entertainment anesthetizes the populace are nothing new. But no one could have predicted binge-watching, which means that once again reality has outstripped our wildest, grimmest imaginings.

headline: Designer Co-op at the Pierre Hotel Comes on the Market
abstract: A two-bedroom with panoramic Central Park views that was once home to Yves Saint Laurent is asking $10 million.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom with panoramic Central Park views that was once home to Yves Saint Laurent is asking $10 million.

headline: Chloë Sevigny Wants More. Lizzie Borden Is Helping With That.
abstract: Ms. Sevigny takes a career turn with “Lizzie,” producing and starring in an arty horror movie about Lizzie Borden and the infamous ax murders.
lead_paragraph: Oh, gawd. Not another profile of Chloë Sevigny. She’s a cooler-than-thou fashionista who also plays supporting roles in indie movies — the It Girl to end all It Girls. We get it.

headline: A Fifth Avenue Aerie at the Pierre for $10 Million
abstract: The two-bedroom apartment has been home to several well-known fashion designers, including Yves Saint Laurent and Tomas Maier.
lead_paragraph: A stylish aerie with a long lineage of prominent fashion-designer occupants is back on the market at the Pierre Hotel.

headline: The Kavanaugh Hearings Continue
abstract: A perfectly partisan proceeding.

headline: Kenny Stills Carries Colin Kaepernick’s Torch by Continuing to Kneel
abstract: The Dolphins receiver is one of the few N.F.L. players who still do so during the national anthem, undeterred by critics who call him unpatriotic.
lead_paragraph: DAVIE, Fla. — As the N.F.L. season gets underway, Colin Kaepernick, a quarterback who has not taken a snap in nearly two years, is back at center stage, his presence looming over the league because of Nike’s dramatic ad campaign featuring his willingness to sacrifice his career for his political beliefs.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Notes on a Foreign Country,’ ‘The Seventh Function of Language’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: In Search of ‘Shabby Chic’ at the Braderie de Lille
abstract: The huge annual flea market in northern France no longer draws the high-end antiques dealers. But it’s still a fun day out.
lead_paragraph: LILLE, France — A tarnished brass-and-crystal chandelier here, a flaking gilded-wood mirror there. A sideboard with rococo curves and a chipped tureen on top.

headline: ‘I Grew Up in a Southern Family — There Was a Lot of Talking’: Jacqueline Woodson on Her Two New Best Sellers
abstract: In “The Day You Begin,” a picture book inspired by her great-grandfather, and “Harbor Me,” a middle-grade novel, Woodson explores the transformative power of storytelling.
lead_paragraph: “Brown Girl Dreaming,” Jacqueline Woodson’s 2014 National Book Award-winning memoir in verse, included a story her mother had passed down, about Jacqueline’s great-grandfather William Woodson, the son of a free black man from Ohio, who fought and died for the Union during the Civil War. After his father’s death, William was sent to live with an aunt in a town where he was the only black kid in his school. Jacqueline transformed the story into a poem: “You’ll face this in your life someday, / my mother will tell us / over and over again. / A moment when you walk into a room and / no one there is like you.”

headline: Tesla Shaken by a Departure and What Elon Musk Was Smoking
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Marijuana', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The head of accounting departed weeks after he arrived, and the company’s chief held forth in a webcast punctuated by his apparent puffs on a joint.
lead_paragraph: For a moment, it looked as if Elon Musk and Tesla had put a summer of turbulence behind them. The moment was very brief.

headline: ‘I Don’t Talk’ That Way, Trump Says. Except When He Does.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: President Trump said he has never used terms like “mentally retarded” or “dumb Southerner,” as he is quoted in Bob Woodward’s new book. But the record shows he has.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Trump tries to rebut the portrayal in the latest attention-grabbing book, he has denied not only saying the things attributed to him, but also that he has ever said anything like them. The problem for Mr. Trump is that, in some cases at least, the record shows that he has.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: You may be preparing for Rosh Hashana (we have recipes for that), or you may simply be getting ready for the week (we also have recipes for that).
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s my first Friday back in forever and if I’m glad to be back in your inbox (and I am), I’m also thankful to Emily Weinstein for giving me summer Fridays off for the first time in my professional life. Please won’t you sign up for her newsletter, “Five Weeknight Dishes,” today?

headline: Flying Toward the Light
abstract: Several theories examine why night airborne insects are drawn to artificial lights, even if it spells doom for them.
lead_paragraph: A. What draws some night-flying insects, notably a variety of moth species, to a flame or other bright light is one of the perennial riddles of natural science. Several theories have been advanced over the years, but none has been universally accepted or conclusively proved.

headline: Could There Be Another Chinese Revolution?
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Corruption (Institutional)', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: A small elite is concentrating power under President Xi. But the stronger it gets, the more vulnerable it may be.
lead_paragraph: All summer there have been uncommon signs that opposition to President Xi Jinping may be growing in China, even Beijing itself. He featured less prominently than usual in official headlines. Important members of the Chinese Communist Party (C.C.P.) criticized his straitjacketed response to the trade war with the United States. A national scandal over several hundred thousand faulty vaccines broke while Mr. Xi was on a tour in Africa to sell his pet project, the One Belt, One Road initiative.

headline: Apothecary Bottles, Collected by a Jewelry Designer
abstract: Ana Khouri’s enchantment with antique vessels began as a child in São Paulo; now she has more than 60 of them.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan-based Jewelry designer Ana Khouri’s enchantment with antique apothecary vessels began as a child in São Paulo, where she was born and raised. Her grandfather, a doctor, had an antique pharmacy cabinet at his farmhouse upstate, and Khouri, 37, remembers being “mesmerized by the beautiful bottles.” She has since begun her own collection of these medicinal relics, which lined pharmacy shelves from medieval times until as recently as the 1950s. The designer’s 60-odd jars and bottles — some made from thick, amber glass, others from Delftware and Limoges porcelain — once contained remedies derived from flora and fauna. In addition to creating her sculptural, boundary-pushing fine jewelry — delicate rose-gold rings that span two fingers, diamond half-moon hoops that float above the earlobe — Khouri has become something of an amateur herbalist. “I am fascinated by how botanicals can cure or cause harm, depending on how they are used,” she said. Her new work will be exhibited at the Phillips auction house in New York City from Sept. 14 to Sept. 16.

headline: The Billionaire Who Bought Trump’s Mansion Faces Scrutiny in Monaco
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Dmitry Rybolovlev, a Russian mining magnate, is suspected of using perks to curry favor with officials, who arrested a businessman he is feuding with.
lead_paragraph: MONACO — There was a time here, in this principality on the Riviera, when Dmitry Rybolovlev could have been mistaken for royalty as he traipsed between restaurants, trailed by up to five bodyguards, more than the monarch himself, Prince Albert II.

headline: Tiger in Twilight
abstract: Tiger Woods is back. But is he back like before?
lead_paragraph: Tiger Woods still has the most famous silhouette in sports, even after all these years.

headline: What We Need to Fight the Next Financial Crisis
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: Congress has taken away some of the tools that were crucial to us during the 2008 panic. It’s time to bring them back.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, the global economy teetered in the face of a classic financial panic, the most dangerous type of financial crisis. In a financial panic, investors lose confidence in all forms of credit, retreating to the safest and most liquid assets, like Treasury bills. The prices of risky assets collapse, and new credit becomes unavailable, with dire consequences for workers, homeowners and savers.

headline: India’s Riotous Triumph of Equality
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The country’s Supreme Court didn’t just strike down an outdated British colonial law — it did so in a ruling that could reverberate across the globe.
lead_paragraph: In a landmark ruling this week, the Indian Supreme Court didn’t simply strike down Section 377, the odious British-introduced law criminalizing homosexual acts — it did so in a judgment of remarkable scope and eloquence.

headline: Living In ... Mattituck, N.Y.
abstract: With coastal property that appeals to second-home owners, prices are going up in this Long Island hamlet. But the sense of community remains.
lead_paragraph: With coastal property that appeals to second-home owners, prices are going up in this Long Island hamlet. But the sense of community remains.

headline: Mattituck, N.Y.: The Lure of the Waterfront
abstract: With coastal property that appeals to second-home owners, housing prices are going up in this Long Island hamlet. But the sense of community remains.
lead_paragraph: Route 25, or Main Road, on the North Fork of Long Island, wends through farmland, vineyards and tidy, picturesque towns established before the American Revolution. East of Riverhead, where the north and south forks of Long Island split from the larger island, Mattituck — a 9.3-square-mile hamlet with a population of about 4,200 in the larger town of Southold, with the Long Island Sound to the north and the Great Peconic Bay to the south — has long prospered, as its historic buildings, stately churches and bustling commercial area attest.

headline: What’s Your Favorite New York Spot?
abstract: Tell us what places in New York — gone or still hanging on — that you love the most and why.
lead_paragraph: Tell us what places in New York — gone or still hanging on — that you love the most and why.

headline: As Sweden Votes, the Far Right Gains Even in an Immigrant Bastion
keywords: ['Elections', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Politics and Government', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: Flen, a town with a history of immigration, is following the trend in much of the country, where the far right is expected to win a fifth of the vote.
lead_paragraph: FLEN, Sweden — The entrance to the small mosque is blocked by a gate. A window is badly cracked around a hole from a rock or a BB gun. A sliding metal security door has been painted with a swastika, only partly removed.

headline: The Fire That Consumed Brazil’s Treasures
abstract: Governments around the world should assign special resources to protect their national museums from the risk of fire and natural disasters.
lead_paragraph: The tragedy that engulfed the 200-year-old National Museum of Brazil in Rio de Janeiro on Sunday night, turning up to 20 million of its holdings into dust, is an urgent reminder of the need for better safekeeping measures at museums around the world. To put what happened in perspective: It’s as if the entire collection of the British Museum disappeared, twice over, in the blink of an eye.

headline: Jason Wu’s Untraditional (and Easy) Fried Rice
abstract: The fashion designer returns to his mom’s staple dish, which contains an unexpected secret ingredient, again and again.

headline: New Phone-Friendly Version of Financial Aid Form Is Coming Out
abstract: The Fafsa form, the gateway for student aid in college, has been notoriously difficult to use, and families generally needed a desktop computer to complete it.
lead_paragraph: The notoriously difficult-to-fill-out federal financial aid form known as Fafsa is going mobile. And, the federal Education Department says, it should be easier to use.

headline: Relive Burt Reynolds’s Coolest, Hunkiest Moments With These 8 Great Performances
abstract: Much of the actor’s best work is streaming right now, it all its rippling, mustachioed glory.
lead_paragraph: Burt Reynolds made more than 100 movies over the course of his 57-year film career. Naturally, not all of them were great (if you missed his 1961 debut in “Angel Baby,” chances are it can wait). But Reynolds could be a much better and more affecting actor than his popular down-home-hunk persona would suggest. Fortunately, much of his best work is streaming right now.

headline: Amazon’s Antitrust Antagonist Has a Breakthrough Idea
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'E-Commerce', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: With a single scholarly article, Lina Khan, 29, has reframed decades of monopoly law.
lead_paragraph: The dead books are on the top floor of Southern Methodist University’s law library.

headline: As Germans Seek News, YouTube Delivers Far-Right Tirades
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Social Media', 'News and News Media', 'Propaganda', 'Neo Nazi Groups']
abstract: A researcher found the platform’s recommendation system had steered viewers to fringe and conspiracy videos on a neo-Nazi demonstration in Chemnitz.
lead_paragraph: CHEMNITZ, Germany — The day after far-right demonstrators took over the streets here, Sören Uhle, a city official who oversees municipal marketing and development, began to get strange phone calls from reporters.

headline: An A’s Castoff Becomes a Rays Catalyst
abstract: Joey Wendle, with his solid hitting and defensive versatility, is a stealth candidate for the American League Rookie of the Year Award.
lead_paragraph: Joey Wendle had managed just three singles in his last 32 at-bats as the calendar flipped to October in 2016. A newcomer to the Oakland Athletics, Wendle would be batting ninth against the Seattle Mariners in the next-to-last game of the season. The A’s were out of the pennant race, but Seattle was still alive.

headline: Photos From the First Day of New York Fashion Week
abstract: Scenes from Jeremy Scott, Kith and more on Day 1.
lead_paragraph: The scorching heat on the first day of New York Fashion Week didn’t deter the front-row crowd. LeBron James and Justin Bieber attended both John Elliott and Kith, where a moving runway cycled through capsule collections.

headline: Vaccines Against H.I.V., Malaria and Tuberculosis Unlikely, Study Says
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Tuberculosis', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Malaria', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Unless the $3 billion spent annually on research triples, the world may not be able to invent vaccines or rapid cures for many ills of the poor.
lead_paragraph: Vaccines against H.I.V., malaria and tuberculosis — three major killers of the world’s poor — are unlikely to be produced in the foreseeable future unless vastly more money is committed to finding them, a new study has concluded.

headline: A Red Tide on Florida’s Gulf Coast Has Been a Huge Hit to Tourism
abstract: Though an algae bloom on the coast is improving, locals and business owners say it may be too little, too late.
lead_paragraph: The Saturday of Labor Day weekend in Siesta Key, just off Sarasota on Florida’s Gulf Coast, was a scorcher, with bright blue skies offering the perfect send-off for summer. John Fabian, a charter boat captain, was ready for it, offering two-hour, $400 sightseeing tours of the Intracoastal Waterway, the aquatic freeway that runs parallel to the coast.

headline: Cuomo Often Takes Taxpayer-Funded Planes and Helicopters, Far More Than Other Big State Governors
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo took 195 trips on taxpayer-funded state aircraft last year, far more than governors in California, Texas and other large states.
lead_paragraph: On a hot July day in 2017, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo visited a country club on Long Island to address business leaders about the future of rail lines that are the lifeblood of commerce and suburban commuters.

headline: Elton John’s Farewell Tour Wardrobe, Explained
abstract: After a 50-year career, the rocket man of pop is retiring from the road. This is the inside story of his finale style statement, designed by Gucci, and the secret power of a sequin.
lead_paragraph: NICE, France — On a late summer afternoon last week, on the sloping driveway of a palatial 1920s villa high in the hills above the city of Nice, sat three large white trucks. Lining a path along its lush lawns were scores of brown cardboard boxes; rolls of Bubble Wrap were unfurled on the grass.

headline: Death That Spurred Ethiopian Conspiracy Theories Is Ruled a Suicide
keywords: ['Hydroelectric Power', 'Levees and Dams', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Semegnew Bekele was the engineer in charge of a $4 billion dam project that had riled Egypt and fallen behind schedule. He died of a gunshot in July.
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — The police in Ethiopia said on Friday that the engineer who had been in charge of an enormous dam being built in the northwest of the country had taken his own life. The body of the engineer, Semegnew Bekele, was found slumped behind the wheel of his car in the capital, Addis Ababa, in July.

abstract: Kevin McCarthy, the House majority leader, says the author of an Op-Ed about resistance within the administration is a “subversive” who should be “exposed and fired.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

lead_paragraph: Thursday’s after-parties were hosted by Jeremy Scott, Cartier and 10 Corso Como.

lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Leif Ove Andsnes on Chopin’s Ballades, ‘the Peak of Romantic Piano Music’
abstract: Mr. Andsnes has recorded these four famously difficult works, with a selection of Nocturnes, for a new album on Sony Classical.
lead_paragraph: According to Leif Ove Andsnes, some piano classics can survive bad performances. The greatness of Beethoven and Brahms come through no matter what. Not so much with Chopin.

headline: Why Aren’t We Eating More Insects?
abstract: They’re high in protein, low in cost, eco-friendly and tasty. And only in the West have we resisted them.
lead_paragraph: JAPANESE GIANT HORNETS, known in their native land as suzumebachi, are behemoths of their kind, some nearly two inches long and reportedly capable of stinging through leather. They often build their nests underground, in forests of cypress and cedar, and there, in autumn, hunters rouse the grown hornets, swatting them into jars of shochu, where they flail and drown. The clear liquor is left to steep for at least two years; it turns umber as venom and pheromones leak from the dead insects. Some who’ve drunk it liken the taste to whiskey, others to salt and ash. But the larvae and pupae, carefully tweezed out of disinterred nests, are eaten immediately, gently simmered with ginger so they stay creamy, or fried to a crisp.

headline: Goodbye to Summer
abstract: Events included the Hampton Classic Horse Show Grand Prix and the Southampton Arts Center’s gala.
lead_paragraph: Events included the Hampton Classic Horse Show Grand Prix and the Southampton Arts Center’s gala.

headline: California Says Nursing Homes Abandoned Elderly During Fire
abstract: The Department of Social Services has moved to close two nursing homes accused of leaving behind residents during last year’s wildfires.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As a firestorm descended on the Northern California city of Santa Rosa in October, staff members at two nursing homes abandoned their residents, many of them unable to walk and suffering from memory problems, according to a legal complaint filed by the California Department of Social Services.

headline: Review: Lifetime’s ‘You’ Lets You Stalk the Stalker
abstract: In “You,” debuting Sunday on Lifetime, a dangerous man becomes violently obsessed with a self-absorbed young woman.
lead_paragraph: Lifetime’s new stalker drama, “You,” has two major flaws: Its name is near impossible to use in conversation or to Google in any meaningful capacity, and it is premiering Sept. 9 as part of the fall TV season rather than a few months ago, when it could have been the steamy summer show we needed.

headline: The Women Behind ‘You’ on Creating This Fall’s Darkest, and Most Timely, Romance
abstract: Sera Gamble and Caroline Kepnes discuss the new Lifetime stalker (and romantic!) thriller, which is based on a novel by Ms. Kepnes.
lead_paragraph: Sera Gamble and Caroline Kepnes had just wrapped a long day on the set of their new Lifetime romantic thriller, “You,” and all they wanted to do was celebrate.

headline: Trump Wants Attorney General to Investigate Source of Anonymous Times Op-Ed
abstract: Speaking to reporters on Air Force One, President Trump called the issue a matter of national security. Prosecutors said an investigation by the Justice Department would be inappropriate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump intensified his attack Friday on an anonymous Op-Ed essay published in The New York Times, declaring that he wanted Attorney General Jeff Sessions to investigate the source of the article, which he has condemned as an act of treason.

headline: The Man Who Made ‘Everyone Look So Famous’
abstract: That was how Andy Warhol described Richard Bernstein, who gave Interview magazine covers their signature look. Everyone wanted it — until they didn’t.
lead_paragraph: “They had faces then,” says Norma Desmond, the silent-film star burning out in “Sunset Boulevard,” a tragic lament for a more gorgeous time gone by. They had faces then, we could say just as well of a more recent era, that rich era in the 1970s and ’80s when Interview magazine ruled the newsstand, its oversize, Technicolor covers a parade of stars.

headline: A Bay Leaf Chicken to Prepare You for Fall
abstract: A glut of end-of-season fresh bay leaves inspires an easy weeknight chicken recipe.
lead_paragraph: Herbs flourish under adverse conditions.

headline: Science Does Not Support Claims That Contraceptives Are ‘Abortion-Inducing’
keywords: ['Plan B (Contraceptive)', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'ABORTION', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Abortion Drugs']
abstract: Judge Kavanaugh’s use of the term in his confirmation hearing resurrected a controversial phrase.
lead_paragraph: During his Supreme Court confirmation hearing on Thursday, Judge Brett Kavanaugh referred to some forms of birth control as “abortion-inducing drugs.” The phrase is a characterization that some anti-abortion religious groups use, but it is not supported by scientific evidence.

headline: A Young Man Working to Stop Chicago’s Gun Violence Loses His Life to It
abstract: Delmonte Johnson, 19, is among the volunteers and activists who were seeking to solve the city’s gun violence problems, only to find their lives ended by them.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — He was part of a group trying to stop the gun violence that has plagued this city. But this week, Delmonte Johnson was killed by it.

headline: French McDonald’s Workers Win Court Ruling Against Restaurant’s Sale
abstract: Employees at a Marseille McDonald’s said selling it to a Middle Eastern food operator was a risk to their jobs and their neighborhood. For now, a court has agreed.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Employees of a McDonald’s in a troubled Marseille neighborhood fighting to keep their restaurant open won a partial victory in court on Friday, their lawyer said.

headline: The Secret Tennis Past of a Basketball Lifer
abstract: Tom Konchalski is renowned in basketball circles for his evaluations of college prospects. But in an earlier life, he once called lines in a U.S. Open semifinal.
lead_paragraph: Tom Konchalski still keeps a close eye on the courts where he once worked.

headline: Obama Lashes Trump in Debut 2018 Speech. President’s Response: ‘I Fell Asleep.’
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: The former president offered a stinging indictment of his successor, sometimes by name, accusing him and his Republican supporters of practicing a “politics of fear and resentment.”
lead_paragraph: URBANA, Ill. — Former President Barack Obama re-entered the national political debate on Friday with a scathing indictment of President Trump, assailing his successor as a “threat to our democracy” and a demagogue practicing the “politics of fear and resentment.”

headline: The New York Times Endorses Blake Morris for State Senate in Thursday’s Primary
abstract: A real Democrat should replace Simcha Felder in Albany.
lead_paragraph: Few politicians have done more to block reform in Albany than State Senator Simcha Felder of the 17th District in Brooklyn. A Democrat, he has voted with Senate Republicans for years, giving them a one-seat majority since last spring that has let them obstruct legislation that could help clean up Albany and make the state a better, fairer place to live.

headline: New York City’s Streetscape, as Seen in Panorama
abstract: In the deadline-driven world of photojournalism, there usually isn’t much time for experimentation. But recently, Todd Heisler tried something different.
lead_paragraph: “I photograph to find out what something will look like photographed,” Garry Winogrand, one of the most prolific street photographers of the 20th century, once said. No matter how immediate photography has become, there is no less pleasure in being surprised by what the camera saw.

headline: Jason Wu: Spring 2019
abstract: Jason Wu Spring 2019 Collection.
lead_paragraph: Jason Wu Spring 2019 Collection.

headline: A Friend of Beethoven, Now Rediscovered in His Own Right
abstract: Anton Reicha, who met Beethoven when they were teenagers, was a composer and theorist whose works are being recorded by the pianist Ivan Ilic.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, the place you’d be most likely to encounter the name Anton Reicha was in the footnotes of books about Beethoven. The two met as teenagers when they played in the same orchestra in Bonn, Germany: Reicha as second flute, Beethoven on viola. Reicha’s name also pops up in the biographies of composers who studied counterpoint with him in Paris: Berlioz, Liszt, Franck, Gounod.

headline: Running, on the Way to Personal Recovery
keywords: ['Homeless Persons', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: A nonprofit uses group running to help people struggling with homelessness and substance abuse put their lives back together.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Joseph, 38, is alumni services coordinator at Back on My Feet in Baltimore.

headline: A Quick-Cooking Pasta That Keeps the Heat Outside
abstract: Celebrate the end-of-summer harvest with this simple dish that highlights sweet peppers and cherry tomatoes.
lead_paragraph: It may be September, but the weather is still taking cues from summer. Just the other day, the temperature in my neighborhood had already spiked to 90 by breakfast time, and I was glad I had stocked up at the farmers’ market. I didn’t even want to go outside.

headline: The U.S. Ambassador Who Crossed Trump on Immigration
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vietnamese-Americans', 'Vietnam War', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: A plan to deport Vietnamese refugees led the veteran Asia hand Ted Osius to quit. He says every diplomat faces the question: “What ethical lines won’t you cross?”
lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — As President-elect Donald J. Trump prepared for his inauguration on Jan. 20, 2017, Ted Osius assumed he was about to lose his dream job as the American ambassador to Vietnam.

headline: Erich Lessing, 95, Photographer Who Chronicled Postwar Europe, Dies
abstract: He fled Europe in 1939 but returned to Austria after the war as a self-taught photojournalist and chronicler of modern history and culture.
lead_paragraph: Erich Lessing, a self-taught photojournalist who fled the Nazi annexation of Austria as a teenager in 1939 but returned after World War II to document Europe’s political and cultural rebirth, died on Aug. 29 in Vienna. He was 95.

headline: Hundreds of Seals Are Dying on the New England Coast
abstract: Deaths of gray and harbor seals, in much greater numbers than usual, have been attributed to viruses related to distemper and the flu.
lead_paragraph: Harbor and gray seals are dying by the hundreds from Southern Maine to northern Massachusetts, apparently from a combination of a measles-like illness and the flu.

headline: Third Point Seeks to Oust Campbell Soup’s Board
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Boards of Directors', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The campaign to replace the soup maker’s 12 directors is one of the most ambitious moves by an activist shareholder in recent years.
lead_paragraph: The Campbell Soup Company has had to grapple in recent years with stagnant sales and consumers forgoing the canned soups that have been its mainstay product for generations.

headline: Justice Dept. Demand for North Carolina Voting Records Extended to D.M.V.
abstract: A Justice Department subpoena would require the state to produce 15 million documents. The state elections board called it overly broad and intrusive.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — In a further sign of the sprawling nature of the Justice Department’s effort to collect voting records in North Carolina, prosecutors demanded eight years of information from the state’s Division of Motor Vehicles, according to a copy of the subpoena obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Inside Alex Jones’s ‘Tangy Tangerine’-Fueled Empire
abstract: Fans of Infowars don’t just buy in to the conspiracy theories peddled by Alex Jones, they actually buy. Mr. Jones has amassed a fortune by pitching health products and weapons components as antidotes to the frightening worldview he broadcasts.
lead_paragraph: Fans of Infowars don’t just buy in to the conspiracy theories peddled by Alex Jones, they actually buy. Mr. Jones has amassed a fortune by pitching health products and weapons components as antidotes to the frightening worldview he broadcasts.

headline: Conspiracy Theories Made Alex Jones Very Rich. They May Bring Him Down.
keywords: ['Rumors and Misinformation', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Censorship', 'Social Media', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Libel and Slander', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The Infowars founder and Trump backer is as much marketer as ideological warrior, selling products to assuage the fears he is so expert at stoking.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN — More than ever before in his two-decade career built on baseless conspiracy theories, angry nativist rants and end-of-days fearmongering, Alex Jones is being called to account.

abstract: In a speech, former President Barack Obama said the Trump-led Republican Party practiced a “politics of fear and resentment.” Mr. Obama’s address also offered a preview of how he will campaign for Democrats in the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: In a speech, former President Barack Obama said the Trump-led Republican Party practiced a “politics of fear and resentment.” Mr. Obama’s address also offered a preview of how he will campaign for Democrats in the midterm elections.

headline: Does Italy Want More Cafes? Starbucks Will Find Out
abstract: Italy’s first Starbucks opened in Milan to enthusiastic crowds, despite high prices and skepticism from the competition.
lead_paragraph: MILAN, Italy — If there is one thing Italy would not seem to need, especially from Americans, it is another place to buy a cup of coffee.

headline: Trump Threatens Tariffs on All Imports From China, Escalating Trade Feud
keywords: ['Customs (Tariff)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Trump said that he was ready to impose tariffs on an additional $267 billion in goods if Beijing did not change its trade practices.
lead_paragraph: President Trump threatened China with another round of punishing tariffs on Friday, saying he was prepared to tax essentially all Chinese goods imported into the United States if Beijing did not change its trade practices.

headline: You’re Happy With Your Job. Why Is That a Problem?
abstract: The assignments are fine, the colleagues great, the benefits terrific. But you’re not doing anything impressive, and you know it. Here’s how to keep your groove from turning into a rut.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: For Gay Indians, Landmark Ruling Is Just the Beginning
abstract: Gay activists in India celebrated the end of a ban on consensual gay sex, even as they prepared for the next battles in advancing gay rights.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Even as gay activists in India celebrated on Friday, a day after a landmark Supreme Court ruling ended the country’s ban on gay sex, they were preparing for resistance to the decision.

headline: Irving Petlin, Artist Who Recorded Injustice, Dies at 83
abstract: In his paintings and pastels, Mr. Petlin reimagined brutal events with subtlety and surrealism in a style neither realistic nor abstract.
lead_paragraph: Irving Petlin, whose idiosyncratic paintings and pastels reflected a moral commitment to document inhumanity — during the Vietnam War, in the Middle East and on the streets of Paris and Los Angeles, among other examples — died on Sept. 1 at his home on Martha’s Vineyard, in Massachusetts. He was 83.

abstract: Some favorite short selections and new Bach and Chopin piano recordings were among the highlights.

headline: The U.S. Stock Market Towers Over the Others. But at What Cost?
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Income Inequality', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Renminbi (Currency)', 'US Dollar (Currency)', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The United States stock market has outstripped nearly all others and has outpaced the domestic economy. But its exceptional performance may come with serious consequences.
lead_paragraph: Much of the world has recovered from the global financial crisis of a decade ago, but one market has prospered above virtually all others: the United States stock market.

headline: Dallas Police Officer Kills Her Neighbor in His Apartment, Saying She Mistook It for Her Own
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The officer told the police that she shot Botham Shem Jean, 26, after mistaking his apartment for her own and believing he was an intruder.
lead_paragraph: A Dallas police officer fatally shot a neighbor inside the man’s apartment late Thursday night, claiming that she mistook his apartment for her own and believed he was an intruder, the police said.

headline: Review: Nature and Song Bring Electricity to ‘Gospel at Colonus’
abstract: With its focus on exiles finding protection and outcasts earning redemption, this revival of the 1983 production feels more timely than ever.
lead_paragraph: Someone should give Zeus a burnt offering. Or a producer credit. At the Delacorte Theater on Thursday night, sporadic rain had been falling for more than an hour. But as soon as the doors opened, thunder hushed, clouds cleared. Lightning still lit up the stage, of course. A metaphor? Mostly. When you revive a work as musically galvanic and ecstatic as “The Gospel at Colonus,” expect electricity.

headline: Luke Voit Always Knew He Could Hit. Now Everyone Else Does, Too.
abstract: Given a chance to swing away, Luke Voit has brought positivity and power to the Yankees’ late-season push.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The roots of Luke Voit’s boisterous, barrel-chested romps around the bases, the Sammy Sosa-like crow hops after connecting on a home run and the forearm shivers that are vigorous enough to leave Popeye with bruises trace back to a bucolic setting — the expansive backyard of his home in Wildwood, Mo., a suburb of St. Louis.

headline: 2018 Festival Albertine to Explore Democracy and Its Future
abstract: Masha Gessen has organized six panels on the theme of reimagining democracy that cover topics like “A Post-Work World.”
lead_paragraph: Masha Gessen, the journalist and author, is organizing this fall’s Festival Albertine, an annual event dedicated to fostering French-American intellectual exchange presented by the Cultural Services of the French Embassy and Albertine Books. The theme of the 2018 festival is Reimagining Democracy.

headline: Congressional G.O.P. Agenda Quietly Falls Into Place Even as Trump Steals the Spotlight
abstract: This week has illustrated why Republicans put up with the chaos: As President Trump raged, his party moved toward an ideological shift in the Supreme Court that will last for decades.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On one end of Pennsylvania Avenue this week, President Trump and his closest advisers labored to beat back perceptions, fueled by an anonymous essay in The New York Times and a bruising new book by Bob Woodward, that he had all but lost control of the presidency from within. He lashed out anew at his attorney general, shouted “TREASON” and demanded investigations of his detractors.

headline: In Immigration Courts, It Is Judges vs. Justice Department
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Trump administration has instituted policies it says will speed up backlogged immigration cases, but critics see them as an attempt to control how judges rule.
lead_paragraph: As the Trump administration pursues a hard-line policy on immigration, it is facing resistance from an unexpected quarter — judges who rule on whether immigrants will be deported or be allowed to stay in the country.

headline: Victims of Sexual Violence Often Stay in Touch With Their Abusers. Here’s Why.
abstract: Asia Argento stayed close with Harvey Weinstein. Jimmy Bennett stayed in touch with Ms. Argento. The dynamic is not uncommon, the National Domestic Violence Hotline says.
lead_paragraph: Why would those who have been sexually assaulted by someone close to them stay in touch with their abuser?

headline: New Antarctica Map Is Like ‘Putting on Glasses for the First Time and Seeing 20/20’
abstract: A high resolution terrain map of Earth’s frozen continent will help researchers better track changes on the ice as the planet warms.
lead_paragraph: You may never make it to the South Pole, but you can now see Antarctica and its glaciers in unprecedented detail.

headline: Making Wills Easier and Cheaper With Do-It-Yourself Options
keywords: ['Wills and Estates', 'Philanthropy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Personal Finances', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: Many websites offer services to create estate plans for little or no money. Some offer a lawyer to talk to free of charge.
lead_paragraph: Michael Ellis used a lawyer to make a simple will when he was young.

headline: Robots Can Manage Your Money. But Even They Need Humans.
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Financial Planners', 'Personal Finances', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Robots and Robotics']
abstract: Betterment, among the largest so-called roboadvisers, is one of the latest online services to reduce even further the cost of advice from a mix of algorithms and warm-blooded professionals.
lead_paragraph: The robots may need some help from humans after all.

headline: The Violence at the Heart of Our Politics
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Debates (Political)', 'Capitol Building (Washington, DC)']
abstract: In Congress before the Civil War, partisan disagreement often featured Bowie knives and pistols. Are we headed back toward that way of life?
lead_paragraph: Mike Huckabee waxed historic this week while denouncing protesters who interrupted Brett Kavanaugh’s Supreme Court confirmation hearings. “Clear the room or start caning them when they open their yaps!” he tweeted, making a backhanded reference to the most famous caning in American history: the 1856 attack on Senator Charles Sumner. Outraged by one of Sumner’s antislavery speeches, Preston Brooks of South Carolina brutally beat him to the ground in the Senate chamber a few days later, stopping only when his cane broke.

headline: George Papadopoulos, Ex-Trump Adviser, Is Sentenced to 14 Days in Jail
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: In an interview, the former campaign adviser said he lied to the F.B.I. to distance himself and the Trump team from “what was probably an illegal action.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — George Papadopoulos, a former Trump campaign adviser, was sentenced on Friday to 14 days in prison for lying to the F.B.I. about his contacts with Russian intermediaries during the 2016 presidential race, becoming the first Trump adviser to be sentenced in the special counsel investigation.

headline: Excerpts From the New York Times Interview With George Papadopoulos
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates']
abstract: Mr. Papadopoulos said he lied to federal investigators because he wanted to protect himself and the Trump campaign from “what was probably an illegal action or dangerous information.”
lead_paragraph: George Papadopoulos, a former Trump campaign adviser, was sentenced on Friday for lying to the F.B.I. about his interactions with suspected Russian intermediaries during the 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: I Would Interview Steve Bannon
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media', 'Social Media']
abstract: He may be a wandering plague ship of a man, but journalists should talk to him.
lead_paragraph: Steve Bannon — that hopelessly unmade bed of a man, that wandering plague ship — will not be attending The New Yorker Festival. As most of the internet now knows, the former White House adviser was to be interviewed onstage by the magazine’s editor, David Remnick. But in response to vociferous objections raised by some New Yorker staff members, other festival speakers and just about everyone who could tap out a tweet about Mr. Bannon’s populist but decidedly racist views, the invitation was quickly rescinded.

headline: Foreign Powers See ‘No Military Solution’ in Syria, but Diplomacy Stalls
abstract: Russia rejects Turkey’s call for a cease-fire in a rebel province, while the Security Council fails to act, stymied by Russia’s veto power.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — At a summit meeting in Tehran on Friday, the presidents of Russia, Turkey and Iran agreed that “there could be no military solution” to the war in Syria, but Russia rejected Turkey’s call for a cease-fire while Iran called for a military push to crush the Syrian rebels and drive out American forces.

headline: How to (Maybe) Avoid Sticker Shock at the Emergency Room
keywords: ['Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Knowing whether to use an urgent care center, a retail clinic, virtual care or the emergency room can make a big difference in cost.
lead_paragraph: Emergency care has always been expensive. Recently, though, a perfect storm of high-deductible insurance plans, new venues of care such as stand-alone emergency departments, and insurers who deny payment based on retrospective review — that is, based on the patient’s final diagnosis rather than the original complaint — has elevated concerns about cost to a level that might best be described as sticker shock.

headline: Florida Must Provide Election Materials in Spanish, Judge Says
keywords: ['Elections', 'Spanish Language', 'Puerto Ricans', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: In an acerbic order, a federal judge said 32 counties with Puerto Rican populations were obligated to provide Spanish-language sample ballots.
lead_paragraph: Florida officials must provide Spanish-language election materials in 32 counties with Puerto Rican populations, a federal judge ruled on Friday, granting part of what a Puerto Rican voter and several Latino advocacy groups had requested. But the judge concluded that there would not be enough time before the November elections to make other changes the plaintiffs had sought.

headline: Stable After Attack, Brazilian Candidate May See Political Fortunes Rise

headline: Mac Miller, Rapper Who Wrestled With Fame and Addiction, Dies at 26
abstract: The musician, who released five albums, began his career as a mischievous party-starter but turned toward darker themes.
lead_paragraph: Mac Miller, a Pittsburgh rapper who built a loyal cult fan base with low-key charisma and intimate verses, died on Friday at his home in the San Fernando Valley in California. He was 26.

headline: T Suggests: Nostalgic Prada, Otherworldly Paintings by a Radical Recluse and More
abstract: A by-no-means exhaustive list of the things our editors (and a few contributors) find interesting this week.
lead_paragraph: The first luxury good I ever coveted, which my grandmother bought for me, was a black nylon Prada bag. It was a cross-body that I wore with everything for years, and it was the start of my love affair with Prada. It led to my next obsession: Prada’s classic Linea Rossa collection of high-tech streamlined pieces made from sportswear nylon, which debuted in 1997 and soon became a hallmark of the brand. Now, Prada is relaunching the collection for a new generation of fans. Last February, Miuccia Prada closed her fall 2018 show with a series of nylon pullover jackets and bucket hats in an array of acidic neon hues, all bearing the Linea Rossa logo, a sleek red stripe. The new collection, which launches this weekend, retains the minimalist ’90s sensibility of the original line but features an updated fabric. Anoraks, padded jackets, quilted pants and bucket hats (there are also angular wraparound sunglasses) all come in a more technical, waterproof and windproof nylon, in a rainbow of new colors including highlighter pink, safety orange and bright mint green. Available at Prada stores worldwide, select boutiques and prada.com — MALINA JOSEPH GILCHRIST

headline: Two Art World Heavyweights Discuss Painting and Parenting
abstract: The artists Michael Williams and Carroll Dunham meet up in the Connecticut countryside to continue a conversation that’s been years in the making.
lead_paragraph: Friends for the better part of a decade, the artists Michael Williams and Carroll Dunham refer to their relationship as a “dialogue.” They might be separated by 28 years (Williams is 40, Dunham is 68) and the width of America, but they manage to stay in touch through regular studio visits, and bond over their common ground as fathers and painters — the latter a role that both describe as inherently isolating.

headline: How the 25th Amendment Came to Be, by the People Behind It
keywords: ['Twenty-Fifth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: We asked three men involved in the design or enforcement of the 25th Amendment to reflect on its history and on discussions about whether it should be invoked.
lead_paragraph: The health troubles of President Dwight D. Eisenhower. The long shadow of how Woodrow Wilson’s wife assumed a role in the presidency after he became ill. The assassination of John F. Kennedy. These crises served as a backdrop more than 50 years ago for Congress to settle what should happen if a president is left unable to govern.

headline: Quarantined Aircraft and Sick Passengers. It’s Not as Scary as It Sounds.
abstract: The quarantine of a flight to New York was followed by sick passengers reported on flights into Philadelphia. But experts say events like this are rare.
lead_paragraph: A pair of flights from Europe landed at Philadelphia International Airport on Thursday and their passengers were sent for medical reviews. A day earlier, a plane from Dubai, United Arab Emirates, was quarantined briefly at Kennedy International Airport in New York after initial reports of as many as 100 sick travelers on board.

headline: Amanda Kyle Williams, Crime Novelist Who Was Dyslexic, Dies at 61
abstract: Ms. Williams, who was dyslexic, didn’t read her first novel until she was 23. Then she landed a $1 million contract to write a mystery series.
lead_paragraph: As a student in rural Georgia, long before she became a successful mystery writer, Amanda Kyle Williams struggled to read even the simplest sentences. The words on the page looked jumbled, like jigsaw puzzle pieces that wouldn’t connect.

headline: A First Look at Prabal Gurung’s Debut Men’s Collection

headline: Prabal Gurung Joins the Wave of Women’s Wear Designers Moving Into Men’s Wear
abstract: Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen of the Row and Simon Porte Jacquemus are also among those turning their attention to men.
lead_paragraph: Ladies first. Men’s wear to follow. A number of fashion designers who have made a name for themselves for their women’s wear lines are turning their attention to men. On Sunday evening, at Spring Studios, during New York Fashion Week’s women’s ready-to-wear collections, the designer Prabal Gurung, will debut a men’s wear line alongside his women’s wear, which he first launched in 2009. This October, Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen’s the Row will offer its first men’s wear collection directly through retailers. Speculation surrounds Hedi Slimane, who will present his first men’s and women’s collections at Paris Fashion Week for Céline since taking over the house — which until now only released clothing for women. And earlier this summer, the French designer Simon Porte Jacquemus, of Jacquemus, showed his first men’s wear collection in Calanque de Sormiou, a seaside cove located on the outskirts of Marseille.

headline: Alibaba’s Jack Ma, China’s Richest Man, to Retire From Company He Co-Founded
abstract: In an interview, Mr. Ma said it was “the beginning of an era” for him and that he planned to focus on philanthropy in education.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Alibaba’s co-founder and executive chairman, Jack Ma, said he planned to step down from the Chinese e-commerce giant on Monday to pursue philanthropy in education, a changing of the guard for the $420 billion internet company.

headline: Del Potro Reaches U.S. Open Final as Nadal Retires With a Knee Injury
abstract: Juan Martín del Potro advanced to his first Grand Slam final since 2009, and will play Novak Djokovic, who defeated Kei Nishikori in the second semifinal on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The scowl on Rafael Nadal’s face and his low mutterings directed toward his coaches in the stands were the first indications on Friday night that something was wrong. When he asked for a trainer to tape his right knee, the level of concern elevated. And then, in perhaps the clearest sign of all, Nadal, one of the greatest ball-hunters in the history of tennis, allowed one to whiz past him without even giving chase.

headline: Cortlandt Street Station, Damaged on Sept. 11, Reopens 17 Years Later
abstract: Nearly 17 years after the Cortlandt Street subway stop was destroyed on Sept. 11, a new station opened in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: When the twin towers fell on Sept. 11, 2001, they came crashing down on the Cortlandt Street subway stop on the No. 1 line. The station was buried under debris, its sturdy beams bent like paper clips.

headline: Is This a Mid-1990s Moment for the Economy? Three Reasons for Optimism
abstract: There are parallels today to the strongest period of growth and prosperity in recent decades.
lead_paragraph: A painful recession was fading into memory, yet the expansion felt unsatisfying to many. There was evidence of huge technological leaps everywhere except in the data on worker productivity. And the unemployment rate was falling to levels that forecasting models predicted would trigger a burst of inflation.

headline: A Look at the Power Behind Naomi Osaka’s Blazing Forehand
abstract: The power game will be on display in this year’s women’s U. S. Open final when two of the hardest hitters in the game, Serena Williams and Naomi Osaka, square off. It will be the first Grand Slam final for Osaka who has burst onto the scene with one of the most powerful forehands in women’s tennis.
lead_paragraph: The power game will be on display in this year’s women’s U. S. Open final when two of the hardest hitters in the game, Serena Williams and Naomi Osaka, square off.
