headline: New in Paperback: ‘Prairie Fires,’ ‘Cockfosters’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: PRAIRIE FIRES: The American Dreams of Laura Ingalls Wilder, by Caroline Fraser. (Picador, $22.) This excellent biography explores Ingalls’s childhood and rise to prominence, and refreshes our understanding of American history, from Native Americans to the homesteaders who displaced them. The book, one of the Book Review’s 10 best of 2017, traces the “Little House on the Prairie” author’s role in shaping the mythology of the American West.

headline: Delia Owens, Who Suffused Her African Memoirs With Lush Natural Detail, Turns to Fiction
abstract: Hints of her wildlife research — particularly the study of brown hyenas — can be seen in her debut novel, “Where the Crawdads Sing.”

headline: War Wounds: Crime Novels From All Kinds of Battlefields
abstract: Marilyn Stasio’s mystery roundup takes readers to World War I Britain and France, then dips into two psychological combat zones in modern America.
lead_paragraph: If I were in jail, George Pelecanos would be on my reading list, right up there with James Lee Burke and Elmore Leonard, who are also favorites of the inmates in THE MAN WHO CAME UPTOWN (Mulholland/Little, Brown, $27). The guys in the general population at the Washington, D.C., jail also go for lady authors, thanks to Anna Kaplan, a roaming librarian the inmates call “Miss Anna.” One loyal client, Michael Hudson, emerges from behind bars as a bona fide bibliophile. (“When he read a book, he was not locked up. He was free.”)

headline: Picture Books About Dreams and Dreamers of All Kinds
abstract: Immigrants, artists and inventors imagine liberation in gorgeous new books by Yuyi Morales, Il Sung Na, Juan Felipe Herrera and more.
lead_paragraph: With each new season of children’s books, subjects seem to cluster. Not long ago, a slew of sloth books appeared. Then two blobfish books, in the same month. This year it’s picture books that wear their hearts on their sleeves, displaying value statements, as titles, on their jackets. Recently, “Be Kind” and “All Are Welcome” have shared space on a Times best-seller list topped by the similarly didactic but less utopian “We Don’t Eat Our Classmates!”

headline: How Forlini’s Survives the Instagram Horde
abstract: If there’s anything worse than an old-school restaurant being uncool, it’s an old-school restaurant suddenly becoming hot.
lead_paragraph: As rats scampered among trash cans by moonlight in Chinatown, a procession of tall and very good looking people started entering an old Italian restaurant on Baxter Street called Forlini’s. They walked past its grand wooden doors and moved right through the stuffy chandelier-lit dining room, where middle-aged customers looked up from their veal marsala and clams casino to consider the stylish spectacle.

headline: How Maya Rudolph Became the Master of Impressions
abstract: The actress and comedian can move up and down the scales of race, age and gender with hilarious ease — a talent that grew from finding her place in a world where no one looked like her.
lead_paragraph: Supposing that God is real and possessed of a human corporeal form — mankind being created in his image (reportedly) — we might reasonably conjecture that God’s anthropoid body integrates the totality of physical traits expressed in Earth’s human population: the skin tones blended to a light tan; the hair dark and thick; the height neither too tall nor too short — about 5-foot-7, say; every shade of human iris (the iridescent blue of a morpho butterfly, the pale green of lichen clinging to a tree, lots of brown) combining to create eyes that are ... also brown. Considering his propensity for giving life, God would probably be a mother. Considering his appreciation of beauty (e.g., snowflake geometry) and busy schedule (e.g., Genesis), he would probably clothe himself in breezily tasteful garments made from natural fabrics cut for maneuverability, like a long denim jumper dress worn over a shirt of pure white cotton. God would look, in other words, like Maya Rudolph running errands on a Tuesday.

headline: The American Past: A History of Contradictions
abstract: Jill Lepore’s “These Truths” shows both the successes and failures that have made the country what it is today.
lead_paragraph: THESE TRUTHS A History of the United States By Jill Lepore Illustrated. 932 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $39.95.

headline: 5 Takeaways From New York’s Primary Election Results
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo brushed past Cynthia Nixon in Thursday’s Democratic contest. But other challengers benefited from the progressive fervor sweeping national politics.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic primary between Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Cynthia Nixon was over in about the time it takes to watch an episode of “Sex and the City.” The Associated Press called the race 30 minutes after the polls closed, as soon as it became apparent that the governor, a two-term incumbent and a Queens native, had rolled up big margins in the five boroughs.

headline: How Valerie Steele, Fashion Curator, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Ms. Steele, who has been called the “Freud of Fashion,” spends part of her day relaxing in a yukata (a casual kimono), but also goes aqua cycling and visits museums.
lead_paragraph: Valerie Steele is the longtime director and chief curator of the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology. Since 1997, she has organized more than 25 exhibitions there, including “The Corset;” “Gothic: Dark Glamour;” and “A Queer History of Fashion: From the Closet to the Catwalk.” Her latest, “Pink: The History of a Punk, Pretty, Powerful Color,” opened on Sept 7. The author of more than 25 books about fashion, Ms. Steele lives in a Chelsea loft with her husband, John S. Major, a historian of ancient China, and their two rescue cats, Raven and Sable.

headline: Why Do People Stay When a Hurricane Comes?
keywords: ['Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Hurricane Florence (2018)', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Hurricane Maria (2017)', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Transportation', 'Coastal Areas']
abstract: The messy truth lies in between two common, incorrect tropes.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Florence is currently battering the Carolina coast. A weakened yet still severe storm, experts expect flooding, high winds and torrential rains in the area, possibly for days. After issuing a mandatory evacuation order, Gov. Roy Cooper of North Carolina warned, “If you wait until conditions get bad, it may be too late to get out safely.” Tens of thousands of Carolinians scrambled to leave. Others, however, stayed put and are weathering the storm.

headline: 5 Classical Music Faces to Watch This Season
abstract: Julia Bullock, Conrad Tao, Ashley Fure, Nico Muhly and Hilary Hahn are creating new musical works and reshaping the way we hear old ones.
lead_paragraph: The classical music season sprawls over centuries and the entire globe, a dizzying array of performances that manages to include both multimillion-dollar productions in front of 4,000 spectators at the Metropolitan Opera and intimate electronic experiments at Issue Project Room in Brooklyn. A balanced cultural diet would include a bit of both, as well as generous helpings of the five artists featured here; we’re particularly looking forward to seeing what they’re up to in the months ahead. They’re musicians who unite virtuosic technique with boundless curiosity, creating new works and reshaping the way we hear old ones. ZACHARY WOOLFE

headline: Architecture Is No Longer Just a ‘Gentleman’s Profession’
abstract: From New Haven to Senegal and Shanghai, female architects — many running their own firms — are invigorating the design of buildings and cities.
lead_paragraph: Architecture was long called a “gentleman’s profession,” which may have been true if by that you meant one that systematically excluded women for most of its existence. Before World War II, you could count the number of noted female architects on one hand. As late as the 1990s, the percentage of architecture firms owned by women in the United States was still in the single digits.

headline: Typhoon Hits Philippines, Bringing Heavy Rains and Stirring Painful Memories
abstract: Typhoon Mangkhut barreled into the northern Philippines with an intensity not seen since Typhoon Haiyan ravaged the country’s center in 2013.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — A powerful typhoon slammed the northern Philippines early Saturday, bringing high winds and torrential rains and evoking memories of Typhoon Haiyan, which ravaged the center of the country in 2013 and killed more than 6,000 people.

headline: She’s Calling the Shots as Director and Cinematographer
abstract: Reed Morano is taking on the apocalypse in her new film “I Think We’re Alone Now.” It’s lighter fare than her last project, about grieving parents.
lead_paragraph: In Reed Morano’s new film, “I Think We’re Alone Now,” opening Sept. 14, a misanthrope (Peter Dinklage) believes he’s the sole survivor of an apparent apocalypse until he runs into a mysterious young woman (Elle Fanning). As one of the few female directors who also serves as her own cinematographer, Ms. Morano may feel almost as alone. But that didn’t stop her from taking on that demanding dual role with her first movie either, the 2015 grieving-parents drama “Meadowland.”

headline: Why Zillow Addicts Can’t Look Away
abstract: Brokers say that Zestimates can be off base, but that doesn’t stop sellers from obsessing over what the website says their home is worth.
lead_paragraph: A couple of times a week, Nick Spencer checks the value of his four-bedroom house in Haddon Heights, N.J., on Zillow. He has no plans to move, describing the town, located about 10 miles from Philadelphia, as “Americana at its best,” and his Cape Cod style home as “a labor of love.”

headline: Amina Claudine Myers, a Singer Who Still Needs No Words
abstract: The 76-year-old performer will debut a new program that celebrates 1950s gospel, black spirituals and her own songbook in October.
lead_paragraph: Amina Claudine Myers was sitting in her apartment in Hell’s Kitchen, surrounded by paintings and photographs as she recalled a rehearsal there almost 40 years ago. She’d been playing the same baby grand piano that sits in the living room today, and Cecil McBee had brought his upright bass. She recalled that sounds came spontaneously to her lips. “I do remember thinking: You don’t need words to express,” she said. “Just your voice, the sound, can relay a message.”

headline: The Shows I’m Afraid to Look Forward To
abstract: Sometimes what you think you won’t like is what you love most.
lead_paragraph: Theater critics, when they pan a particular show, are often accused of hating the entire art form. I can’t speak for my possibly masochistic colleagues but, for me, that makes no sense. Every time I take my seat in the audience I do so with pleasure and with my mind prepared to engage and enjoy. The theater is where I have always felt safest and therefore most receptive to whatever new ideas might be on offer.

headline: Democrats (Wistfully) Take Aim at a Republican Stronghold: Evangelicals
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Evangelical Movement']
abstract: Conservative Christians have been a powerful voting bloc favoring Republicans as Democrats stood on the sidelines. Progressive evangelicals hope to change that.
lead_paragraph: For years Republicans have enjoyed the support of a powerful constituency: conservative evangelical Christians, whose passion on issues like opposition to abortion and support for Israel has aligned them with the party’s agenda. It has been an almost impenetrable voting bloc in recent years, and growing stronger, with more than 80 percent of white evangelical voters supporting President Trump in 2016.

headline: Sure, It’s Only September, but the Oscar Race Is in Full Swing
abstract: “Black Panther” and “A Star Is Born” are likely to make the final cut for best picture, while the best actress race is extra-crowded this year.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The 2018 award-season aspirants will include superheroes, space travelers and Lady Gaga, but will their movies prove popular enough to assuage the fears of an academy that nearly introduced an Oscar just for blockbusters? With three significant fall film festivals now on the books, including the Toronto International Film Festival heading into its final weekend, and with a few impressive holdovers from earlier in the year still making waves, it’s time to take a look at the clarified landscape of Academy Award contenders. Here are some of the movies and performances that your new Carpetbagger expects will be in the running for the six biggest Oscars.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Do it because it may help distract from the dreariness, or because it can help distract someone else. But do take the time to make food for the ones you love.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It is hard on mornings such as this one, with terrible winds, rain and the Atlantic Ocean bearing down on our neighbors in the Carolinas and surrounding states, to write brightly about the summer pasta (above) you might make this weekend, to serve alongside savory tomato sorbet, with pear kuchen for dessert. Hundreds of thousands have left their homes to seek shelter from Florence’s path, and millions more sit tensely, watching the storm models, looking out at the sky, wondering what’s going to happen, how bad it might be. Adrenaline is the flavor of the day.

headline: Your Future Should Be Bigger Than Your Past. Here’s How to Do It.
abstract: If your past feels bigger than whatever you can imagine in your future, it’s not a healthy sign. A single, focused question can help reframe things.
lead_paragraph: I recently got together with two of my best friends from high school, Jamie and Jason. We’ve been friends for over 30 years. We don’t see each other as often as we’d like to because life is busy. But when we do it’s always amazing.

headline: The Irresistible Allure of Pork and Fennel
abstract: The aromatic vegetable and its seeds beautifully flavor chops in this easy recipe.
lead_paragraph: While window-shopping in the West Village the other day, I had a sudden hankering for some fine, fat pork chops. I saw them — fetchingly displayed by the Italian sausage in the refrigerated case of a neighborhood butcher shop (the kind that are sadly disappearing) — and I craved them. If there was a moment’s hesitation, let us say the chops won out.

headline: Transparency Hasn’t Stopped Drug Companies From Corrupting Medical Research
abstract: The outrage over an influential doctor’s hidden millions is misplaced.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Dr. José Baselga resigned from his position as chief medical officer at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Earlier this month, ProPublica and The New York Times revealed that he’d received millions of dollars from drug and device companies whose fortunes he stood to affect. He also sat on the board of at least six companies, where his fiduciary responsibility to them might conflict with his obligations to the cancer center. Most of his outside income was not disclosed to the journals in which he published, in violation of their requirements.

headline: In This North Carolina Coastal Town, ‘Downtown Is Literally Underwater’
abstract: Hundreds were rescued from flood-marooned homes overnight, with another 150 awaiting rescue. “We are praying and hoping for the best,” one resident said.
lead_paragraph: NEW BERN, N.C. — There is plenty of past in this city, 308 years of it: colonial governors, Union troops, communities of freed slaves and yes, hurricanes, plenty of them. But none of it, at least nothing that anyone alive could remember, seemed to prepare New Bern for Hurricane Florence.

headline: How a Love of Jane Fonda and the Color Pink Created a California Dream House
abstract: Perched on a hill planted with fruit trees, one home in Eagle Rock takes the Los Angeles fantasy to new heights.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES BECKONS the restless. It hums a million small reasons to slough off your life and move there — 72 degrees and sunny (even when it’s not), the city feels like it unfurls forever, offering the wild promise of self-invention, a frontier land of permissiveness and cheap avocados and good light. It remains, as the artist David Hockney put it, “the edge of the Western world.”

headline: How to Make a Crossword Puzzle: The Series
abstract: Now, all in one place: Bring your theme ideas and follow along as New York Times constructors and editors pull back the curtain on puzzle making.

headline: China Should Match California’s Effort to Slow Climate Change
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Solar Energy', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Global Warming', 'Law and Legislation', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: By pledging to cut its emissions in half by midcentury, China would propel itself into a world-leading role in the fight against global warming.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At long last, a handful of political leaders are starting to set goals on greenhouse emissions that are consistent with the magnitude of the climate crisis.

headline: Fallen Stars, From Roseanne Barr to Kevin Spacey, Rearrange Fall TV
abstract: This season brings several shows that are remaking themselves after actors who were accused of acting reprehensibly were fired.
lead_paragraph: It’s harder to get away with being horrible in Hollywood than it used to be.

headline: After Massachusetts Gas Explosions, Weary Residents Ask, What Happened?
abstract: An investigation has begun into the cause of the explosions that burned at least 80 buildings, but attention was squarely focused on the natural gas lines of a utility.
lead_paragraph: LAWRENCE, Mass. — For miles around, the neighborhoods were empty and silent. Stores were dark, schools closed, sidewalks empty. At corners, the stoplights were powerless and blank, but it didn’t really matter since only a few cars ventured out.

headline: For Elderly Women With Breast Cancer, Surgery May Not Be the Best Option
abstract: Nursing home patients may be frail or have other diseases, leading some doctors to advise hormone therapy rather than operations.
lead_paragraph: Annie Krause moved into a nursing home in Detroit in 2015, when she was 98 years old. She had grown frail. Arthritis, recurrent infections and hypertension had made it difficult for her to manage on her own.

headline: Behind the Cover: Maya Rudolph
abstract: For this issue, a look at the master of impressions.

headline: Canelo Álvarez vs. G.G.G.: Start Time, Odds and How to Watch
abstract: Two of the finest fighters of their generation, Canelo Álvarez and Gennady Golovkin, will meet again on Saturday. Their first meeting ended in a draw.
lead_paragraph: In an era in which the best boxers often avoid fighting each other, the sport is treating fans to a second matchup between two of the finest fighters of their generation when Canelo Álvarez meets Gennady Golovkin on Saturday in Las Vegas.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A question has loomed over Washington: What will the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, do when he wraps up his investigation into whether the Trump campaign conspired with Russia and whether President Trump obstructed justice?

headline: The Playlist: Lana Del Rey’s Smoldering Return, and 12 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks from Kurt Vile, Al Green, Mariah Carey, Gucci Mane and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Freezing Credit Will Now Be Free. Here’s Why You Should Go for It.
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Computer Security', 'Credit Scores', 'Identity Theft', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Privacy', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: A year after the Equifax security breach, most people have not frozen their credit records. Consumer advocates recommend freezes to foil identity theft.
lead_paragraph: Consumers will soon be able to freeze their credit files without charge. So if you have not yet frozen your files — a recommended step to foil identity theft — now is a good time to take action, consumer advocates say.

headline: Prominent Cancer Researcher Resigns from Dartmouth Amid Plagiarism Charges
keywords: ['Plagiarism', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Research', 'Academic and Scientific Journals', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Dr. H. Gilbert Welch was seen as an authority on the risks of aggressive screening for breast cancer and over-diagnosis. He disputed the charges.
lead_paragraph: One of the country’s most influential researchers in cancer screening has resigned from his post at Dartmouth College, after a two-year internal investigation concluded he had plagiarized a graph included in a paper published in a prominent journal.

headline: An Art-World Lion Finds a Den in a Midcentury Landmark
abstract: In the studio with the painter Peter Halley as he prepares for his “punky” and personal installation in Manhattan’s Lever House.
lead_paragraph: Walk into the artist Peter Halley’s sprawling West Chelsea studio and the first thing you’ll notice is a massive plaster cast replica of an ancient bronze sculpture of Poseidon, procured from the Athens archaeological museum a decade and a half ago. He — Poseidon, not Halley — stands nude and musclebound on a rolling platform, arms outstretched like a surfer, hovering in front of a shelf of fluorescent paints. “I never meant to leave it here, but it’s just so perfect,” says the painter, gazing fondly at the Greek god looming overhead. One time, a snooty European collector visited and snarked that Cy Twombly kept actual antiquities in his studio. The artist chuckles. “I was like: ‘I’m not Cy Twombly.’ ”

headline: Gas Explosions Ravage Homes in Massachusetts Towns
abstract: Dozens of homes burned and thousands more were affected by an overpressurized gas line in Lawrence, Andover and North Andover, Mass., the authorities said. At least one person was killed.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of homes burned and thousands more were affected by an overpressurized gas line in Lawrence, Andover and North Andover, Mass., the authorities said. At least one person was killed.

headline: Minor Offenses From Long Ago Are Keeping Dozens of Migrant Families Separated
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Child Custody and Support', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Salvadoran-Americans']
abstract: Even minor misdemeanor convictions are keeping some migrant parents from being reunited with their children, who must remain in federal shelters.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A court-imposed deadline for reuniting “tender-age” children separated from their parents at the border came and went long ago. But a 3-year-old girl from El Salvador is going on her sixth month in a federal immigration shelter, one of dozens of migrant children stranded in the system because authorities have determined they cannot be returned to their parents.

headline: Review: Resonant Bodies Festival Gives Voices Room to Breathe
abstract: In three nights and nine sets, the plucky festival drew together New York musical scenes that aren’t always connected.
lead_paragraph: While the 800-pound gorillas of New York’s classical scene, the Metropolitan Opera and New York Philharmonic, prepare for their season-opening galas, a pluckier, scrappier operation took center stage this week. Over three evenings at Roulette in Downtown Brooklyn, the Resonant Bodies Festival presented 45-minute sets by nine different vocalists, three per night. Not a single performance was dull. And at least one set per performance was astonishing.

headline: Janet Weinberg, 63, Dies; Advocate for Gay Causes and the Disabled
abstract: Ms. Weinberg’s fund-raising work for the Gay Men’s Health Crisis led to her being named chief operating officer and then chief executive.
lead_paragraph: Janet Weinberg, an advocate for people with disabilities who found her calling as a top executive and fund-raiser at social service organizations like the Gay Men’s Health Crisis, died on Sept. 1 in the Bronx. She was 63.

headline: It’s a Climate Summit. Why Is the Electric Shuttle Nearly Empty?
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Global Warming', 'Transportation', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles']
abstract: Organizers of the Global Climate Action Summit aimed to produce a largely carbon-free event, but it’s not always easy getting everyone to go along.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It’s not easy going green. Offer electric buses and some still choose hulking Chevy Suburbans. Require paperless brochures and some hawk their colorful booklets.

headline: Eliud Kipchoge Is the Greatest Marathoner, Ever
abstract: The reigning Olympic champion has won an unheard-of eight straight marathons. Can he capture the world record Sunday in Berlin?
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Eliud Kipchoge, the most decorated marathoner on the planet, is a man of immense self-discipline. He rolls out of bed at 5 a.m. for his morning runs. He splits his time between his home in Eldoret, Kenya, where he lives with his wife and three children, and a training camp up in the hills, 8,000 feet above sea level, where he shares chores with teammates.

headline: Women Have Won More Primaries Than Ever Before. Will They Set a Record in November?
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Women and Girls', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Governors', 'States (US)']

headline: Police Move to Clear Treehouse Protest Against Coal Mine in German Forest
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Coal', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Environment']
abstract: German police began tearing down the first of about 60 treehouses to evict protesters from a site that has come to symbolize the country’s split over coal.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The police started evicting protesters from treehouses on Friday in what remains of a formerly vast forest in Western Germany, moving cranes and backhoes into a strip of ancient woodland where activists have lived for years on the edge of a growing open-pit mine.

headline: The Craftsman Still Making Windsor Chairs by Hand
abstract: At his father’s workshop in remote Vermont, a solitary woodworker preserves the craft of building an American symbol.
lead_paragraph: SOME SYMBOLS OF America’s complex origins — Columbus Day, Andrew Jackson on the $20 bill, statues of Confederate generals — haven’t aged well, but the Windsor chair, preferred seating of the founding fathers, remains enshrined as an object of beauty and desire.

headline: Water Droplets Don’t Just Hover on a Hot Pan. They Roll.
abstract: Physicists took a deeper look at the Leidenfrost effect, which you’ve likely experienced when you’ve dripped water into a pan to test its temperature.
lead_paragraph: Drip water on a hot pan, and the droplets will skitter around the pan, speeding like tiny mad hovercraft on cushions of steam.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As part of its policy to end all aid for Palestinian civilians, the United States is blocking millions of dollars to programs that build relationships between Israelis and Palestinians, according to current and former American officials briefed on the change.

headline: 3 Investments That May Have Hit Their Peak
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Private Equity', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Venture Capital', 'Real Estate Investment Trusts', 'Personal Finances']

lead_paragraph: This week is the 10th anniversary of the collapse of Lehman Brothers, a flash point in the financial crisis. The economy has rebounded since then and the stock market has risen to record highs, but a feeling of caution looms over many investors.

headline: Volkswagen Beetle, Symbol of ’60s Counterculture, Will Be Discontinued Again
abstract: The German carmaker’s United States unit, the only division still turning out the curvy car originally developed at Hitler’s direction, will end production of the vehicle in July.
lead_paragraph: The Volkswagen Beetle — the curvy car developed at Adolf Hitler’s direction that became an improbable symbol of the hippie counterculture of the 1960s — is set to become a thing of the past.

headline: A Bloody Rivalry for the Throne, This Time With Margot Robbie
abstract: “Mary Queen of Scots,” featuring Ms. Robbie as Queen Elizabeth I, is one of many movies to explore a notorious battle for power. Here’s a guide.
lead_paragraph: Those gowns. That hair. That world-shaping geopolitical intrigue. In “Mary Queen of Scots,” which opens Dec. 7, a pair of Renaissance frenemies returns. Mary Stuart, a queen of Scotland and fleetingly queen consort of France, and her cousin Queen Elizabeth I, were rivals for the English throne. (Mary and her Catholic supporters thought so, anyway.) Some early letters suggest a warm relationship — Elizabeth signed one “a dear sister and a faithful friend.” But Elizabeth eventually had Mary imprisoned. When evidence of an assassination plot surfaced, she had her beheaded.

headline: Russians Planned Attack on Lab Testing Salisbury Nerve Agent, Swiss Say
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The Dutch expelled two Russian agents preparing a cyber attack on a Swiss lab, officials say, adding a new twist to Moscow’s clashes with the West.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Two Russian spies caught in the Netherlands and expelled had been plotting cyber sabotage of a Swiss defense laboratory analyzing the nerve agent used to poison a former Russian agent in Britain, Swiss officials said Friday.

headline: For His Next Act, a Ukrainian Rock Star Looks to Politics
abstract: Svyatoslav I. Vakarchuk, Ukraine’s favorite musician, sang the protest anthems for two popular uprisings and is now considering a run for president.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — In the midst of Ukraine’s revolution, the pop singer Svyatoslav I. Vakarchuk jumped onto a stage before almost a quarter of a million protesters. With steam billowing from his mouth in the frigid air, he clenched a microphone wrapped in Ukraine’s blue and yellow flag and sang to his country: “My darling! Rise up my dear! Wake up!”

headline: Even in Better Times, Some Americans Seem Farther Behind. Here’s Why.
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Whites', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: Two groups in particular — whites without a college degree, and black and Hispanic college graduates — have lagged as incomes and wealth have grown.
lead_paragraph: Americans’ household earnings are finally stretching back to their pre-recession heights. But feeling secure and comfortable isn’t only a measure of how much money you have. It’s also a measure of how much you have compared with others.

headline: The Credit Crunch and the Great Recession (Wonkish)
abstract: Ben Bernanke argues that it was mainly about finance. I have (friendly) questions.
lead_paragraph: OK, this is weird. There’s an economic dispute underway about the causes of the Great Recession — but that’s not what’s weird. What’s so strange in these days and times is that it is being carried out among well-informed people who actually look at data and argue in good faith. Hey, guys, don’t you know that sort of thing went out a couple of decades ago?

headline: 5 Dangers of Flooding in Hurricane Florence
keywords: ['Hurricane Florence (2018)', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Floods', 'Weather', 'Water', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: Experts provide the steps you can take to avoid them.
lead_paragraph: Drenching rains were inundating North Carolina on Friday as Hurricane Florence crawled inland at three miles an hour. Storm surges, overflowing waterways and intense rain that might dump as much as 40 inches could leave entire communities underwater. “Catastrophic flash flooding is expected to continue to worsen today,” the National Weather Service warned.

lead_paragraph: Citigroup agreed to pay more than $12 million to settle a regulator’s claims that it misled investors who thought they were paying a premium to keep their trading activity shielded from interference by high-frequency traders, the Securities and Exchange Commission has announced.

headline: The Jay Horwitz Show, Co-Starring Generations of Mets
abstract: The ultimate team lifer has a new role after decades as the Mets’ public-relations director, a run during which he mentored Darryl Strawberry and endured John Franco’s pranks.
lead_paragraph: When Kirk Gibson shook Dodger Stadium with his famous home run to win the opening game of the 1988 World Series, Jay Horwitz was stationed in the Oakland Athletics’ dugout, surrounded by gloom. Five years later, he felt a similar sensation in Toronto, standing in another losing dugout for another magic moment.

headline: Why Your Cardiologist Should Ask About Your Love Life
abstract: The heart may not be the origin of our feelings, but it is affected by them.
lead_paragraph: For many years and across many cultures, the heart was thought to be where our emotions resided. The word “emotion” derives in part from the French verb émouvoir, meaning “to stir,” and perhaps it is only natural that emotions would be linked to an organ characterized by its agitated movement.

headline: At Toronto, Women Who Are Shockingly, Thrillingly Human
abstract: Nicole Kidman in “Destroyer,” Natalie Portman in “Vox Lux” and other star turns are at the heart of a film festival filled with female-centric stories.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — “Destroyer,” a down-and-dirty thriller starring a sensational Nicole Kidman, isn’t the kind of movie that tends to have a red-carpet moment at the Cannes Film Festival. It’s too brutal, too pulpy and deliberately ugly. All that made it ideal for the Toronto International Film Festival, a sprawling showcase for unapologetic genre fictions and pleasurably difficult art films. The event’s size gives it abundant variety, which in turn is a reminder that a festival movie doesn’t need to conform to some received idea of cinema. There are 342 titles in this year’s edition, which ends Sunday, and it’s just too big and aesthetically diverse to set a clear new-season agenda, as smaller, more selective festivals try to do.

headline: They’ve Made Lots of Bubble Tea. Now They’ll Make the Pearls Too.
abstract: The Boba Guys chain has opened a Bay Area factory to produce the tapioca pearls that define the popular drink.
lead_paragraph: The partners behind Boba Guys, a chain of bubble-tea cafes, already made their own infusions and syrups to go with the tea leaves they imported from China, Taiwan and Japan. A few years ago, they got to thinking, why not make the pleasingly chewy tapioca pearls from scratch, too?

headline: David Yallop, Writer Who Saw a Deadly Vatican Conspiracy, Dies at 81
abstract: An investigative journalist, he was best known for “In God’s Name,” a best seller that claimed that Pope John Paul I was murdered in a Vatican plot.
lead_paragraph: David Yallop, an investigative journalist who wrote popular books about true crime and conspiracy, including a best seller asserting that Pope John Paul I was murdered as part of a Vatican plot, died on Aug. 23 in London. He was 81.

headline: Calm Before the Season: The Week in Classical Music
abstract: Preparations for the start of the fall music maelstrom were on the mind of our classical editor.
lead_paragraph: [Read all of our classical coverage here.]

headline: The Hacking of America
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Constitution (US)', 'News and News Media', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Political and technological disruption have fed off each other since the nation’s founding. Now they are dangerously out of whack.
lead_paragraph: Every government is a machine, and every machine has its tinkerers — and its jams. From the start, machines have driven American democracy and, just as often, crippled it. The printing press, the telegraph, the radio, the television, the mainframe, cable TV, the internet: Each had wild-eyed boosters who promised that a machine could hold the republic together, or make it more efficient, or repair the damage caused by the last machine. Each time, this assertion would be both right and terribly wrong. But lately, it’s mainly wrong, chiefly because the rules that prevail on the internet were devised by people who fundamentally don’t believe in government.

headline: In Face of Trump Criticism, NATO Works to Build Conservative Support
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Jens Stoltenberg, the head of NATO, worked Capitol Hill this week to argue that the alliance is critical not just for Europe but also for bolstering American military and intelligence agencies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The head of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization worked to shore up support in Washington this week, with boosters of the alliance anxious to retain the support of American conservatives amid criticism by President Trump and ahead of a possible Senate vote next year on expansion.

headline: For the First Time, the Met Will Perform Opera on Sundays
abstract: Seeking more ticket buyers, the company will add Sunday matinees and take a midwinter break in February.
lead_paragraph: It was not until 1919 that New York State legalized Sunday baseball games and what were then called “moving picture shows.” Now, nearly a century later, another never-on-Sunday tradition is coming to an end: The Metropolitan Opera will begin performing Sunday matinees next year for the first time, the company announced Friday.

headline: At Dua Lipa Concert, Dancing Fans Were Dragged Out
keywords: ['Music', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Guards', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']

headline: A Chorus Remembers Michael Brown in ‘Antigone in Ferguson’
abstract: This combination of a classical tragedy and a contemporary discussion group finds a mirror for Ferguson, Mo., in ancient Thebes.
lead_paragraph: Never underestimate the wisdom of the chorus during a tragedy, onstage or in life. It may be the ambitious monarchs and vengeful soldiers who always, often disastrously, initiate the action. But it is the chorus, so much more than a backup group, that has always had the long view. The mighty ignore its voice at their peril.

headline: Manafort Folds. Now What?
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: His cooperation agreement with Robert Mueller is the start of a new chapter in the special counsel’s investigation.
lead_paragraph: Those who practice criminal law — including the three of us — have long predicted that Paul Manafort, the disgraced former Trump campaign chairman, would eventually fold to Robert Mueller, the special counsel. On Friday, we were proven right: Mr. Manafort and the special counsel have reached an extensive cooperation agreement, among the most significant developments in Mr. Mueller’s investigation to date.

headline: As the Ice Melts, NASA Will Be Watching
abstract: The new ICESat-2, set to launch on Saturday, can measure changes in the planet’s ice that are less than the width of a pencil.
lead_paragraph: If all goes well for NASA on Saturday, climate scientists will get a new eye in the sky that will be able to watch the Earth’s ice melt practically drip by drip.

headline: Young Americans, What Do You Think About the Kavanaugh Confirmation?

abstract: Brett Kavanaugh’s confirmation vote, barring delays caused by allegations of sexual assault, is scheduled for Sept. 20. What’s at stake for you?

headline: On Politics With Lisa Lerer: On to November
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: What we learned from the primaries, a trip to Charleston, and reading your emails.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host. Tonight we’re following Hurricane Florence updates. If you’re in the path of the storm, stay safe.

headline: As Aaron Judge Returns, Yankees Pitchers Make Another Case for Optimism
abstract: A shutout by Masahiro Tanaka and Luis Cessa on Friday may have been more important than Judge’s presence or the Yankees’ 11-run scoring binge against the Blue Jays.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees on Friday welcomed Aaron Judge back to their active roster, if not to their batting order, for the final 16 games of the season, a move that Manager Aaron Boone hoped would inspire his team to regain some swagger.

headline: WADA Set to Bring Russia Back to World Sport
abstract: An independent panel has recommended allowing the country to begin testing its athletes for performance-enhancing drugs.
lead_paragraph: Russia moved a step closer to leaving behind its status as a global sports pariah on Friday after an influential panel recommended that the country’s banned antidoping agency be reinstated.

headline: The Top 5 Takeaways From New York Fashion Week
abstract: All the reviews, the people and the trends.
lead_paragraph: Hello and happy London Fashion Week!

headline: Your Friday Evening News Briefing: Tropical Storm Florence, Paul Manafort, Brett Kavanaugh
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Walter Mischel, 88, Psychologist Famed for Marshmallow Test, Dies
abstract: Dr. Mischel’s experiments with preschoolers and sweets zeroed in on the importance of delayed gratification, and his insights changed the study of personality.
lead_paragraph: Walter Mischel, whose studies of delayed gratification in young children clarified the importance of self-control in human development, and whose work led to a broad reconsideration of how personality is understood, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Federal Panel Alarmed as Thousands Are Dropped From Medicaid in Arkansas
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'States (US)']
abstract: New work requirements imposed on the state’s Medicaid recipients have left 4,350 low-income residents without health coverage. “I hope these data scare the pants off people,” a panel member said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of a federal advisory panel expressed alarm this week that 4,350 low-income people in Arkansas had lost Medicaid coverage because they failed to show they were complying with new work requirements held up by the Trump administration as a model for the nation.

headline: Where Are All the American Orchestra Conductors?
abstract: Music directors from abroad have had an avenue for advancement unavailable to most homegrown aspirants. One result: a tradition of foreign-born maestros leading U.S. orchestras.
lead_paragraph: Before winning acclaim as a virtuoso composer and a charismatic popularizer of classical music, Leonard Bernstein attained fame as a conductor. In 1943, still green at 25 and assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic, he took the podium as a last-minute stand-in for an ailing Bruno Walter. With no rehearsal and everything on the line, he saved the day and gained celebrity overnight.

headline: The World of Today Brought to You by the Financial Crisis
keywords: ['Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Recession and Depression', 'Interest Rates', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: From bank bailouts to rock-bottom interest rates, the fallout influenced economics, politics and even the rise of Bitcoin over the past decade. Here’s a rough guide to some of those changes.
lead_paragraph: From bank bailouts to rock-bottom interest rates, the fallout influenced economics, politics and even the rise of Bitcoin over the past decade. Here’s a rough guide to some of those changes.

headline: Nancy Blomberg, Champion of Native American Art, Dies at 72
abstract: As a curator at the Denver Art Museum, she valued American Indian works as art, not as ethnographic specimens.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Blomberg, who as a curator at the Denver Art Museum treated American Indian artworks as aesthetic creations, not artifacts, and championed the artists who made them, died on Sept. 2 at her home in Breckenridge, Colo. She was 72.

headline: Pompeo Calls a Former Diplomat’s Meetings with Iranians ‘Unseemly and Unprecedented’
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The secretary of state criticized John Kerry for discussing the jettisoned nuclear deal with Iranian diplomats. Mr. Kerry shrugged it off and plugged his new book.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Friday excoriated John Kerry, who was the top American diplomat in the final years of the Obama administration, for meeting with Iranian officials in what he described as “unseemly and unprecedented” discussions.

headline: Are Women Penalized More Than Men in Tennis? Data on Fines Says No
keywords: ['Tennis', 'United States Open (Tennis)', 'Australian Open (Tennis)', 'Wimbledon Tennis Tournament', 'French Open (Tennis)', 'Officiating (Sports)']
abstract: Men have been fined for misbehavior more frequently than women at Grand Slam events in the past 20 years, with one significant exception: coaching violations.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams argued that she was subject to a double standard when she was cited for verbal abuse by the chair umpire Carlos Ramos during the United States Open women’s final last Saturday.

headline: Wreaking Havoc, Deadly Storm Cuts Through the Philippines
abstract: By Sunday morning, at least 25 deaths from Typhoon Mangkhut had been reported. But Philippine officials were still assessing the damage.
lead_paragraph: Typhoon Mangkhut roared through the Philippines on Saturday, after tens of thousands of people evacuated their homes ahead of the 550-mile-wide storm. By Sunday morning, at least 25 deaths had been reported.

headline: Florence Is Blamed for at Least Five Deaths as It Roars Ashore in North Carolina
abstract: The storm made landfall near Wilmington, N.C., and had contributed to the deaths of at least five people. Hundreds more had to be rescued.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, N.C. — After slamming into the Carolina coast on Friday with powerful winds and torrential rains, Hurricane Florence left a trail of devastation as it crawled over the southeastern part of the state, posing what may be its greatest threat in the days ahead as it roars inland with what are shaping up to be record-setting quantities of water.

headline: Rachid Taha, 59, Algerian Rocker Who Spoke for Immigrants, Dies
abstract: Mr. Taha, who led the group Carte de Séjour before beginning a solo career, melded his Arabic heritage with punk, funk and electronic beats.
lead_paragraph: Rachid Taha, who became a rock star in France with assertive lyrics and music that melded his Algerian heritage with punk, funk and electronic beats, has died in Les Lilas, a Paris suburb. He was 59.

headline: He Stopped at a Traffic Light in Queens. Moments Later, He Was Shot Dead.
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers']
abstract: A Rikers Island correctional officer on his way to work was found in his car, about a half mile from his home, the police said. No arrests have been made.
lead_paragraph: It’s unclear if the two men — a New York City correctional officer and a motorcyclist — knew each other when they met along a quiet roadway in the Jamaica section of Queens early Friday morning, the police said.

headline: Why the Left Couldn’t Take the Top of the Ticket in New York
keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Elections, Lieutenant Governors', 'Elections, Attorneys General', 'Voting and Voters', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Party challengers in statewide races seemed to have momentum. But in the end, it was the newcomers in local contests who prevailed.
lead_paragraph: In Thursday’s New York Democratic primary, the top of the ticket held for the establishment, giving Governor Andrew M. Cuomo, and his lieutenant governor, Kathy Hochul, a near guarantee of another term. The governor’s anointed choice for attorney general, Letitia James, beat Zephyr Teachout, who seemed to have the most momentum in the last days of the campaign.

headline: Peter Donat, Actor Who Played a Panoply of Roles, Dead at 90
abstract: Mr. Donat acted often on the screen and had a recurring role on “The X Files.” But he said he was most gratified by theatrical work.
lead_paragraph: Peter Donat, a Canadian-born character actor who played a wide variety of classical and contemporary roles in theater, film and television, died on Monday at his home in Point Reyes Station, Calif. He was 90.

headline: Trade Ministers Call for W.T.O. Overhaul, but Offer Few Details
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'Protectionism (Trade)', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: In a tacit acknowledgment that Mr. Trump has shaken the international trading system, G20 officials sought to reduce tensions.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Trade ministers from the Group of 20 countries said Friday that there was an “urgent” need to overhaul the World Trade Organization, which President Trump has threatened to withdraw the United States from.

headline: Small Investors Are Prey, Again, for the Wolves of Wall Street
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Financial Brokers', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Congress tried to protect ordinary Americans’ portfolios with the Dodd-Frank Act, but today they are more vulnerable than ever.
lead_paragraph: Ten years after the collapse of Lehman Brothers, and despite Congress’s efforts to protect Mom and Pop with the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act, the small investor is increasingly vulnerable to shoddy practices on Wall Street.

keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Corporations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Computers and the Internet']

headline: Taking Page From 2016, Trump Claims Democrats Will Destroy Safety Net
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Medicare', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: In his presidential run, Mr. Trump said his Republican primary opponents would cut older Americans’ benefits. In this year’s elections, he has directed the same attacks at Democrats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump had a blunt message for Montana voters last week, an unapologetic reprise of the promise to protect Medicare and Social Security that he used during the 2016 presidential campaign to successfully appeal to older, blue-collar voters.

headline: This Is Not the End of Trump
abstract: Chaos in the White House has not diminished the chances of a two-term presidency.
lead_paragraph: David Halberstam, in “The Best and the Brightest,” listed the “virtues Americans have always respected” as “hard work, self-sacrifice, decency, loyalty.” I don’t believe that’s changed since 1972. President Trump, in his sublime indecency, fails the test on all these qualities except perhaps hard work, yet tens of millions of Americans still admire him.

headline: The Great Canadian Compromise: The Canada Letter
abstract: A measure that allowed Canada to create its own constitution in 1982 but left many unhappy has returned to haunt the current political scene.
lead_paragraph: In the unlikely event that President Trump was paying attention to events in Canada this week, he might have felt a touch of envy.

headline: Medicine’s Financial Contamination
keywords: ['Research', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Clinical Trials', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Doctors', 'Hospitals', 'Academic and Scientific Journals']
abstract: Disclosure rules may seem arcane, but money corrupts medical research.
lead_paragraph: The fall from grace last week of Dr. José Baselga, the former chief scientific officer of Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, illuminated a longstanding problem of modern medicine: Potentially corrupting payments by drug and medical device makers to influential people at research hospitals are far more common than either side publicly acknowledges.

headline: Change Comes to Albany, if Not the Governor’s Mansion
keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Reformers win real victories in New York’s Democratic primary.
lead_paragraph: New York voters have spoken, and Gov. Andrew Cuomo remains the most powerful man in New York politics.

headline: Quotation of the Day: The Philosopher-King of Marathon
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 15, 2018.
lead_paragraph: “When I run, I feel good. My mind feels good. I sleep in a free way, and I enjoy life.”

headline: The People’s Republic of Cruelty
keywords: ['Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Religion and Belief', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: A regime at war with the human soul will eventually lose.
lead_paragraph: Every now and then, when credulous Western observers aren’t fawning over China’s high-speed rail network or calculating the precise moment when its economy will become the world’s largest, a news story breaks through to remind us that the People’s Republic remains what it has always been: a place of fear and cruelty. One such story, by the Times’s Chris Buckley, is worth particular attention.

headline: Welcome to the President’s Rat Pack, Paul Manafort
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The demand for justice once again outweighs the president’s demand for loyalty.
lead_paragraph: Pardon us, but was it only three weeks ago that President Trump expressed “such respect” for Paul Manafort, his former campaign chairman and freshly minted felon, who had refused to cooperate with the special counsel’s office and took his federal bank- and tax-fraud conviction like a “brave man”?

headline: Aaron Judge Returns to the Yankees, but the Clock Is Still Ticking
abstract: The Yankees beat the Blue Jays, 11-0, in Judge’s first game back on the roster since he hurt his wrist in July. He could play only defense Friday, and the Yankees said they would not take the risk of letting him swing a bat in a game yet.
lead_paragraph: It got late early for the Yankees this season, as Yogi Berra would have said. With more than two weeks left in the regular season, the pennant race is virtually over. The Boston Red Sox should bring Champagne with them to Yankee Stadium next week to celebrate another division title.

headline: Julia Salazar, the Left’s Post-Truth Politician
abstract: The democratic socialist lied. And lied. And lied. Then she won handily in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: According to The Washington Post’s running count, Donald Trump is averaging 7.6 “Trumpian claims” a day. One wonders how many Salazarian claims Julia Salazar has spoken.

headline: A Dallas Police Officer Shot Her Neighbor, and a City Is Full of Questions
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The shooting of an unarmed black man by a police officer who entered his apartment has polarized Dallas and inflamed racial tensions.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Botham Shem Jean analyzed risk for a living at a global auditing firm. For someone in his line of work, the evening was shaping up to be as risk-free as it gets: Alone, in his one-bedroom apartment one block from the Dallas Police Department headquarters.

headline: Progress
abstract: David Liben-Nowell is back, with a forward-looking puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE —  One of the things that struck me about today’s excellent puzzle was the freshness of its two spanning across entries, which I always assume are the “seeds” or inspirations of a particular grid (which is not always true, in fact, but the norm). They seem to play off each other as hopeful signs of human evolution, one societal, one technological.

headline: Evelyn Rodriguez, Mother of Girl Killed by MS-13, Is Fatally Struck by S.U.V. Before Memorial
abstract: Ms. Rodriguez, who was a vocal advocate for victims of MS-13 gang members, attended the State of the Union address in January at President Trump’s invitation.
lead_paragraph: Evelyn Rodriguez, who became a vocal advocate for victims of gang violence after members of the transnational gang MS-13 were charged with killing her 16-year-old daughter, died after being struck by an S.U.V. on Friday — just before a memorial service for the second anniversary of her daughter’s death.

headline: Manafort Plea Deal Casts New Scrutiny on Lobbyists He Recruited
keywords: ['Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Legal Profession', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Foreign Agents Registration Act', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: New evidence laid out by the special counsel exposed the sometimes surreptitious ways in which foreign interests try to buy influence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2012, Paul Manafort had a problem. He was seeking a way to bolster the interests of his pro-Russian Ukrainian clients in Washington, but he did not want to set off tough federal disclosure rules for foreign lobbying.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: The Creative Arts Emmys and ‘What’s Eating Gilbert Grape’
abstract: Gear up for the Emmy Awards with the Creative Arts ceremony. Or stream a touching ’90s drama.
lead_paragraph: Gear up for the Emmy Awards with the Creative Arts ceremony. Or stream a touching ’90s drama.

headline: Ruby Washington: A Quiet Trailblazer in Photojournalism
abstract: Ms. Washington, the first African-American female staff photographer for The New York Times, knew how to keep her cool even in tense situations.
lead_paragraph: Ruby Washington was an intensely private person. Her daughter, Courtney, said she had no idea her mother was the first African-American woman to become a staff photographer at The New York Times. Her editors said that while she won awards, she didn’t go to galas to accept them. And when she fell ill with breast cancer in 2010, many of her colleagues had no clue, since she kept on working.

headline: Off the Washington Coast, a Restaurant That Follows the North Star of Localism
abstract: At Ursa Minor, on Lopez Island, the menu relies heavily on the bounty of the island — but also on nontraditional ingredients.
lead_paragraph: Three hours by car and ferry from Seattle’s frenetic tech scene, Lopez Island pokes along at its own neighborly pace. Slow-pez, the affectionate nickname used by many of its 2,500 full-time residents, is the third largest of Washington state’s San Juan Islands. A single desultory village serves as hub for these 30 square miles of rolling farmland and evergreen forest bisected by two-lane roads, where passing motorists give each other a little wave. Everyone’s a neighbor on Lopez, even if you’re new to the island.

headline: #MeToo in the Monastery: A Chinese Abbot’s Fall Stirs Questions on Buddhism’s Path
abstract: A charismatic rising star was China’s most important leader to be toppled by charges of sexual and financial misconduct.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Over the past two decades, religion in China has boomed, and no faith has benefited more than Buddhism. The number of temples has tripled, monks and abbots have become well-known public figures, and China has used the faith to build ties around the world, sending out nuns and monks on good-will missions.

headline: Fraying Ties With Trump Put Jim Mattis’s Fate in Doubt
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Officials say that the president has soured on his defense secretary, and that Mr. Mattis is increasingly weary of capricious demands from his boss.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Back when their relationship was fresh and new, and President Trump still called his defense secretary “Mad Dog” — a nickname Jim Mattis detests — the wiry retired Marine general often took a dinner break to eat burgers with his boss in the White House residence.

headline: The Progressive Playbook: How These Candidates Pulled Off Their Upsets
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Campaign Finance', 'Endorsements', 'Elections, Governors', 'Political Advertising', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Among the surprises this primary season were several high-profile upsets from the left. The Times asked some of the strategists and candidates behind these wins to break them down.
lead_paragraph: It has become a familiar pattern this primary season. The day after a surprising victory by a progressive underdog — say Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, Andrew Gillum of Florida, Jahana Hayes in Connecticut, Wesley Bell in Missouri or Ayanna Pressley in Massachusetts — national audiences rush to meet the latest Democrat who defied expectations.

headline: A Classic Dallas Hotel Gets Cool and Contemporary
abstract: The Adolphus still has its distinctive chandelier and fireplaces, but after a makeover, menus are more refined and the rooftop is home to a relaxing pool and bar.
lead_paragraph: From $239 a night.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: California tries a new tack on gun violence. What you didn’t see on Miss America. Maya Rudolph on mastering impressions. And King Kong takes the stage.
lead_paragraph: It’s officially the last weekend of summer, and while the sweep of a new season is upon us, our journalism remains unwavering. You have our permission to take the rest of the weekend off and enjoy some great reads from the past week.

headline: 12 Dead, Power Failures and Catastrophic Flooding in the Carolinas
abstract: Fierce rains were likely to produce “catastrophic flash flooding and prolonged significant river flooding,” the National Hurricane Center said.
lead_paragraph: CONWAY, S.C. — Florence, the powerful storm that has already left at least 12 people dead and about a million without power on the East Coast, continued to move inland at an ominously sluggish pace Saturday, fat with rain and threatening to deliver hardship and devastation far beyond the wind-battered coasts.

headline: Wednesday Martin Dares to Call Her New Book ‘Untrue’
abstract: After a scoffed-at but successful pop ethnography of Park Avenue, she turns to the topic of infidelity.
lead_paragraph: Looking improbably dainty in a white summer frock, Wednesday Martin stepped to the front of a glass-enclosed room in Sag Harbor, N.Y., wielding a mandrake-like piece of pink plastic. “This is your clitoris,” she told her mostly female listeners.

headline: The Flea Circus
abstract: Dueling dealers! $1,000 T-shirts! Homemade fruit spreads! In the age of eBay, the Rose Bowl market’s still got it.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — At 4 a.m. on the second Sunday of every month, headlamps light up like fireflies in Lot K of the Rose Bowl Stadium here. They are worn by collectors searching for treasure: Hans Wegner club chairs, perfectly aged Levi’s jeans (preferably from before 1971), and AC/DC and Wu Tang Clan concert T-shirts.

headline: How I Dressed to Heal My Heartbreak
abstract: One of my only productive strategies for working with fear was dressing with intention. That became even more important when I was healing myself.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2013, I was crying to a friend on a Brooklyn-bound train when a perky stranger reached out and waved in my direction a tiny red copy of “Awakening Loving-Kindness.” “I think you need this more than I do,” he said. I took the book, thanked him and examined the photo of its author, the Buddhist nun Pema Chödrön, on the cover. Someday, I’ll read this, I thought.

headline: A Simple Life
abstract: Mennonites living in Belize exist apart from the government, with limited technology and surrounded by farmable land.
lead_paragraph: When Mennonites began moving to Belize in the late 1950s, they did so for the same reason their ancestors have migrated for centuries: to live in line with their religious beliefs, including the separation of church and state, pacifism and sustainability, without interference. That means apart from the government, with limited technology and surrounded by farmable land.

headline: How a Ukrainian Hairdresser Became a Front for Paul Manafort
keywords: ['Identity Theft', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Corporations', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: To evade taxes, many shell companies are headed by “nominee directors” who can be homeless people or even victims of identity theft.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — At first glance, what happened to Yevgeny G. Kaseyev hardly seems like misfortune.

headline: Alexachung: Spring 2019
abstract: Alexachung 2019 Collection.
lead_paragraph: Alexachung 2019 Collection.

headline: Three Things About Her and Three About Him
abstract: A mutual friend thought the two might make a good couple, and so sent each a text with facts about the other.
lead_paragraph: Joanna Braun Levine and Yigit Bora Bozkurt were married Sept. 15 at Wave Hill in the Bronx. Gregg M. Rubin, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for this event, officiated, with Gloria Steinem, the writer and activist and a friend of the bride’s family, leading a ceremony that incorporated Jewish and Turkish wedding traditions.

headline: That Little Boy She Used to Read to Has Turned the Page
abstract: When they met, she was a seventh grader and he was a first grader. He had a crush from the beginning. It took her many more years.
lead_paragraph: Lila Lancaster Seiler Dupree and Daniel Lee Adair were married Sept. 15 at Wasgat Cove, the summer home of the bride’s family in Northeast Harbor, Me. James Buchanan, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Park Avenue Church Site Turned Condo
abstract: The 11-unit building replaces a church annex that housed a popular preschool, bringing condos to a predominantly co-op district.
lead_paragraph: An Upper East Side condo that displaced a popular Park Avenue preschool in 2013 and had to be scaled down to meet historic district requirements will finally start sales this month.

headline: New Kavanaugh Disclosure Shows Little Sign of Impeding His Nomination
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: Even opponents of Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh said they did not anticipate that a decades-old assault claim would move to the forefront unless the accuser agreed to cooperate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sudden new revelations in Supreme Court confirmation fights are not new. Anita Hill’s accusations of sexual harassment against Clarence Thomas surfaced after his initial hearings had concluded. Justice Neil M. Gorsuch, President Trump’s first nominee to the court, faced claims that he had plagiarized parts of his book just as his nomination headed toward a Senate floor vote.

headline: Rwanda Freeing Over 2,000 Prisoners, Including an Opposition Leader
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Politics and Government', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Hutu Tribe', 'Tutsi Tribe']
abstract: President Paul Kagame’s government ordered the release of Victoire Ingabire Umuhoza, leader of an opposition party, and Kizito Mihigo, a musician and activist.
lead_paragraph: A prominent opposition leader and a popular gospel musician, both imprisoned after angering the government of Rwanda, walked free on Saturday, after officials said that more than 2,000 inmates would be released.

headline: How to Help Those Affected by Florence
abstract: Residents of the Carolinas face the arduous task of cleaning up, repairing and rebuilding. Here’s how to help.
lead_paragraph: As the Carolinas grapple with devastating flooding from Florence, residents face the arduous task of cleaning up, repairing and rebuilding homes and businesses.

headline: Boris Johnson, Eyes on Downing Street, Sets Political Fires
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Muslim Veiling']
abstract: Since leaving Prime Minister Theresa May’s government, Mr. Johnson, who would like her job, has displayed his skill at causing uproars while seeming affable.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The setting was the annual dinner of the American Enterprise Institute, a tony affair on Thursday featuring 1,500 exuberant believers in free enterprise, limited government and the superiority of American values.

headline: Can a Felon Be the President of My Condo Board?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Condominiums', 'Boards of Directors']
abstract: Some states, like Florida, bar people who have been convicted of felonies from serving on association boards. But New York is not among them.
lead_paragraph: Q: A candidate for the president of the board of my Park Slope, Brooklyn, condo has a past felony conviction. I believe that some states do not allow people convicted of felonies to run for seats on condo boards. What are the rules in New York? Can this person legally run for a seat on the board?

headline: California Had Its Own Climate Summit. Now What?
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Hydrofluorocarbons', 'Methane']
abstract: There were plenty of announcements at a major climate conference in San Francisco, but not enough of what one researcher called the “exponential changes” still needed.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, presidents and prime ministers have been the public face of the fight against climate change, gathering at United Nations summit meetings and pressuring each other to reduce emissions.

headline: The Economy Is Humming, but Trump Is Tweeting. Republicans Are Worried.
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Political Action Committees']
abstract: The president and the healthy economy have become countervailing forces, with his self-inflicted wounds obscuring the Republican message, and buoying Democrats
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Democrats enter the fall midterm campaign with palpable confidence about reclaiming the House and perhaps even the Senate, tensions are rising between the White House and congressional Republicans over who is to blame for political difficulties facing the party, with President Trump’s advisers pointing to the high number of G.O.P. retirements and lawmakers placing the blame squarely on the president’s divisive style.

headline: Our 20 Favorite Salmon Recipes
abstract: Slow-roasted citrus salmon, salmon burgers and more.
lead_paragraph: There are few worse meals than bland, uninspired fish dinners. We’re here to say: “Let’s cook better.” Try Alison Roman’s cumin-roasted salmon with cilantro sauce (above), Mark Bittman’s four-spice salmon or Sam Sifton’s simple and flavorful pan-roasted salmon with jalapeño. Click the “20 Salmon Dinners” collection below for more.

headline: Female Athletes Face Crazy Expectations. They Can Be Overcome.
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'NCAA Track and Field Championships', 'Running', 'Women and Girls', 'Track and Field']
abstract: We still hear that to win or be worthy, we must be thin — and don’t dare bring up your period. But trying to fit this projected image has serious consequences.
lead_paragraph: When I met Melody Fairchild at Steens Mountain Running Camp in Oregon in 2006, I was a sub-elite runner in the throes of recovery from disordered eating, exercise bulimia and distorted body image. As a Division I student-athlete, I’d wrestled with what collegiate coaches, peers and, well, every magazine told me about thin and athlete-specific ideals. Plagued with injuries, I had osteopenia, the precursor to osteoporosis; amenorrhea, the absence of menstruation; and depression — all consequences of what’s now recognized as Relative Energy Deficiency in Sport, or RED-S, a condition that impairs physiological functioning.

headline: Typhoon Mangkhut: How to Help
abstract: Nonprofits have mobilized to help those affected by Typhoon Mangkhut, which pummeled the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Before advancing to strike China, Typhoon Mangkhut, a powerful storm 550 miles wide, pummeled the Philippines, leaving destruction in its path.

headline: An Ex-Owner of the Dodgers Takes Another Swing in Marseille
abstract: Frank McCourt’s ownership of the Los Angeles Dodgers is not remembered fondly, but he is hoping the lessons he took from that experience help with his new team, Olympique de Marseille.
lead_paragraph: MONACO — Not long after Frank McCourt arrived at his luxury hotel here, there was a knock at the door. A valet had returned with a newly pressed shirt. McCourt, freshening up after an overnight trans-Atlantic flight, called out from the bathroom with an instruction to hang the shirt in the closet.

headline: City Ballet Fires Two Male Dancers Named in Photo Sharing Scandal
abstract: Amar Ramasar, one of the company’s stars, and Zachary Catazaro were implicated in a lawsuit that has roiled the company.
lead_paragraph: New York City Ballet fired two principal male dancers on Saturday morning after they were named in  a lawsuit in which a woman accused a third dancer of inappropriately sharing texts of sexually explicit photographs.

headline: Molly Goddard: Spring 2019
abstract: Molly Goddard 2019 Collection
lead_paragraph: Molly Goddard 2019 Collection

headline: Torrents of Water in Towns Across the Carolinas. And a Guy With a Boat.
abstract: An improvised network of volunteers has sprung up to locate and rescue people who did not evacuate for Tropical Storm Florence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, N.C. — As the flat-bottomed fishing boat crept into a swirling river that had once been Summer Haven Lane, Tray Tillman scanned the brown floodwaters and half-submerged houses in search of somebody to save.

headline: Protesters Shut Afghan Election Offices as Political Crisis Brews
abstract: After five elections, Afghanistan still lacks a basic consensus over how to hold elections, with the latest logjam threatening the country’s stability.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Protesters demanding anti-fraud measures shut down the offices of Afghanistan’s election commission in three of the country’s major provinces on Saturday, just weeks before a vote for Parliament, the latest symptom of a political logjam that could turn violent amid a raging war with the Taliban.

headline: Typhoon Mangkhut Wreaks Havoc in Philippines, Leaving at Least 25 Dead
abstract: Amid the suffering, there was also relief that the storm’s damage was not much worse, at least according to the initial assessments.
lead_paragraph: CLAVERIA, Philippines — Typhoon Mangkhut, which meteorologists called the most powerful storm in the world this year, swept through the northern end of the Philippine island of Luzon, leaving at least 25 people dead and wreaking havoc. It uprooted trees, ripped off roofs, set off landslides and flooded farms and roads.

headline: Why Do Gullah Communities Choose to Ride Out Hurricanes?
abstract: In this week’s Race/Related newsletter, we discuss Hurricane Florence, a New York congressional candidate’s brief rap career, and more.
lead_paragraph: Please sign up here to have the Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Today’s acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon is particularly momentous.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC —  The rara avis Sammus major Ezerskyus says that today’s puzzle is the official 500th acrostic from team Cox Rathvon in the pages of The Times. We’ll presumably all be here in 19 years-and-a-bit to work on number 1,000, but 500 is legion. Five hundred home runs, as far as I’m concerned.

headline: Edwin Moses: WADA’s Credibility Rides on Its Russia Decision
abstract: The World Anti-Doping Agency seems likely to vote to let the country off the hook though it has not abided by the organization’s road map. That would be a mistake.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the World Anti-Doping Agency’s executive committee will gather in the Seychelles to hold the most crucial antidoping meeting in recent times.

headline: Ten Years Ago, Wall Street Collapsed. These Reporters Told the Story.
abstract: Journalists remember when Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy, which sent shock waves across the global financial system.
