headline: Is Technology Harming Teenagers?
abstract: Readers critique a psychiatrist’s essay debunking claims that technology is causing an epidemic of anxiety.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 2-Year-Old Boy With Deadly Cancer Gets an Early Christmas From His Neighbors
abstract: An Ohio boy isn’t expected to live until Christmas, so his neighbors decorated their homes, sent holiday cards and planned a parade with Santa for him.
lead_paragraph: Five weeks ago, Brody Allen’s parents were told that their 2-year-old son’s rare form of brain cancer meant he had two months to live.

headline: Piano Lessons in the Panopticon
abstract: I never made as much progress learning jazz as I did online. Was it the technology?
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — A few years ago, I began taking jazz piano lessons on the internet.

headline: 23andMe Said He Would Lose His Mind. Ancestry Said the Opposite. Which Was Right?
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Tests (Medical)', "Alzheimer's Disease", 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Consumer genetic tests aren’t error-proof.
lead_paragraph: In many ways, Matt Fender, a 32-year-old resident of New York City, is the prototypical 23andMe customer: tech-savvy, educated, a bit of a worrier. But he wasn’t worried last December when he clicked a button to dump all the raw data from his 23andMe genetic test into a DNA search engine called Promethease, which sorts through data for gene variants that have received a mention in the medical literature.

headline: Trump Finally Makes a Friend
abstract: The president may be shunned nearly everywhere but at the bottom of the world he has finally found a loyal mate.
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia — President Trump has admitted he feels “amazingly alone” in the midst of all his scraps with allies and snarls with undermining advisers.

headline: What America Looks Like From a Jail in South Texas
keywords: ['Immigration Detention', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: America’s immigration laws vs. America’s people.
lead_paragraph: Of all the ways I imagined the inevitable — being arrested, getting detained — I never envisioned sitting on the cold cement floor of a jail cell in South Texas surrounded by children.

headline: Money Talks. Will the G.O.P. Listen?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: Seth Klarman was once the biggest donor to the Republican Party in New England. This year he’s giving some $20 million to Democrats.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The first page of Seth Klarman’s most recent 25-page investor letter does not inspire confidence. There are quotes about truth and justice from George Orwell, Reinhold Niebuhr and Mark Twain. But the kicker is a line from Ramsay Bolton, a character from “Game of Thrones”: “If you think this has a happy ending, you haven’t been paying attention.”

headline: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie: The Carnage of the Cameroons
abstract: This is a story about an African nation’s fatal disregard of its minority population. It is also a story about the muddled sludge of colonial history.
lead_paragraph: When our friend Theo first met his Chinese wife, Libby, in Shandong Province, her parents, protective of their only daughter and wary of Africans, finally gave their blessing with the words, “at least he’s not a bad looking black.” Theo tells this story with wry amusement, as though he would parse it more if he were not already so burdened. He is a pleasant and gentle man, respectful, trustworthy, the kind of man who in West Africa would be said to have had “good home training.” But for the past year, a dark sighing heaviness has blanketed him.

headline: Conservatism After Christianity
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Voting and Voters', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A new survey reveals the Republican Party's religious divide.
lead_paragraph: One of the many paradoxes of the Trump era is that our unusual president couldn’t have been elected, and couldn’t survive politically today, without the support of religious conservatives … but at the same time his ascent was intimately connected to the secularization of conservatism, and his style gives us a taste of what to expect from a post-religious right.

headline: Democrats’ Top-Secret Formula for Victory
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Governors', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Stop obsessing over ideology. It's about personality.
lead_paragraph: In a Pennsylvania congressional district, Conor Lamb defies the odds to beat his Republican opponent in a bitterly fought special election and the message is clear: Democrats must hug the center. Dozens of strategists take careful note. A hundred news commentaries bloom.

headline: I Came of Age During the 2008 Financial Crisis. I’m Still Angry About It.
keywords: ['Millennial Generation', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Recession and Depression', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: The generation that graduated into the recession is not to blame.
lead_paragraph: I grew up in a suburb of Detroit, in a house near a dead end, which my parents bought in 1992. They paid for it with a conventional mortgage that they had the misfortune of refinancing in January 2008.

headline: Netflix Morning Meeting
abstract: The streaming service needs ideas for new shows. Lots and lots of shows.
lead_paragraph: Netflix plans to spend about $8 billion this year on original television. It also got the most Emmy Award nominations of any network in 2018, putting an end to HBO’s 17-year streak as nominations champ. While the stars attend the Emmy ceremony Monday night, the Original Programming team is preparing to shatter records for next year.

headline: U.S. Drops Charges Against Ex-Senegal Official in Chinese Energy Bribery Case
abstract: Prosecutors offered no explanation for dismissing the case. Cheikh Gadio was arrested 10 months ago along with a representative of CEFC China Energy.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have quietly dismissed charges against a former Senegalese government official who had been accused of conspiring with a representative of a large Chinese energy company in a bribery case.

lead_paragraph: Paul Manafort, President Trump’s former campaign chairman, is forfeiting an estimated $22 million worth of real estate in New York — including three Manhattan apartments, a Brooklyn townhouse and a home in the Hamptons — as part of a plea deal with federal prosecutors announced on Friday.

headline: Remembering Mac Miller, Low-Key Hip-Hop Bellwether
abstract: The 26-year-old rapper and producer stood at the crossroads of movements that have been shaping popular music over the past decade.
lead_paragraph: Mac Miller, who died last week at 26, was a rapper and producer who evolved quickly and frequently. Each of his albums — which all debuted in the Top 5 of the Billboard chart — was different from the one before. He began as a teenage hip-hop classicist and grew into an experimentally minded aesthete.

headline: ‘Uh, What?’
abstract: Joel Fagliano’s puzzle needs us all to speak up, please. Enunciate.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — It’s been eight months since the last Sunday puzzle by Joel Fagliano, which is about 245 minis, so we can’t blame him for the gap. His theme today reminded me of an old joke in which three people are waiting for a bus on a blustery day.

headline: Border Patrol Agent Arrested in Connection With Murders of 4 Women
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'internal-national collaboration']
abstract: Juan David Ortiz, a federal Customs and Border Protection supervisor, was arrested on Saturday after a woman who said she had escaped helped the authorities find him, officials said.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — A United States Border Patrol agent was arrested in South Texas on Saturday in connection to a calculated killing spree that left four people dead in recent weeks around the city of Laredo, the authorities said.

headline: Quotation of the Day: China in Path of Strong Typhoon That Killed at Least 25 in the Philippines
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 16, 2018.
lead_paragraph: “This was the strongest and the worst storm that I’ve ever experienced in my life. I was crying because I don’t know how I will be able to afford to fix my house.”

headline: ‘I’m Just Glad We’re Alive’: Gas Leak Leaves Thousands Displaced and Afraid
abstract: The chaotic aftermath of the still-unexplained gas leak gave rise Saturday to an unusual sight, displaced residents lugging their belongings in wagons and bags slung over their shoulders.
lead_paragraph: LAWRENCE, Mass. — Emmanuel Peguero, 7, thought he had been walking for 80 miles on Saturday. And how many days would it be before he could return to his own home? One thousand, he predicted.

headline: College Football Scores: Brigham Young Upsets No. 6 Wisconsin

headline: Typhoon Mangkhut: Storm Hits China as Philippines Searches for Dozens Buried in Slides
abstract: Remote areas of the Philippines reported dozens buried by mud, as the storm battered Hong Kong and then killed at least two others on the Chinese mainland.
lead_paragraph: As Typhoon Mangkhut moved past Hong Kong and struck southern China, the authorities in the Philippines said that landslides had buried dozens, including people sheltering in a church and a dormitory for miners. The death toll there was rising sharply as rescue workers began moving in.

headline: A Boy Named Chance in a Land Without Heart Surgeons
abstract: I went to Kigali in Rwanda to report on the type of heart disease afflicting Chance and millions of other young people. I was supposed to be a fly on the wall. Before I knew it, I was trying to help.

headline: J.K. Rowling’s Friend Robert Galbraith Has Something to Say
abstract: The author of the Cormoran Strike mystery series has a new book out this month, “Lethal White.”
lead_paragraph: “Lethal White,” the fourth volume in Robert Galbraith’s hugely popular Cormoran Strike mystery series, goes on sale Sept. 18. But who, exactly, is Robert Galbraith? The British author has never appeared at a bookstore event; you won’t find his photo on the books’ jackets. What little we know about Mr. Galbraith comes from his good friend J.K. Rowling, who has talked about him on Twitter — and from his own website, which details his military background. But until now, the reclusive author has been shy about granting interviews.

headline: Why the I.C.C. Should Rejoice When America Attacks It

headline: What Do We Actually Know About the Economy? (Wonkish)
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Recession and Depression', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: Macroeconomics is better than you think, microeconomics worse, and data are limited
lead_paragraph: In a couple of days I’m giving a luncheon talk to the New York chapter of the National Association of Business Economists, and the title of this essay was the title I provided for the talk. To be honest, it was a bit of a dummy title, and I wasn’t at all sure what I would actually say; but I’ve been spending some time trying to pin things down, and found myself wanting to put it together in a little essay. So here are some meta reflections on economic knowledge, inspired in part but not entirely by the financial crisis and its aftermath.

headline: Sweden to End Twitter Experiment Letting Ordinary People Be Nation’s Voice
abstract: For seven years, Sweden has given control of the @sweden Twitter account to a different person each week, yielding quirky, surprising and provocative results.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — It was a radical experiment in free speech, even for Sweden: Give ordinary and not-so-ordinary people the chance to be, more or less, the official voice of a nation. After seven years of Twitter posts on topics as varied as manga comics, ugly sweaters and the dangers of prescription drugs, Sweden is calling it quits.

He appears relatively early in Atkinson’s story: only one jump back in time after a brief 1981 sequence in which the heroine, Juliet Armstrong, is hit by a car. Let it be said — again — that the endlessly devious Atkinson (“Life After Life,” “Case Histories”) knows how to start a book with a bang.

headline: How an Unsolved Mystery Changed the Way We Take Pills
keywords: ['Tylenol (Drug)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Extortion and Blackmail', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Containers and Packaging']
abstract: The origins of tamper-resistant packaging — exasperating yet reassuring — lie in a deadly episode in 1982, when cyanide-laced Tylenol killed seven people.
lead_paragraph: Odds are that you have had moments of frustration trying to open new bottles of aspirin or other over-the-counter medications. Perhaps your fingernails are not up to the task of breaking the seal on the plastic wrap. Or maybe the pop-up cap is a challenge, seemingly designed to be not only childproof but also adultproof. The foil covering the lip of the bottle may defy neat tearing. Then you struggle to remove every wisp of the cotton wad standing between you and the medicine.

headline: Sam Darnold and Jets Fall Back to Earth in Loss to Dolphins
abstract: The rookie quarterback was intercepted twice, including once in the end zone, in the Jets’ home opener.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Even by Jets standards, it was a strange week. There was the blowout win in Detroit six days earlier. Then there was the chief executive, Christopher Johnson, declaring his team as “one to be reckoned with.” There was Edwin Anzalone, the famous fan known as Fireman Ed, relenting from his six-year boycott of home games and leading the “J-E-T-S” chant again after calling it quits in 2012. There was hope, promise, expectations, and other fluttery feelings that are rare guests at MetLife Stadium for a Jets home opener.

He at least said as much before Sunday’s game against the Toronto Blue Jays when asked if he believed his team’s offense relied too much on hitting home runs, the only category in which they lead Major League Baseball.

headline: Nature Roars. Washington Hears Nothing.
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Methane', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Hurricane Florence (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The elements offer a rebuke as President Trump rolls back policies designed to address global warming.
lead_paragraph: As if this past summer of merciless heat waves, droughts and megafires were not warning enough, in the past several days the elements sounded another alarm about the state of a world made warmer by the burning of fossil fuels. It came in the form of a one-two punch of wind and rainfall from Hurricane Florence, which like Hurricane Harvey a year ago, has derived much of its wallop from unusually warm ocean waters and stalled weather systems linked to climate change. “Supercharged” is the word one prominent climate scientist, Michael Mann, used to describe Florence, echoing the findings of the federal Global Change report in 2014 that, along with a rise in other extreme weather events, “hurricane intensity and rainfall are projected to increase as the climate continues to warm.”

headline: Myanmar’s Assault on a Truthful Press
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'Freedom of the Press', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: When Myanmar’s government defends the harsh sentence given to two courageous reporters who exposed mass murder, it breaks a fundamental promise of democracy: the rule of law based on facts.
lead_paragraph: In Myanmar, as everywhere, facts have power. It was the gruesome facts uncovered by two of our reporters for Reuters, Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo, that led to their being framed, arrested, tried and — this month — handed a draconian seven-year prison sentence. Last week, Myanmar’s civilian leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, resolutely ignored the facts and vigorously defended the unjust convictions. With the United Nations General Assembly gathering soon, it’s time to harness the facts to secure our reporters’ freedom.

headline: Mets Fall to Red Sox in a Battle of Two Aces With Different Goals
abstract: Chris Sale and Jacob deGrom took the mound in what could have been a tantalizing matchup. But Sale is coming off an injury, and deGrom’s Mets are far from the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — On Sept. 11, 1985, two standout pitchers, Dwight Gooden of the Mets and John Tudor of the St. Louis Cardinals, faced off at Shea Stadium in a matchup for the ages. Gooden fired nine scoreless innings; Tudor threw 10. The Cardinals won, 1-0, in the 10th inning when Cesar Cedeno smashed a home run off Jesse Orosco.

headline: Review: Listening to ‘Uncle Vanya’ With Virgin Ears
abstract: Richard Nelson’s emotionally transparent interpretation of a Chekhov masterwork, starring a brilliant Jay O. Sanders, makes us hear a classic anew.
lead_paragraph: When did you acquire this new set of ears? You’re watching a play you thought you knew better than you know your best friend, and yet suddenly it sounds different. It’s clearer, truer and more comprehensible than it’s ever been before, as if it had always been operating on a frequency that you’ve only now been given access to.

headline: ‘The Deuce’ Season 2, Episode 2 Recap: Sheet Rock and Cranes
abstract: Change is afoot up and down the Deuce. It just might not be the kind its various entrepreneurs envision.
lead_paragraph: So much of “The Deuce” is about the power characters hold over one another, depending on where they place in the hierarchy of exploitation. There are mobsters and corrupt cops on one end, prostitutes on the other end, and people like Vinnie and Candy somewhere between, exerting power and control where they can but beholden to men who can snuff out their ambitions — or possibly their lives.

Circuit, the nation’s second most-powerful court. Before that, he held top legal jobs in the federal government, including the White House Counsel’s Office, and was a partner at a leading law firm.

His death roiled this city, leading to upheaval in the police department, demonstrators in the streets and murder charges against the officer, Jason Van Dyke.

headline: The Risks to Children From Adults Who Smoke
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Children and Childhood', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Asthma', 'Babies and Infants', 'Lung Cancer', 'Parenting', 'Bronchitis']
abstract: Even if smokers don’t light up in the presence of children, residue on objects can cause harm.
lead_paragraph: Adults who wish to avoid exposure to secondhand smoke have options. Among my strategies: I don’t allow smoking in my home or car; I have no friends or close family members who smoke; I walk in front of smokers or cross the street to avoid them; I eat inside restaurants; and I hold my breath when passing smokers outside stores and office buildings.

headline: Can Paying for a Health Problem as a Whole, Not Piece by Piece, Save Medicare Money?
abstract: A program called bundled payments appears promising, but we need more rigorous evaluations.
lead_paragraph: Among the standard complaints about the American health care system is that care is expensive and wasteful. These two problems are related, and to address them, Medicare has new ways to pay for care.

headline: A Rwandan Game Park Defying the Odds
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Despite modest tourism numbers, Akagera National Park is a success story in the making, particularly considering that, like its host country, it survived catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: The road through Akagera National Park in eastern Rwanda was blocked. Two giraffes had positioned themselves smack in the middle of the dirt road and were rubbing their necks together. In the car, with a driver and a guide, my cell service was long gone; there was nothing to do but sit back, relax and enjoy the show.

headline: After the Battle: A Warning From Mosul
abstract: Organized combat in Iraq’s second city ended more than a year ago, but the city remains crippled by deadly munitions that still lie hidden beneath huge mounds of rubble.
lead_paragraph: MOSUL, Iraq — As the calamitous civil war next door in Syria grinds on toward a final battle in Idlib, with an unthinkably tragic end in sight, it’s worth taking a look farther east, at this shattered Iraqi city. Today, Mosul stands as a measure of how difficult “recovery” can be in this part of the world, even after the gunfire stops.

headline: New Approach to Breast Reconstruction May Reduce Pain and Weakness for Some
abstract: The technique places implants on top of muscle, instead of under it.
lead_paragraph: Before Deborah Cohan had a double mastectomy and breast reconstruction five years ago, her plastic surgeon explained that he would “create a little pocket” behind her chest muscle and “slip the implant in.”

headline: The Threat to Roe v. Wade in the Case of the Missing Precedent
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'ABORTION', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At his confirmation hearings this month, Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh singled out a 1992 Supreme Court decision, saying it was central to any discussion of the power of precedent. But at the Supreme Court itself, the decision has gone missing.

keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']

lead_paragraph: The amenities that have proliferated in luxury buildings don’t always get much traffic. When’s the last time anyone actually played one of those grand pianos or cooked dinner in a shared lounge?

headline: A Nobel Laureate Asks What Makes a ‘Disordered Mind’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Brain']
abstract: In his new book, the neuroscientist Eric Kandel explores the science of unusual brains, locating many of his answers in genetics.
lead_paragraph: THE DISORDERED MIND What Unusual Brains Tell Us About Ourselves By Eric R. Kandel 304 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $30.

headline: Reading the New South
abstract: A group of forward-thinking, upstart journals and websites are exploding the stereotypes so many attach to this place and its people.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — I was a graduate student in Philadelphia when James Watt, the former Secretary of the Interior of the United States, came to campus in 1984. Mr. Watt’s brief tenure in federal office was characterized by an almost cartoonish villainy. Rolling Stone magazine called his attitude toward the environment a “rip-and-ruin view of our natural resources, land, water, parks and wilderness.” That night Watt argued for letting each state set its own air- and water-safety standards, a position that makes no sense if you’re aware that rivers and winds don’t respect state borders.

headline: A Journey to Kashmir’s Gurez Valley
abstract: Ten years after his first visit, a writer revisits a remote, conflicted region, once a spur of the Silk Road, that is still new to tourism.
lead_paragraph: In 1895, the British author Sir Walter Lawrence called the Gurez Valley “one of the most beautiful scenes in all of Kashmir,” where the tourmaline waters of the Kishenganga River are framed by “mountain scarps of indescribable grandeur.” In the book he wrote after traveling throughout the princely state, Lawrence predicted that Gurez would soon become one of Kashmir’s most popular Himalayan tourist destinations. For reasons he never could have foreseen, 120 years later, Gurez is still waiting.

headline: Bloomberg May Run for President as a Democrat. Some of His Views May Cause Him Trouble.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Political Advertising', '#MeToo Movement', 'Search and Seizure', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Gun Control', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Michael Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York, acknowledged he has some differences with progressive Democrats, but said, “It’s impossible to conceive that I could run as a Republican.”

Bloomberg is actively considering a campaign for president as a Democrat in 2020, concluding that it would be his only path to the White House even as he voices stark disagreements with progressives on defining issues including bank regulation, stop-and-frisk police tactics and the #MeToo movement.

headline: Inside a Reimagined Shoreditch Loft
abstract: The London architects Zoe Chan Eayrs and Merlin Eayrs achieve an almost impossible feat in interior design: homes with genuine patina and soul.
lead_paragraph: The London architects Zoe Chan Eayrs and Merlin Eayrs achieve an almost impossible feat in interior design: homes with genuine patina and soul.

headline: The Architects Who Live Wherever They Work
abstract: Zoe Chan Eayrs and Merlin Eayrs inhabit spaces as they renovate them, infusing each room with history and humanity.
lead_paragraph: IN OUR INSTA AGE, the life cycle of a design trend has never been shorter: An idea that seemed so fresh one day feels dead the next, gone the way of so many millennial pink sofas and Beni Ourain rugs. How, then, does one create a real home, built to endure the whims of fashion? And how do designers, dependent on cultivating a certain recognizable vernacular for clients, manage to create an identity without becoming their own cliché?

headline: In Marrakesh, One Designer’s Adobe House Is as Colorful as Her Ceramics
keywords: ['Art', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Carpets and Rugs', 'Ceramics and Pottery', 'Design', 'Textiles']
abstract: The Belgian transplant Laurence Leenaert makes her home just like she makes her crafts: by instinct.
lead_paragraph: Most days, the 28-year-old Belgian designer Laurence Leenaert can be found in her sunny studio in Sidi Ghanem, an industrial area of northwest Marrakesh where many of the city’s artisans produce their painted ceramics or leather goods. It is here that Leenaert, with the help of several assistants, creates her own versions of these products for her line, Lrnce, which also includes textiles, mirrors and clothing — all in her distinctive patterns and colors that reference Picasso’s ceramics, Miró’s line drawings and Moroccan tribal patterns. Her pitchers and vessels — creamy white except for the vibrant shapes, wobbly lines and asymmetrical faces painted onto them — were featured at the Conran Shop during London Craft Week in May and are also found at Le Bon Marché in Paris, Mociun in Brooklyn and at her studio showroom.

headline: These Gay Figure Artists Are Reimagining the Male Gaze
abstract: Working largely outside the gallery system, a group of illustrators is reviving the discipline and redefining how queer bodies are represented in art.
lead_paragraph: LAST FALL, IN a tiny apartment in downtown New York, a 30-year-old gay physique model named Matthew Williams stood naked against a white backdrop in front of the gay artist John MacConnell. “It’s liberating to be able to be comfortable in your body,” Williams said, barely moving his lips as he concentrated on holding still. The 33-year-old MacConnell — boyish, equally fit — wore black jeans and a white T-shirt as he sketched on a letter-size sheet of paper with his blue ballpoint pen. “It’s important for me to capture likeness and not just a body,” he said.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: Alison Roman has a superb, and supremely riffable, recipe for a brothy seafood pasta.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Holy crow did our Alison Roman deliver a good new recipe this week: a tomato-rich weeknight fish pasta (above) that you can riff on forever, or at least until you come down on a favorite combination of fish. She calls for firm, white-fleshed fillets, along with shrimp, mussels or clams. I’d try squid and scallops, on top of flounder, and omit the shrimp. You’ll make it however you make it — ling cod and spot prawns would be great, if you’re in the California market — but attend to her volumes of garlic and olives. Those are big players in this game.

headline: Floods in Nigeria Kill More Than 100, Wiping Out Homes and Farms
abstract: Even for a region where the rainy season often brings deadly flooding, the toll is high, with a growing population and runaway development worsening the problem.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Rainy season flooding across Nigeria has killed more than 100 people, as water poured over the banks of the West African country’s two major rivers, and into numerous cities and towns.

headline: “Strict Liability” for Facebook Content?
abstract: Richard Allan, Facebook vice president of public policy solutions, argues that the company should not be legally liable for all content published on its platform.
lead_paragraph: Richard Allan, Facebook vice president of public policy solutions, argues that the company should not be legally liable for all content published on its platform.

headline: British MP on Facebook’s Breach of Trust
abstract: “It’s not good enough for us to get things piecemeal when Facebook feels like telling us,” says Damian Collins, British member of Parliament and chairman of the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee.
lead_paragraph: “It’s not good enough for us to get things piecemeal when Facebook feels like telling us,” says Damian Collins, British member of Parliament and chairman of the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee.

headline: Christopher Kane: Spring 2019
abstract: Christopher Kane 2019 Collection.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Kane 2019 Collection.

headline: Trump Is Making America Great Again
abstract: Just not the way he thinks.
lead_paragraph: In the video above, I argue that Donald Trump is in fact making America great again — by driving us to engage in our democracy as few presidents have. The shock of his election and his chaotic governance has mobilized progressives to run for office — women in record numbers — and to march for causes like women’s rights and gun control.

headline: Bugs, Weeds, Gophers: A Trump-TV Antithesis Tackles Real Problems
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: “Montana Ag Live” offers taxpayers a speck of reassurance that a republic administered by a fair, competent and good-humored bureaucracy might still exist.
lead_paragraph: BOZEMAN, Mont. — The Sunday morning after Senator John McCain died, the “Meet the Press” credits rolled over a photo of the deceased sitting next to former Senator John Kerry. Mr. McCain, the Republican P.O.W., famously joined forces with Mr. Kerry, the Democrat and onetime spokesman for Vietnam Veterans Against the War, to help President Bill Clinton normalize relations with Vietnam. The photo made me wonder if we’re running out of government officials who might help quibbling Americans normalize relations with one another.

headline: Midterm Election Poll: California’s 25th District, Knight vs. Hill
abstract: This district, just north of Los Angeles, is one of the Democrats’ biggest targets. Hillary Clinton won here in 2016, but it has been represented by a Republican since 1993. The district is now about 40 percent Hispanic, and registered Democrats outnumber Republicans.
lead_paragraph: This district, just north of Los Angeles, is one of the Democrats’ biggest targets. Hillary Clinton won here in 2016, but it has been represented by a Republican since 1993. The district is now about 40 percent Hispanic, and registered Democrats outnumber Republicans.

headline: Review: Chutzpah? An Afro-Cuban-Yiddish Opera Worth a Schlep
abstract: “Hatuey: Memory of Fire,” through Sunday at Montclair State University, tells the story of a 16th-century uprising in a 1930s Havana nightclub.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — I won’t lie: I had to suspend disbelief while watching a crucial moment in Frank London’s new opera “Hatuey: Memory of Fire” on Sunday. On stage, a conquistador priest brandished a crucifix as he urged an indigenous rebel to embrace Jesus. In Yiddish. Tied to the stake, the defiant Taino chief told the priest that if heaven had whites in it, he would rather go to hell.

headline: New Trailer: ‘Mary Poppins Returns,’ With Emily Blunt
abstract: Ms. Blunt plays the titular nanny, who brings more than just a spoonful of nostalgia with her.
lead_paragraph: “Nothing’s gone forever,” Emily Blunt sings in the new trailer for “Mary Poppins Returns.” Indeed, the sequel seems poised to capture the supercalifragilisticexpialidocious magic of the original, as it features brightly colored old-fashioned animation mixed with upbeat live-action musical numbers.

headline: An Avalanche of Japanese Shave Ice
abstract: Pastry chefs in the United States are exploring the countless possibilities of kakigori, a traditional dessert that’s both exacting and amenable to interpretation.
lead_paragraph: Before Norie Uematsu became a pastry chef, she waited all year for shave-ice season at home in Japan. Now, she decides when that season begins and ends.

headline: Reversing Course, Chris Collins Will Seek 4th House Term Despite Indictment
abstract: Mr. Collins, a Republican, had said he would not seek re-election, but removing oneself from the ballot in New York is no easy task.
lead_paragraph: Representative Chris Collins, the New York Republican indicted on insider trading charges last month, reversed course on Monday and announced he would seek another term.

headline: Tequila Picks Up Mezcal’s Smoky Habit
abstract: A new Patrón tequila uses older, traditional methods to imbue the spirit with a distinctive smokiness.
lead_paragraph: Mezcal appears to be teaching tequila a thing or two. For years, especially at the higher end, tequilas were becoming so refined that the spirit’s typical vegetal characteristics were sanded off. Then came the increasing interest in mezcal, with its more rustic, aggressive profile. Now distillers are starting to produce tequila with enhanced aroma and flavor using older production methods. Patrón Tequila’s new limited edition Gran Smoky is a good example, made by roasting Weber blue agave hearts or “piñas” over mesquite in stone pits and crushing them with stone tools. The spirit is clear, with a pleasing viscosity, a bell pepper aroma, and notes of citrus and spice on the palate.

headline: Shan Tianfang, a Superstar of Chinese Storytelling, Dies at 83
abstract: When Mr. Shan first brought his storytelling to radio in 1980, an estimated 100 million people tuned in.
lead_paragraph: Shan Tianfang, a storyteller whose energetic oral renditions of classical Chinese novels and historical events propelled the ancient pingshu tradition into the modern age for generations of Chinese, died on Sept. 11 in Beijing. He was 83.

headline: Miss Hatch Chile Season? You Have a Second Chance
abstract: Kalustyan’s in Murray Hill will roast fresh chiles and sell them by the pound for one day only.
lead_paragraph: Fresh seasonal green chiles from Hatch, N.M., are now available at Kalustyan’s market. On Saturday afternoon, the shop will be roasting chiles for the first time in a steel drum on the sidewalk in front of the store. Nathaniel Cotanch from Zia Green Chile Company will be in charge of roasting. The freshly seared pods are put in bags to make it easier to remove the skins, and sold by the pound.

headline: Charges of Racism Hobble a Soccer Revival in Germany
abstract: An embarrassing World Cup. Accusations of discrimination from a star player. German soccer tries to heal through its Euro 2024 campaign.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — For Reinhard Grindel, the leader of Germany’s soccer federation, this has become an awkward moment to promote his country’s campaign to stage European Championship in 2024, or, really, anything having to do with a national team program that only months ago was considered a symbol of unity for the country and one of the most unstoppable forces in sports.

headline: Coffee, Their Way
abstract: Felix Roasting Co. on Park Avenue South makes coffee from scratch, mostly.
lead_paragraph: The new Felix Roasting Co. coffee bar and cafe makes a strong visual statement, with custom wallpapers, intricate stone flooring and architectural details like an oval copper dome over the central bar. Ken Fulk, who also worked on the new Legacy Records restaurant, designed the space, and he has become a partner in this venture. Matt Moinian, a hotelier who is the managing partner and owner, became a coffee buff several years ago. Reagan Petrehn, 24, is the shop’s barista and resident coffee expert. The Felix team gets its green coffee beans from around the world, and has them roasted for classic drinks as well as some elaborate concoctions like hickory-smoked s’mores latte. Much of what is served, including the alternative milks, are made from scratch in the kitchen downstairs. “We don’t buy things,” Mr. Petrehn said. Except for the sweet and savory pastries that come from Supermoon Bakehouse on the Lower East Side.

headline: A Bit of Brooklyn History in Your Pocket
abstract: A new guidebook to the borough’s mom-and-pop food businesses is a trip down memory lane.
lead_paragraph: “Brooklyn Mom & Pop,” a smart little guide to Brooklyn, is a trip down memory lane, though the 99 throwbacks, all in business at least 30 years, are still very much alive. Vintage doughnut shops, pork stores, pizzerias, neighborhood Chinese restaurants, cocktail lounges and ice cream parlors are listed according to neighborhood. You probably know of Di Fara’s and Peter Luger, but what about Rzeszowska Polish bakery in Greenpoint, which sells paczki, the jelly-filled doughnuts?

headline: At the Close of Karl Ove Knausgaard’s ‘My Struggle,’ a Magician Loses His Touch
abstract: Vital writing and interesting ideas are buried in this endurance test of a novel, which includes a 400-page section about Hitler in addition to Knausgaard’s usual autobiographical musings.
lead_paragraph: The most elite of the world’s white, male, under-60 novelists sometimes seem to ride together as if in a peloton, as if they were competitors in the Tour de France, coasting in and out of each other’s slipstreams. When one breaks from the pack while up in the mountains — witness Jonathan Franzen or the Norwegian Karl Ove Knausgaard — a target surfaces on his jersey.

headline: Paul McCartney Tops Eminem for His First No. 1 Album in Over 3 Decades
abstract: “Egypt Station,” the new solo album from the former Beatle, tops the Billboard chart this week.
lead_paragraph: Before this week, Paul McCartney, a Billboard behemoth with the Beatles, had not achieved a No. 1 album of his own in 36 years. To do it this time, he had to take on Eminem.

headline: Master the Art of Shucking Oysters
abstract: At Greenpoint Fish & Lobster Company in Long Island City, Queens, wannabe shuckers can learn from the professionals.
lead_paragraph: Properly opening oysters takes skill. Learn the technique, safely practice it and slurp the results at Greenpoint Fish & Lobster Company’s location in Long Island City, Queens. They’re holding one-off classes on Fridays from 8 to 10 p.m. through Nov. 9 (except for Oct. 19). Wine, beer and snacks are served, and there will be oyster facts to digest. Participants can also buy oyster knives, gloves and oysters to take home.

headline: A Trove of Lincoln Artifacts Heads to Auction
abstract: The scholar Harold Holzer has spent his life collecting more than 700 paintings and other material related to the 16th president.
lead_paragraph: Harold Holzer has devoted much of his life to a guy who died more than 80 years before he was born. More specifically, he has spent much of his time fixating on this man’s face — his face in paintings, in photographs, sculpted out of plaster.

headline: Lapses in Turning the Lights On
abstract: When you flip the switch, there seems to be a wait before the bulb glows brightly.
lead_paragraph: A. Chances are that a household now has a mixture of bulb types — incandescent, compact fluorescent (CFL) and light-emitting diode (LED) bulbs — and each has a different start-up process.

headline: Review: Tom Arnold’s ‘Trump Tapes’ Blows Smoke With No Smoking Gun
abstract: In his new Viceland show, Tom Arnold is the latest media star to tease the existence of One Tape To Rule Them All.
lead_paragraph: The most obvious question raised by the title of Tom Arnold’s “The Hunt for the Trump Tapes” is: which (alleged) ones? Outtakes from “The Apprentice”? Recordings from the Miss Universe pageant? Surveillance footage captured in a Moscow hotel room, or in Trump Tower, or God knows where else?

headline: Emilia Wickstead: Spring 2019
abstract: Emilia Wickstead 2019 Collection
lead_paragraph: Emilia Wickstead 2019 Collection

headline: Egg Pastas With More Oomph
abstract: Al Dente Pasta has added spinach and turmeric flavors in fun shapes to its lineup.
lead_paragraph: Though Al Dente Pasta is factory-made, it delivers the characteristics of fresh homemade egg pasta. That’s because the founder, Monique Deschaine, trained with Marcella Hazan, and Ms. Deschaine’s pasta dough is rolled in small batches. The company, based in Whitmore Lake, Mich., has just added are several concise and colorful shapes to its inventory. Called Piccolo, the pastas come in spinach farfalletti, trendy turmeric pinchetti and golden egg bonnetti, and they cook in just a few minutes.

headline: Hillary Clinton Condemns Trump in New Essay: ‘Our Democracy Is in Crisis’
abstract: In a blistering critique published by The Atlantic, Mrs. Clinton accused President Trump of ignoring the law, dividing the country and serving himself above all.
lead_paragraph: With the midterms fast approaching, Hillary Clinton has written a scathing critique of President Trump that accused him of disregarding the law and weakening the social fabric of the country, imploring voters to “do everything we can to fight back” and “mobilize massive turnout” in November.

headline: Saltmarsh Sparrows Fight to Keep Their Heads Above Water
abstract: Rising sea levels are bringing more nest-flooding tides that threaten to push the birds that breed in coastal marshes along the Atlantic Coast to extinction.
lead_paragraph: HAMMONASSET BEACH STATE PARK, Conn. — The newly hatched saltmarsh sparrows are helpless, all but featherless, with reddish skin, barely visible in the evening light.

headline: Big Jay McNeely, 91, Dies; R&B’s ‘King of the Honkers’
abstract: At the dawn of rock ’n’ roll, he put the saxophone front and center, sometimes while lying on his back, kicking his legs, or jumping off the stage.
lead_paragraph: Big Jay McNeely, whose wailing tenor saxophone and outrageous stage antics helped define the sound and sensibility of early rock ’n’ roll, died on Sunday in Moreno Valley, Calif. He was 91.

headline: Midterm Election Poll: New Jersey’s 7th District, Lance vs. Malinowski
abstract: The district includes all of Hunterdon County and parts of five other counties in northwestern New Jersey. Mr. Lance, a moderate, won re-election in this district by 11 points in 2016 even as it swung toward a narrow victory for Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: The district includes all of Hunterdon County and parts of five other counties in northwestern New Jersey. Mr. Lance, a moderate, won re-election in this district by 11 points in 2016 even as it swung toward a narrow victory for Hillary Clinton.

headline: Brock Long’s Woes Mount as House G.O.P. Launches Travel Inquiry
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Hurricane Florence (2018)']
abstract: Representative Trey Gowdy, the chairman of the House Oversight Committee, said Monday he will investigate the potential misuse of government vehicles by FEMA’s chief.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans will investigate reports that Brock Long, the administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, repeatedly misused government vehicles to commute from Washington to North Carolina, where his family resides.

headline: Is the Shofar … an Instrument of Technological Disruption?
abstract: Mark Zuckerberg performed for his followers on Facebook while Marc Benioff of Salesforce (and now Time) led a live congregation in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Sure, it’s been around since biblical times, but suddenly the shofar is trending among Bay Area billionaires.

headline: Russia and Turkey Announce Demilitarized Zone in Last Rebel-Held Part of Syria
abstract: The announcement by Russia and Turkey about Idlib Province appeared to forestall what had been widely feared as a brutal offensive by Syrian forces.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s defense minister said on Monday that Syria would refrain from launching an offensive on Idlib Province, the last major rebel stronghold, after the presidents of Russia and Turkey agreed to establish a “demilitarized zone” there to avert a potentially catastrophic military confrontation.

headline: After the Storm: Photos From Hong Kong, Battered by Typhoon Mangkhut
abstract: While Hong Kong is well-prepared for major storms, the intensity of this typhoon, the most intense to hit the city since 1946, took many by surprise and caused significant damage.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong is a city well prepared for typhoons, with a detailed warning system that alerts residents to the severity of any approaching storm so that they know how — and how quickly — to respond.

headline: How an Expert Broker Makes Home Hunting Easy
abstract: For young couples, buying a home is challenging. But when Mike and Meredith met Aroza, a real estate agent with Sotheby’s International Realty, they learned that with the right help, it doesn’t have to be.
lead_paragraph: For young couples, buying a home is challenging. But when Mike and Meredith met Aroza, a real estate agent with Sotheby’s International Realty, they learned that with the right help, it doesn’t have to be.

headline: Sonia Sotomayor’s Book Tour Is a Hit With Hispanic Kids: ‘I Like How She Stood Up for Herself’
keywords: ['Puerto Ricans', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Books and Literature', 'Women and Girls', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: The Supreme Court justice has two new children’s books adapted from her memoir. She recently spoke in Brooklyn to an appreciative crowd with many Hispanic and Latino families.
lead_paragraph: As Justice Sonia Sotomayor spoke at the Brooklyn Public Library about her life and the story behind her two new children’s books, she told the audience of about 500 people about an instance when a man had questioned her choice of footwear.

headline: Review: Cults, Demons and Nicolas Cage in ‘Mandy’
abstract: Mr. Cage uses his outsize performing chops to excellent effect in this idiosyncratic revenge fantasy.
lead_paragraph: “Mandy” opens with a God’s-eye view of a dense, dark forest; on the soundtrack, you hear the stately prog-rock of King Crimson’s “Starless.” I had goose bumps immediately. It wasn’t just the combination of aesthetically apposite sounds and images, but a personal association — that music has moved me for many decades.

headline: The Quest to Create and Perfect an Artificial Heart
abstract: Mimi Swartz’s “Ticker” tells the story of the doctors who, against all odds, struggled to make a device to replace one of our most vital organs.
lead_paragraph: TICKER The Quest to Create an Artificial Heart By Mimi Swartz Illustrated. 317 pp. Crown. $27.

headline: The U.S. Can’t Punish the Palestinians Into Negotiating
abstract: Diplomacy as coercion goes against everything American foreign policy stands for.
lead_paragraph: Are President Trump’s advisers checking his worst impulses? From trade to NATO, we’ve been assured that the “adults” in the White House are working quietly to prevent the president from following through on his often erratic foreign policy proclamations.

headline: Termites Are Actually Shrunken Cockroaches and Other Things About Them You Really Don’t Want to Know
abstract: In Lisa Margonelli’s “Underbug,” she focuses on the extraordinary capabilities of the termite and what the insect can teach us about ourselves.
lead_paragraph: UNDERBUG An Obsessive Tale of Termites and Technology By Lisa Margonelli 303 pp. Scientific American/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $27.

headline: The Assault Accusation Against Kavanaugh
abstract: The accusation has readers debating whether adults should be held accountable for possible youthful transgressions and drunken behavior.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Alan Abel, Hoaxer Extraordinaire, Is (on Good Authority) Dead at 94
abstract: A professional trickster, Mr. Abel gleefully hoodwinked the American public time and again, even convincing The Times in 1980 that he had died.
lead_paragraph: Alan Abel, a professional hoaxer who for more than half a century gleefully hoodwinked the American public — not least of all by making himself the subject of an earnest news obituary in The New York Times in 1980 — apparently actually did die, on Friday, at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 94.

headline: If You See Disinformation Ahead of the Midterms, We Want to Hear From You
abstract: The Times is looking for examples of online ads, posts and texts that contain false claims and are being deliberately spread. Here's how to send a tip.
lead_paragraph: As November’s midterm elections approach, The New York Times is looking for examples of online ads, posts and texts that contain political disinformation or false claims and are being deliberately spread on internet platforms to try to influence local, statewide, and federal elections.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Campaign Marked a Fund-Raising Letter an Official ‘Summons.’ It Wasn’t Against the Rules.
abstract: The Texas senator’s re-election campaign sent voters in at least three counties a letter with a label suggesting it was a legal summons. The Federal Election Commission says doing so doesn’t break any rules.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz’s Senate re-election campaign has been sending voters in Texas a fund-raising letter in an envelope labeled “summons enclosed,” drawing criticism from some who called it misleading and raising questions about whether such a practice was legal. It is.

headline: Chicago Prosecutors Paint Officer as Reckless in the Shooting of Laquan McDonald
abstract: Officer Jason Van Dyke, who fatally shot the 17-year-old in 2014, is on trial for murder. Jurors heard opening statements in the case Monday morning.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — On the night he shot and killed Laquan McDonald in Chicago, Officer Jason Van Dyke saw only a “black boy walking down the street” who had the “audacity to ignore the police,” prosecutors told jurors Monday as testimony began in one of the most closely watched murder trials in the city’s history.

headline: Poland’s Leader Finds an Ally in Trump, Even as He Brings Courts to Heel
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'United States International Relations', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The judicial overhaul has inspired protests and the threat of European Union sanctions. But American officials have largely remained silent.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — When President Trump visited Warsaw in the summer of 2017, the Polish government was busy setting up a transformation of the nation’s judicial system in ways that critics found deeply troubling and undemocratic.

headline: Jules Feiffer Completes His Trilogy: A Song of American Deceptions
abstract: A look at “The Ghost Script,” the last of Feiffer’s trio of noir graphic novels, alongside Hartley Lin’s charming “Young Frances.”
lead_paragraph: The finale of Jules Feiffer’s “Kill My Mother” trilogy, THE GHOST SCRIPT (Liveright, $26.95), plunges into the world of 1950s Hollywood and its infamous blacklist. Feiffer luxuriates in the ironies, as when an ostensibly banished female screenwriter goes undercover and looks for work: Behind facial hair and pseudonym, her bespectacled face like a Feiffer self-portrait, she bites back laughter when a producer unwittingly offers rewrite duties on a script that she originally wrote.

headline: Burberry M/W: Spring 2019
abstract: Burberry M/W 2019 Collection
lead_paragraph: Burberry M/W 2019 Collection

headline: What 13,000 Patents Involving the DNA of Sea Life Tell Us About the Future
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Biotechnology and Bioengineering', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Innovation', 'Research', 'Law of the Sea (UN Convention)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: Whether a single private entity should be able to set the direction of how the genes of so many living things are used was a piece of a broader debate at the United Nations this month.
lead_paragraph: This is a California brown sea hare. It has some of the biggest brain cells in the animal kingdom.

headline: First Fatal Citi Bike Crash: Was the Bus Driver to Blame?
abstract: A 36-year-old was struck and killed while commuting in 2017. The driver is now on trial in Manhattan, where biking is growing in popularity.
lead_paragraph: The driver of a 50,000-pound bus traveling on a Manhattan street narrowed by parked cars honked at a cyclist pedaling ahead on a Citi Bike. But instead of slowing down, the prosecutor said, the driver squeezed the bus past him.

headline: Terry Crews Shares ‘Apology’ Letter From Executive Who Resigned in His #MeToo Case
abstract: Mr. Crews said that the Hollywood executive, Adam Venit, had groped him at a party. A civil settlement was reached this month.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year ago, as countless women began revealing stories of sexual harassment and assault in Hollywood, the actor Terry Crews became a rare male voice in their midst, when he said he, too, had been a target.

headline: Emmys 2018: ‘Game of Thrones’ and ‘Marvelous Mrs. Maisel’ Win Big Awards
abstract: It’s a tie: HBO and Netflix won 23 Emmys each. And it was a big night for Amazon’s “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel,” which took five more awards.
lead_paragraph: • “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel” won five awards on Monday night, including best comedy series, and “Game of Thrones” picked up the award for best drama.

headline: Your Tuesday News Briefing: South Korea, Taiwan, the Emmys
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Shorting Cannabis Stocks Is Getting Costly
abstract: Investors betting against the stocks of marijuana companies have lost $626 million since the start of August.
lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline: Meet SpaceX’s First Moon Voyage Customer, Yusaku Maezawa
keywords: ['Private Spaceflight', 'Moon', 'Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'Space and Astronomy']
abstract: Yusaku Maezawa, a Japanese fashion entrepreneur, and several artists would follow a looping path around the moon aboard a new rocket. When the flight might occur is uncertain.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk on Monday evening introduced Yusaku Maezawa, founder of the online Japanese clothing company Zozo, as his first customer for a voyage around the moon aboard a SpaceX rocket.

headline: When Being Separated From Your Luggage Is a Good Thing
keywords: ['Luggage and Packing', 'AIRPORTS', 'Airport Security', 'Customer Relations', 'Travel and Vacations', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Remote baggage check, offered by airlines and private services, appeals to frequent fliers. “To remove the bag from the journey is to change the journey,” the head of one service said.
lead_paragraph: The days of dragging suitcases to and through the airport may be numbered.

headline: Merger of Cigna and Express Scripts Gets Approval From Justice Dept.
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: The takeover of one of the nation’s largest pharmacy benefit manager by a big health insurer is expected to close by the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials on Monday gave the go-ahead to the proposed merger between Cigna, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, and Express Scripts, a major pharmacy benefit manager.

headline: Before Heading Back to Football, Urban Meyer Has His Say
abstract: Back from suspension, the Ohio State football coach is at turns defiant and remorseful.
lead_paragraph: Ohio State’s football coach, Urban Meyer, returned from a three-game suspension with a splash on Monday, insisting that he did not lie about when he learned of a domestic assault allegation against a former assistant coach and that he has always had zero tolerance for violence against women.

headline: Chaos at the World Equestrian Games
abstract: The disruption caused by Hurricane Florence couldn’t be avoided, but several other problems seem to be self-inflicted.
lead_paragraph: For Tryon, in western North Carolina, the arrival of the quadrennial World Equestrian Games this month was a chance to host the type of big international event that seldom comes to small Southern towns. Organizers promised half a million spectators and $400 million in economic impact.

headline: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and the Politics of a $3,000 Suit
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: The Democratic star was criticized for appearing in a magazine spread looking like a member of the 1 percent. Was it hypocrisy or a savvy move?
lead_paragraph: Recently, Interview magazine published a conversation between the actress Kerry Washington and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez accompanied by photographs of the young politician wearing a fitted blazer with wide lapels and green piping; a slim, matching set of trousers; and an elegant pair of black stilettos from Manolo Blahnik, the total cost for which was somewhere around $3,500.

headline: Elon Musk Sued by Cave Rescuer He Accused of Being a Pedophile
keywords: ['Libel and Slander', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Caves and Caverns', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Mr. Musk and the caver butted heads this summer about the high-profile rescue of a group of children trapped in a cave in Thailand.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the brash Silicon Valley billionaire, was sued on Monday by a British cave explorer he had accused of being a pedophile after the two butted heads over the high-profile rescue of children from a cave in Thailand this summer.

headline: Mueller and Defense Lawyers Ask for Flynn Sentencing to Be Scheduled
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: The request signals that Mr. Flynn’s cooperation with prosecutors for the special counsel has been exhausted.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The special counsel and defense lawyers asked a federal judge on Monday to schedule sentencing this fall for President Trump’s former national security adviser, Michael T. Flynn, a signal that his cooperation with prosecutors has been exhausted.

headline: Bill Cosby’s Wife Asks Panel to Investigate Trial Judge
abstract: Camille Cosby told the Pennsylvania Judicial Conduct Board in a letter that she views the judge who presided over her husband’s trial to be unethical.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Bill Cosby’s wife on Monday stepped up her campaign against the judge who presided over her husband’s criminal trial, asking a state board to investigate the judge because he failed to disclose a feud with a former district attorney who was a key witness in the case.

headline: Toronto Symphony Taps Gustavo Gimeno as Its Music Director
abstract: Mr. Gimeno, a former percussionist whose international conducting career has taken off in the last few years, will take the post in Toronto in 2020.
lead_paragraph: It was only in February that the fast-rising Spanish conductor Gustavo Gimeno made his debut with the Toronto Symphony Orchestra, but they seem to have hit it off: The orchestra announced on Monday that he would become its next music director.

headline: Three Things to Watch This Week
abstract: A doc, a drama and a baby animal show.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday, the Times TV critic Margaret Lyons picks the best of what’s ahead before the weekend. Check back each week for more recommendations.

headline: Burberry’s 50 Shades of the British Bourgeoisie
abstract: In his debut for the house, Riccardo Tisci played with the brand’s codes and played it safe at the same time
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a cavernous former Royal Mail warehouse south of the Thames, where luxury developments were built in anticipation of an influx of foreign money that never materialized, and after a long buildup of teasers — a new, Pop-tastic Peter Saville logo; a $390 limited drop T-shirt; Beyoncé in bespoke wear at her recent concert in Houston — Riccardo Tisci, the chief creative officer of Burberry, finally unveiled his first collection for the brand. There was not a single celebrity in the audience.

headline: Retire? These Graying ‘Encore Entrepreneurs’ Are Just Starting Up
abstract: More people in their 50s and 60s are starting their own businesses, redefining a start-up culture often ruled by the young.

It was 2013 and it took six months — and hundreds of résumés — to land another position as a manager of publications and marketing for the American Civil Liberties Union. A year later, he was laid off again.

headline: John Pritchard III, Tenacious Law Enforcement Leader, Dies at 75
abstract: Rising from beat cop to high-ranking posts in New York, he had a hand in investigations of the mob, Abscam, corruption scandals and a child-killer case.
lead_paragraph: John S. Pritchard III, a tenacious investigator whose law enforcement career spanned more than three decades and six agencies in New York, involving some of the most notorious crimes of that era, died on Thursday in Port St. Lucie, Fla. He was 75.

headline: Before and After Florence: See the Impact of the Storm

headline: Boys Will Be Supreme Court Justices
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Lying']
abstract: Kavanaugh’s accuser is credible. Will it matter?
lead_paragraph: Obviously, I believe Christine Blasey Ford, the psychology professor who says that Brett Kavanaugh sexually assaulted her in high school while his friend Mark Judge watched and, at moments, egged him on. I believe her when she says that Kavanaugh, who she says was drunk, held her down, covered her mouth when she tried to scream, and ground against her while attempting to pull her clothes off. I believe her when she says this incident haunted her all her life.

abstract: For 43 of the last 63 years, someone named Daley has run Chicago. With Mayor Emanuel gone, could another Daley take his place?

headline: A San Francisco Tech Mogul Buys a Fabled Slice of New York Media

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Marc Benioff is like the Salesforce Tower: He looms over this city.

headline: Jodie Whittaker Brings ‘Doctor Who’ Its Biggest Change in 55 Years
abstract: Ms. Whittaker is the first woman in the history of this BBC sci-fi series to play the Doctor, ushering in a new era of inclusivity at the show.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — When Jodie Whittaker got the news some months ago that she had been cast as the protagonist of “Doctor Who,” the long-running BBC series, she went through a range of overwhelmed reactions. She cried; she caught her breath; she excitedly squeezed the knee of a colleague sitting next to her.

headline: For Sheldon Silver, a Last Stay-Out-of-Prison Gambit Fails
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Decisions and Verdicts']

headline: Philippine Miners Trapped in Typhoon: Drawn by Gold, Drowned in Mud
keywords: ['Typhoon Mangkhut (2018)', 'Landslides and Mudslides', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Mines and Mining', 'Gold', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Rescues']
abstract: Dozens of people who eked out a living at a small-scale mine were killed when Typhoon Mangkhut’s drenching rains unleashed a landslide in their mountain community.
lead_paragraph: ITOGON, Philippines — A month ago, Jes Feliciano struck gold. The ingot was the size of a coin, and it brought the 16-year-old miner more money than he ever imagined.

headline: Review: A One-Man Funeral With Many Lives in ‘I Hear You and Rejoice’
abstract: Mikel Murfi’s virtuoso performance about the life and death of a redoubtable woman is a many-tongued wonder of Irish storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Accomplished entertainer though he is, Tony Cleary — who performs under the name of the Amazing No Instrumental Man — doesn’t have a thing on his creator. True, using only his mouth and hands, Tony is able to summon a church organ, a harmonica, a trumpet and, most amazingly of all, the fabled tenor John McCormack singing on a scratchy 78-r.p.m. record.

headline: After Fetching a High Price, Time Magazine Moves Into a New Era
abstract: “These things just take a lot longer than you think they would,” one executive said of the sale of Time magazine. Now Meredith must turn to the sales of Fortune and Sports Illustrated.
lead_paragraph: When Time magazine started in 1923, it hit upon a popular formula: short, punchy items that aggregated the week’s events and came in an entertaining package. But the newsweekly could never compete with the digital version of its own blueprint: the internet’s bloggers, explainers, listicles and 30-second videos.

headline: Jenifer Lewis Supports Colin Kaepernick by Wearing Nike on Emmys Red Carpet
keywords: ['Sneakers', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']

lead_paragraph: A year ago, it would have been a bold fashion statement. Now, it’s a political one.

headline: A Dress Rehearsal for Our Deaths
abstract: Yom Kippur asks us to look our mortality in the face. Can we sustain the stare?
lead_paragraph: This Tuesday at sundown, millions of people around the world will participate in a dress rehearsal for their deaths.

headline: In Flood-Hit Public Housing, a Reminder That the Poor Bear Brunt of Storms’ Fury
keywords: ['Hurricane Florence (2018)', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Poverty', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: Residents of a North Carolina housing complex have found themselves at the center of a redevelopment drama, even as they wonder what will become of their Florence-hit homes.
lead_paragraph: NEW BERN, N.C. — Before the river rose and the water trespassed into her little public housing unit, ruining her black sectional sofa and her children’s clothes, leaving her walls moist to the touch — indeed, before she even knew that the river could be her enemy — Keisha Monk thought she had found something better than basic shelter at Trent Court.

headline: Trump Orders Russia Investigation Documents Be Declassified
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: The decision was the latest example of Mr. Trump siding with congressional allies over law enforcement officials, who have said the move could endanger national security.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump ordered law enforcement and intelligence officials to declassify documents related to the Russia investigation and other inquiries, White House officials said on Monday, the latest instance of the president siding with Republican allies on Capitol Hill over federal law enforcement.

headline: Ira Sabin, Founder of JazzTimes Magazine, Is Dead at 90
abstract: Originally a drummer, he channeled his passion for jazz into a publication that began as a four-page newspaper to promote his record store in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Ira Sabin, a bebop drummer who in 1970 started what became JazzTimes magazine, one of the world’s leading jazz publications, as a four-page newspaper to promote new releases at his record store in Washington, died on Wednesday at an assisted living facility in Rockville, Md. He was 90.

headline: Stakes Are High as Red Sox Visit, but Only for the Yankees
abstract: Six weeks ago, this Red Sox-Yankees series appeared as though it could decide the division. But Boston surged out of sight, leaving the Yankees with altered priorities.
lead_paragraph: The last time the Yankees saw the Boston Red Sox, they were walking out of Fenway Park in the wee hours of the morning dragging their luggage, equipment bags and metaphorical tails behind them.

headline: Why America Needs to Hear Brett Kavanaugh’s Accuser
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The Senate is right to reopen hearings on his Supreme Court confirmation after Christine Blasey Ford’s claim of sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: What happened between two teenagers at a suburban Maryland house party on a night more than three decades ago? Since one of them has been identified by the other as Brett Kavanaugh, a federal appeals court judge who is now up for a seat on the United States Supreme Court, the Senate correctly decided to hear from Judge Kavanaugh and his accuser next week before proceeding with his confirmation.

headline: Surveillance Videos Offered Key Clues in Shooting Death of Rikers Island Officer
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers']

headline: Guatemala’s Democracy Is Under Threat — by Its Own President
abstract: The government refused to let an anti-corruption prosecutor back into the country, defying the top court and pushing the nation toward a constitutional crisis.
lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY — The president of Guatemala pushed the nation toward a constitutional crisis on Monday, ignoring an explicit order by the country’s top court while testing the bounds of the nation’s fragile democracy.

headline: Who Is Winning the Trade War?
abstract: Definitely not American consumers.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration will impose tariffs on $200 billion more in Chinese goods starting next week. As Mary E. Lovely wrote in August, most of the revenue raised by the Trump tariffs is coming out of the pockets of American consumers, not Chinese companies.

headline: The Federal Agency That Fuels the Opioid Crisis
abstract: The Drug Enforcement Administration has proved itself incompetent for decades.
lead_paragraph: Every day, nearly 200 people across the country die from drug overdoses. Opioids have been the primary driver of this calamity: first as prescription painkillers, then heroin and, more recently, illicitly manufactured fentanyl. The death toll has risen steadily over the past two decades.

headline: Officers Kill Knife-Wielding Queens Woman Who Reported Burglary, Police Say
abstract: The police said the woman lured officers to her home with a report of a burglary, then lunged at them with a knife as they searched for an intruder.
lead_paragraph: The police fatally shot a 54-year-old woman in Queens on Monday evening after she called 911 to report a burglary at her home and then lunged at responding officers with a knife, law enforcement officials said.

headline: 2018 Emmy Winners: A Complete List
abstract: A look at the shows, actors and production teams who won at the 70th Primetime Emmy Awards.

headline: The Decline and Fall of New York City Ballet
abstract: Once among the city's greatest cultural institutions, George Balanchine’s creation lost its way under his successor, Peter Martins.
lead_paragraph: George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein spent their lifetime creating what was possibly the most beautiful, fragile and deeply historied arts institution in American history — New York City Ballet. Their achievement is all the more miraculous for its having ever existed at all. Mr. Kirstein often said he was amazed each night as the curtain rose, so tenuous was the whole enterprise.

headline: Emmys Monologue: ‘Ronan Farrow Is on Line One’

headline: Emmys 2018: Yes, Teddy Perkins Was in the Crowd. And So Was Donald Glover.

Calls mounted to delay the vote and investigate. It was late September, and a Supreme Court seat hung in the balance.

headline: Henry Winkler Wins His First Emmy. Ayyy!

headline: European Capital

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 4, Episode 7: Tempered Expectations
abstract: The achievement gap is widening between Jimmy and Kim — unless your definition of success includes velour tracksuits.
lead_paragraph: Anyone wondering how “Better Call Saul” would handle the rest of Jimmy McGill’s yearlong suspension from the law — a lengthy span that had the potential to delay the arrival of the show’s title character — now has an answer. Through the magic of montage at the opening of this week’s episode, we zip from May to January, watching Kim collect plastic trophies for each branch of Mesa Verde she helps open, while Jimmy sells pay-as-you-go phones out of a van.

headline: Emmys Marriage Proposal: Glenn Weiss Surprised Fiancée and Show’s Producers

headline: Kim Jong-un Will Visit South Korea, Leaders Announce
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations']
abstract: The promised trip would be the first ever by a North Korean leader. Mr. Kim also promised to dismantle missile facilities in the presence of outside inspectors.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, will visit South Korea “in the near future,” he said on Wednesday after meeting with the South’s president, Moon Jae-in. He also agreed to dismantle missile facilities in the presence of outside inspectors, and he promised additional moves toward denuclearization if the United States takes steps of its own.

He grew up in Saginaw, Mich., an economically depressed Rust Belt city with one of the highest rates of violent crime in the nation. It is also a basketball hotbed, where players take pride in their scrappy, physical style of play. Draymond Green, an intense, sharp-elbowed All-Star with the N.B.A. champion Golden State Warriors, is among the pros who have come from Saginaw.

headline: Jerry Brown Made Climate Change His Issue. Now, He’s Not Sure How Much Politicians Can Do.
abstract: The California governor, set to retire in January, made global warming a signature cause. His appraisal: “I don’t know if I’m an optimist. I’m a realist.”

headline: Claire McCaskill Is in a Rugged Political Fight. She’s Survived Them Before.
