headline: New & Noteworthy
abstract: A selection of books published this week; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: KAFKAESQUE By Peter Kuper and Franz Kafka. (Norton, $19.95.) Kuper has been adapting Kafka’s stories in graphic novel form since 1988. This book gathers 14 of them, including “In the Penal Colony” and “A Hunger Artist,” placing the work in a contemporary setting so that Kafka, that master critic of the modern world, can comment on issues like civil rights and homelessness. STAN SMITH By Stan Smith, foreword by Pharrell Williams. (Rizzoli, $55.) The Stan Smith tennis sneaker, named after the former world No. 1 tennis player Stan Smith, has maintained cult status since it was first introduced over four decades ago. This book celebrates the sneaker’s reach, from mentions in rap lyrics to its appearance in Bollywood movies. THE WHITE HORSE By Mary McCartney. (Rizzoli, $55.) McCartney, a photographer who grew up in the Sussex countryside, focuses here on one white stallion, Alejandro, and the intimate relationship between horse and rider. WRITERS UNDER SURVEILLANCE Edited by JPat Brown, B. C. D. Lipton and Michael Morisy. (MIT Press, paper, $24.95.) Obtained through the Freedom of Information Act, the F.B.I. files in this collection monitor writers considered by the government to have been subversives. Many of the intellectual heavyweights are here, from Hannah Arendt to Susan Sontag to James Baldwin. AMY WINEHOUSE Photographs by Blake Wood, text by Nancy Jo Sales. (Taschen, $40.) Wood’s images of the singer, especially of her relaxing on the beach at St. Lucia, show a human, private side to contrast the self-destructive public persona.

headline: More ‘Gridlock Alert Days’: Don’t Even Think of Driving in Manhattan
abstract: In the latest sign of worsening traffic, the city expands its congestion warning system beyond the holiday season to get more drivers off the roads.
lead_paragraph: There are bad traffic days in New York City — many of them. And then there are gridlock alert days.

headline: The Other Side of Istanbul
abstract: The Asian side of the Turkish city, oft overlooked by travelers, provides plenty of charms — and a better chance to get maximum enjoyment from a minimal amount of lira.
lead_paragraph: Istanbul, famously, is a city that straddles two continents. And it’s clearly the European side of the Bosporus that attracts the bulk of the city’s tourism — in part because it’s home to the ancient city’s big league attractions, like the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque. But the Asian side of the strait, oft overlooked by visitors, is worth exploring in its own right, as I found when I visited this past June with my girlfriend, Sarah.

headline: Clarity and Grace Shine Through the Darkness in Sally Field’s Memoir, ‘In Pieces’
abstract: Though the traumatic events of Field’s childhood permeate almost every page, they do not define her.
lead_paragraph: IN PIECES By Sally Field Illustrated. 404 pp. Grand Central Publishing. $29.

headline: Trump’s Growing Legal Team Has a Problem: It’s Operating Partly in the Dark
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The president’s lawyers are struggling to understand where the investigations surrounding him are going, and the extent of his legal exposure.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly a dozen lawyers now assist President Trump in contending with two federal investigations, one in Washington and one in New York, that could pose serious threats to his presidency and his businesses. But the expanding legal team is struggling to understand where the investigations could be headed and the extent of Mr. Trump’s legal exposure.

headline: The 52 Places Traveler: In Lucerne, Kindness Trumps the (Stunning) Views
abstract: Lucerne, Switzerland, is best known — rightly so — for its mountains, lake and views. What sticks with me most, though, is the pervasive sense of hospitality and human kindness I found there.
lead_paragraph: Our columnist, Jada Yuan, is visiting each destination on our 52 Places to Go in 2018 list. This dispatch brings her to Lucerne, Switzerland; it took the No. five spot on the list and is the 34th stop on Jada’s itinerary.

headline: The Hotel in Afghanistan That Refuses to Close Its Doors
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Bost Hotel, a relic of America’s mid-20th-century presence in Helmand Province, has survived despite being at the center of decades of war.
lead_paragraph: The bay windows in the Bost Hotel’s dining room looked out across the Helmand River. For all the river’s immensity, the current, borne hundreds of miles from up in the Hindu Kush, spoke only in whispers. The air hummed with mosquitoes. Beyond the river, on the outskirts of Lashkar Gah, the capital of Afghanistan’s Helmand Province, red tracer rounds arced across the night sky.

headline: What I Saw When I Rode Out Florence
abstract: A storm’s violence, and its aftermath.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, N.C. — Hurricane Florence made landfall on Friday just five miles from my home here. Although the storm has since been downgraded to a tropical depression and lumbered west, today, Wilmington remains all but cut off from the outside world, with the major highways flooded and impassable. Toppled oak trees block intersections. Downed power lines snake across the ground. A giant sinkhole has swallowed one of the major thoroughfares. Coast Guard helicopters thunder across the sky, bringing aid supplies. We are marooned.

headline: The Designers Envisioning a Bold New Kind of Japanese Architecture
abstract: A freethinking firm makes its mark exploring the intersections between public and private, indoors and out, function and form.
lead_paragraph: ON A MAY morning that was somewhere between rainy and sunny, in a Tokyo neighborhood that was somewhere between Shibuya and Shinjuku, I arrived at a nondescript brown-tiled building to visit Makoto Tanijiri and Ai Yoshida, the 44-year-old principals of Suppose Design Office, a Japanese architecture firm known for its raw, unfinished aesthetic — bookcases made from shipping pallets, houses with gaping holes instead of windows — that has been frequently praised and often copied in recent years. Suppose, which has more than 35 employees between this office and another in Hiroshima, and which is responsible for some of the most idiosyncratic contemporary homes and offices throughout Japan, moved into this partly below-ground space in late 2016.

headline: What Happens When a Single Art Project Becomes a Decades-Long Obsession?
abstract: Rodin and Duchamp toiled away on pieces for spectacular lengths of time. But in an era of digital hyperdrive, fidelity to one work seems even more heroic.
lead_paragraph: A FEW DAYS AFTER Sept. 11, the artist Robert Longo noticed his youngest son, 6-year-old Joseph, standing in his bedroom in their Brooklyn apartment before a skyscraper made of Montessori blocks. Longo watched as the boy rammed it methodically with one of the three-inch cast-metal planes he collected, a Boeing 767-223ER, the exact model Mohamed Atta had just used to fly into the first tower of the World Trade Center. “He just kept crashing it into the blocks,” Longo, 65, recalls, “over and over and over. I just can’t get the image out of my head.”

headline: Review: ‘Garry Winogrand’ Pictures an Artist and His World
abstract: The film, subtitled “All Things Are Photographable,” gives the master of street photography the “American Masters” treatment.
lead_paragraph: “Garry Winogrand: All Things Are Photographable” gives the prolific street photographer — a label he disdained but could never shake — the “American Masters” treatment. Informative but not overwhelming, it blends biography and appreciative analysis in 90 brisk, packed minutes. Visual artists are especially good subjects for this kind of documentary, and still images like Winogrand’s — mostly black-and-white, full of latent drama and arrested kineticism — lend themselves to cinematic contemplation.

headline: La Vara Chefs Open Saint Julivert Fisherie in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn
abstract: An ode to wild boar on East 27th Street, a British import in the Time Warner Center and other restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: For their latest project, Saint Julivert Fisherie, Alex Raij and her husband, Eder Montero, the chefs who own La Vara, El Quinto Pino and Txikito, zeroed in on seafood. “I always wanted to draw attention to fish,” Ms. Raij said. “I like cooking fish, and I also wanted to take it out of the Spanish vernacular.” So the menu they devised features global touches in dishes like raw scallops with shiso tacos, sea urchin with a sweet-corn chawanmushi custard, shellfish pozole, and a tuna casserole with curry leaf. But Spain is not ignored either, with Txikito-style octopus carpaccio and skate with sherry, chili and parsley. The long, narrow space, formerly their Texoá coffee bar, has been done in 1930s Modernist style. A central bar, lit by a complex hanging fixture by the local artist David Weeks, is its focus. “I was inspired by the Maison de Verre in Paris,” Ms. Raij said, referring to a landmark building on the Left Bank. “I didn’t want anything blue and nautical-looking.” Glass brick and hard-edged metal are also used. The restaurant seats about 40. (Opens Thursday)

headline: After a Simulated Game, Aaron Judge Plays in a Real One

headline: High-Dose Folic Acid Does Not Prevent High Blood Pressure of Pregnancy
abstract: Some studies suggest that taking high doses of folic acid can prevent pre-eclampsia, but a randomized trial found it did not.
lead_paragraph: Some experts believe that a high daily dose of folic acid can reduce the risk for pre-eclampsia, the dangerous high blood pressure that can occur during pregnancy. A randomized trial has found that it does not work.

headline: Ehsan Yarshater, Iran Scholar With a Monumental Vision, Dies at 98
abstract: He worked on his magnum opus, an encyclopedia of Iranian history and culture, for more than 40 years, retiring at the letter “K.” The work goes on.
lead_paragraph: Ehsan Yarshater, an eminent Iranian historian who founded and edited the Encyclopedia Iranica, a magnum opus of Iranian history and culture that helped transform the modern understanding of Persian civilization, died on Sept. 2 in Fresno, Calif. He was 98.

headline: How to Throw a Party Like a British Fashion Designer
abstract: Comfort food, colorful dresses and unlimited cocktails are among Molly Goddard’s tips for hosting a memorable evening.
lead_paragraph: “Food and wine are just the best things in the world, aren’t they?” the British designer Molly Goddard says with a laugh. Dressed in a matching cardigan and skirt in a kaleidoscopic poppy print, she’s surveying the party she’s throwing at the newly opened Russell Square restaurant Neptune during London Fashion Week. A D.J. is spinning dance hall tracks at a bar festooned with strings of multicolored balloons and draped with rose-pink metallic fringe. At intimate tables of two or four, hungry guests tuck into what Goddard calls “speed” dinners, in which three courses are served within a 40-minute sitting, to allow guests to either stay on and party or head home for an early night. The rest of the 200-strong crowd — a mix of friends, fashion editors, loyal fans of Goddard’s eponymous brand and models fresh from her recent runway show — are dancing to Sean Paul’s “Get Busy.” “We’ve got buckets of beer, wine, prosecco, cocktails. Whatever anyone wants, we have it,” the designer adds with a smile.

headline: Cobble Hill’s Go-To Spot for Framing Art, or Alligator Skins
abstract: Since 1978, Make a Frame, in its landmark building on Atlantic Avenue, has been committed to creating custom frames and championing the work of local artists.
lead_paragraph: Not a lot has changed at Make a Frame in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn.

headline: Parts of a ‘Virtual’ Border Wall, Built With the Tech Behind Driverless Cars
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Border Barriers', 'Sensors', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Start-ups', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Computer Vision']
abstract: In a rural Texas county, lidar sensor technology is being tested as a way to spot illegal intruders from Mexico. That use could divide workers in Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: DEL RIO, Tex. — In this tiny town at the edge of South Texas brush country, a black steel fence runs along the Mexican border. About 15 feet high and topped by small metal spires that bend toward Mexico, it stretches west from a Border Patrol checkpoint for about a mile and a half. Then it stops.

headline: Annette Michelson, Film Studies Pioneer and Journal Founder, Dies at 95
abstract: Through the influential arts journal October and her own writings, Ms. Michelson helped turn cinema into an academic discipline.
lead_paragraph: Annette Michelson, who was a founder of the arts journal October and whose essays on film helped establish cinema studies as its own discipline and influenced generations of students, critics and scholars, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 95.

headline: Why Women Can Take Years to Come Forward With Sexual Assault Allegations
abstract: Some common reasons for doubt, like a long delay before speaking out or a hazy recall of some details, are exactly what experts say they would expect to see after a sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: She can’t remember exactly what happened. She sent friendly text messages afterward. She didn’t fight back. And, of course, she took decades to come forward.

headline: Justice Department Is Examining Tesla After Musk Comment
abstract: The company said the department requested documents after its chief executive, Elon Musk, said he had “funding secured” to take its stock off public markets.
lead_paragraph: Tesla said on Tuesday that the Justice Department had requested documents from the company after its chief executive, Elon Musk, abruptly announced that he had lined up funding to convert the publicly traded electric-car maker into a private company.

headline: Among the Mangroves, a Girl Learns to Swim
abstract: In a small Colombian village, a mother guides her daughter through a rite of passage.
lead_paragraph: Dulce is Spanish for “sweet,” and sweetness is what the 8-year-old protagonist of this film, aptly named Dulce, radiated as she welcomed us to her village, La Ensenada, on Colombia’s Pacific coast. We were there to document the effects of climate change on women in traditional communities, where rising sea levels have made difficult lives even harder. And we decided to center this story on the piangua, a black clam that women in these Afro-Caribbean communities harvest by hand to support their families (the clams are considered a delicacy in nearby Ecuador).

headline: Trump Sides With Kavanaugh, Accusing Democrats of Timing Sex Assault Charge to Delay Confirmation
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “I feel so badly for him that he’s going through this,” President Trump said of Judge Brett Kavanaugh. “This is not a man that deserves this.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump falsely charged on Tuesday that Democrats had sought to time a sexual assault allegation against his Supreme Court nominee, Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, to obstruct his confirmation, siding with the judge as he called for a swift process for airing the accusation on Capitol Hill.

headline: Christine Blasey Ford Wants F.B.I. to Investigate Kavanaugh Before She Testifies
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Sexual Harassment', '#MeToo Movement', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Her position puts the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing scheduled for Monday in doubt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The woman who has accused President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee of sexual assault all but ruled out appearing at an extraordinary Senate hearing scheduled for next week to hear her allegations, insisting on Tuesday that the F.B.I. investigate first.

headline: Review: The Humanity of Yvonne Rainer’s Natural and Peculiar Dances
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art’s Judson Dance Theater exhibition this week brings performances of Yvonne Rainer’s 1960s dances, with wonderful revelations.
lead_paragraph: Yet again, the nonconformist rebels of yesteryear become the standard-setters of today. The Museum of Modern Art exhibition “Judson Dance Theater: The Work Is Never Done” shows why the work of the New York downtown dance experimentalists of the 1960s was once radical. Many people would still be challenged by it today.

headline: Why Your DNA Is Still Uncharted Territory
abstract: Scientists are focusing on a relatively small number of human genes and neglecting thousands of others. The reasons have more to do with professional survival than genetics.
lead_paragraph: You have a gene called PNMA6F. All people do, but no one knows the purpose of that gene or the protein it makes. And as it turns out, PNMA6F has a lot of company in that regard.

headline: Wage Parity at Harvard
abstract: A retired union president tells the story of how it came to be.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How to Get Strong
abstract: You don’t have to lift like a bodybuilder (or look like one) to benefit from resistance training. And the best part is that it’s never too late to get started. We’ll show you how.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to lift like a bodybuilder (or look like one) to benefit from resistance training. And the best part is that it’s never too late to get started. We’ll show you how.

headline: Chair Umpire Who Counseled Nick Kyrgios Is Suspended by ATP Tour
abstract: Mohamed Lahyani, the Swedish chair umpire who gave an on-court pep talk to Nick Kyrgios during a match at the U.S. Open, will miss two tournaments.
lead_paragraph: Mohamed Lahyani, the Swedish chair umpire who gave an on-court pep talk to Nick Kyrgios during a match at this year’s United States Open, has been suspended without pay for two weeks by the ATP Tour because of the incident.

headline: An Experimental Troupe Can Unpack Its Bags
abstract: Theater Mitu inaugurates a new home in Gowanus, Brooklyn, with a multimedia piece called “Remnant.”
lead_paragraph: For over 20 years, the New York-based company Theater Mitu has been creating an experimental body of work that borrows elements from Hinduism and Christianity, Shakespeare and Euripides, Mexican history and state-of-the-art technology. One of its recent productions was a revival of “Death of a Salesman” in which Happy, Willy Loman’s younger son, was played by a punching bag.

headline: Ranch Nation
abstract: How one creamy, peppery salad dressing became America’s favorite flavor.
lead_paragraph: As a young republic, our nation embraced the dressings of many lands: Italian, French, Russian and the magical Thousand Islands. But with the creation — and inexorable rise — of ranch, we have forged the one true American dressing.

headline: Mary Nooter Roberts, Champion of African Art, Is Dead at 58
abstract: She helped alter standard institutional presentations of African art by acknowledging its spiritually, socially and physically interactive character.
lead_paragraph: Mary Nooter Roberts, a scholar of African art who helped change the way non-Western art is presented in Western museums, died on Sept. 11 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 58.

headline: ‘Bodyguard,’ a Dark Thriller From the BBC, Is Coming to Netflix
abstract: The hit British series explores the tension between security and civil liberties and stars the “Game of Thrones” actor Richard Madden.
lead_paragraph: Netflix will stream the BBC’s six-part political thriller “Bodyguard” outside the U.K. starting on Oct. 24, the company announced Tuesday. The series has already been a hit in Britain: The first episode drew in 10.4 million television viewers over seven days — the largest audience for any new U.K. show in a decade, according to the BBC.

headline: For Capitalism, Every Social Leap Forward Is a Marketing Opportunity
abstract: Brands are now racing to capture the market of young people who strive to live gender identities that fit.
lead_paragraph: They are the new beautiful people and their pronouns are they, their and them. Fashion courts them. Publishers pursue them. Corporations see in them the future of consuming, as generations come of age for whom notions of gender as traditionally constituted seem clunkier than a rotary phone.

headline: Lizzo Wants to Build You Up
abstract: “I made a commitment to feel-good music,” the artist said before a show at MoMA PS1. “I had to show my belly a lot of attention, a lot of love.”
lead_paragraph: Four hours before showtime at MoMA PS1 Warm Up, Lizzo was stressing about whether anyone in the crowd would know the lyrics to her songs. “I have to fake it until I make it,” the artist said backstage. “You just have to gas yourself up. It takes a lot of work.”

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Sept. 19, 2018
abstract: Look closely at these graphs, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Updated: September 20, 2018

lead_paragraph: Hurricane Florence continues to destroy life and property in North Carolina, as rivers across the state swell and flood their banks, and parts of South Carolina have faced flash flood warnings.

headline: Behind the Kidnapping Case That Inspired ‘Lolita’
abstract: Two new books, Sarah Weinman’s “The Real Lolita” and T. Greenwood’s “Rust and Stardust,” revisit the story of Sally Horner’s 1948 abduction.
lead_paragraph: THE REAL LOLITA The Kidnapping of Sally Horner and the Novel That Scandalized the World By Sarah Weinman 306 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $27.99.

headline: A New Art Season, a New Test of Survival
abstract: The art market is in crisis, and the art fairs are largely to blame.
lead_paragraph: Now that the new art season has begun, one question on everyone’s mind is: How many more galleries will close by next summer? In the past five years, notices of galleries shutting their doors have become as commonplace as announcements of new exhibitions.

headline: The Amputee Who Showed Everyone
abstract: Shaquem Griffin of the Seattle Seahawks lost his hand but not his dream.
lead_paragraph: When he was 4 his mother found him in the kitchen with a knife. He was summoning the nerve to slice off his own fingers. This wasn’t because he was crazy but because he was all too sane and understood correctly that the dysfunctional appendages dangling from his misshapen left hand were the source of his physical agony. He wanted relief, however he had to get it.

headline: HBO and Netflix, Reluctant Rivals, Party Down After Winning 23 Emmys Apiece
abstract: After years of Emmy glory, HBO hosted a civilized affair in an airy plaza. The Netflix party was loud, with Dave Chappelle and Tiffany Haddish among the revelers.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Richard Plepler, the chairman and chief executive officer of HBO, stood at the center of an airy plaza at the Pacific Design Center, where the network has held its post-Emmys party for more than a decade.

headline: Megaphones Up, the Philharmonic Opens With Two Young Voices
abstract: The composers Ashley Fure and Conrad Tao make their New York Philharmonic debuts with new works during the first two weeks of the season.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic’s declaration of its new-music bona fides this season is so emphatic, it’s being delivered with megaphones.

headline: N.F.L. Hall of Famers Demand Health Insurance and Share of Revenue
keywords: ['Football', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: The group, led by Eric Dickerson, is demanding health insurance coverage and a share of N.F.L. revenues or else those former players will boycott Hall of Fame induction ceremonies.
lead_paragraph: A group of Hall of Famers led by Eric Dickerson is demanding health insurance coverage and a share of N.F.L. revenues or else those former players will boycott the induction ceremonies.

headline: A Witty and Original Writer Shares His Love for the Essay
abstract: In “Essayism,” Brian Dillon rhapsodizes over his favorite practitioners of the form, including Susan Sontag, Joan Didion and Montaigne.
lead_paragraph: Every year, 30,000 tons of cosmic material passes through the atmosphere and drizzles down to earth. Only in the Arctic, or at the bottom of the deepest seas, can it be found unadulterated: a powder of asteroid and comet particles. Everywhere else this stardust mingles with the earth, with us. We wear it in our hair, carry it in our pockets.

headline: Salt Bae Serves Maduro as Venezuela Suffers
abstract: The celebrity chef drew Mr. Rubio’s ire for serving a lavish meal to the authoritarian president of Venezuela, known for his extravagant lifestyle amid crushing poverty.
lead_paragraph: Video footage released Monday showed a performance like the one that launched Nusret Gokce to stardom. But within a matter of hours, Mr. Gokce, a celebrity chef better known as Salt Bae, had deleted the footage after Senator Marco Rubio denounced him on Twitter.

headline: Inside Margaret Howell’s Holiday Home, a Trove of Found Objects
abstract: For 20 years, the British designer has combed the shores of Suffolk for sculptural flotsam.
lead_paragraph: For 20 years, the British designer has combed the shores of Suffolk for sculptural flotsam.

headline: How Margaret Howell, Master of British Fashion, Became a Beachcomber
keywords: ['Rock and Stone', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week']
abstract: The designer’s Modernist holiday home on the Suffolk coast abounds with artful arrangements of unusual pebbles and colorful driftwood.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Howell, the designer and director of the timeless British brand of the same name, likes to celebrate her birthday with a swim in the sea. It’s a tradition she’s continued since she was a little girl in 1950s England; now a preternaturally youthful 72, her enthusiasm shows no sign of waning. Since buying her Modernist holiday home on the Suffolk coast, near the small town of Woodbridge, close to 20 years ago, these swims have become more and more frequent. “I’m outdoors here most of the time,” says Howell, whose modest four-bedroom retreat, designed by the Swiss architect Rudy Mock, sits on a narrow lane that meanders for half a mile, all the way down to the beach.

abstract: Administration officials told senators that a court ruling that limits detention of children has encouraged migrants to bring their offspring when they illegally enter the country.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Trump administration officials told a Senate panel on Tuesday that a decades-old court ruling that limits the length of time migrant children can be detained hampers the government’s ability to stem illegal immigration, and needs to be amended by Congress.

headline: Let It Flow! #PantsuitNation is Now Caftan Country
abstract: Hillary Clinton, Beyoncé and Chrissy Teigen are among those choosing this sisterly, forgiving style.
lead_paragraph: It is the opposite of the pantsuit: the free-flowing, form-swallowing caftan. Yet there was Hillary Clinton talking to Laurene Powell Jobs about President Trump, Russia and the midterm elections at OZY Fest in July, having not so much walked as wafted onstage in a baby-blue linen caftan dotted with white cloudlike shapes.

abstract: A tourist draw, the Cape Fear River in Wilmington, N.C., can also be a beast, surging madly to overtake homes and force residents fleeing.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, N.C. — J. Michael Hutson stood with his neighbors at the edge of the Northeast Cape Fear River on Tuesday morning, watching as its menacing brown waters advanced on their homes.

headline: The N.H.L., Seeking Fans in China, Calls In the Great One
abstract: China wants to have 300 million winter sports fans by the time it hosts the 2022 Olympics. The N.H.L. wants to build its Asian fan base. The two missions converged this past week.
lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China — Some of the young Chinese hockey players receiving trophies here on a recent morning looked stunned, as if they had seen a ghost.

headline: Consumers Will Increasingly Feel Pain From Trump’s Trade War. Here’s Why.
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The administration has tried to shield popular products from tariffs. That gets harder with each new round.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration seems confident that consumers will not feel pain from its escalating trade war with China. “Because it’s spread over thousands and thousands of products, nobody’s going to actually notice it at the end of the day,” Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross told CNBC on Tuesday, when asked about the administration’s latest round of tariffs on Chinese imports.

headline: Our Favorite Photos From the London Shows
abstract: T’s photographers captured the week’s defining moments, from Christopher Kane’s jewels to Matty Bovan’s extreme millinery.
lead_paragraph: T’s photographers captured the week’s defining moments, from Christopher Kane’s jewels to Matty Bovan’s extreme millinery.

headline: T’s Best Photos From London Fashion Week
abstract: Highlights from the spring 2019 shows, including Riccardo Tisci’s Burberry debut.
lead_paragraph: There was a palpable charge in the air at London Fashion Week, where the shows paid homage to both tradition and feverish self-expression. The models for Erdem looked like exuberant mourners, in their black veils and high-necked dresses of all colors. In his debut for Burberry, Riccardo Tisci showcased the company’s trademark trenches with corsets and gussied up beige raincoats with splendid jewels and feathers. Meanwhile, Molly Goddard presented riots of ruffles and flouncy frocks — a spectacle of over-the-top femininity with a revolutionary edge. Here, we round up the highlights from the spring 2019 shows, as captured by T’s photographers.

headline: Brooklyn Diocese Is Part of $27.5 Million Settlement in 4 Sex Abuse Cases
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Compensation for Damages (Law)']
abstract: The settlement is believed to be one of the largest ever awarded to victims of sexual abuse in the Roman Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: Four men who were repeatedly sexually abused as children by a religion teacher at a Roman Catholic church reached a $27.5 million settlement with the Diocese of Brooklyn and a local after-school program on Tuesday, in one of the largest settlements ever awarded to individual victims of abuse within the church.

headline: Ruth Clark, Who Helped the Jobless Get a Foothold, Dies at 76
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Secretaries, Stenographers and Typists', 'Vocational Training', 'Minorities', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A key-punch operator herself, she opened an agency in 1974 to meet a demand for data processors and to relieve unemployment in minority neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Clark, a civic leader and philanthropist who founded a personnel agency both to meet the demand for data processors in the 1970s and to relieve high unemployment in Harlem and other minority neighborhoods in New York, died on Thursday in Manhattan. She was 76.

headline: Los Angeles Will Ban the Sale of Fur
abstract: The City Council voted on Tuesday for a fur-free future.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles is on track to become the largest city in the United States to ban the sale of fur clothing and accessories.

headline: Thad Mumford, Pathbreaking Television Writer, Is Dead at 67
abstract: Mr. Mumford forged a writing career on shows like “M*A*S*H” and “Maude” at a time when African-Americans were rare in network writing rooms.
lead_paragraph: Thad Mumford, an Emmy Award-winning writer and producer for “M*A*S*H” and other hit television shows at a time when African-Americans were practically unheard-of in network writing rooms, died on Sept. 6 in Silver Spring, Md. He was 67.

headline: Stormy Daniels’s ‘Full Disclosure’ Book Will Likely Rattle White House
abstract: Mr. Trump’s presidency has proved to be an unexpected boon for the publishing industry, which has unleashed a barrage of juicy insider accounts.
lead_paragraph: In her new memoir, “Full Disclosure,” Stormy Daniels cites a statement that President Trump’s former lawyer, Michael Cohen, asked her to sign, denying that she had a sexual encounter with Mr. Trump. “If indeed I did have a relationship with Donald Trump,” the statement read, “trust me, you wouldn’t be reading about it in the news, you would be reading about it in my book.”

headline: I Highly Recommend Joining This Cult
abstract: I am slashing my spending and rethinking my bourgeois ways. You should, too.
lead_paragraph: Let me tell you about the cult I have joined: the cult of thrift. The indoctrination started gently, with a podcast here, a YouTube video there, about minimalism, debt-free living, frugality, decluttering, zero waste.

headline: ‘It’s Back’: Underwater Yet Again, the Carolinas Face a New Reality
abstract: As climate change and rapid growth bring more flooding, residents and officials must grapple with where to rebuild and how to prepare for the next storm.
lead_paragraph: GARLAND, N.C. — After Hurricane Matthew stomped into his trailer home and pulped his floors, walls and cabinets two years ago, Bobby Barnes Jr. spent $90,000 to rebuild and protect himself from another flood. He raised the house two feet onto brick pilings, bought $1,300 worth of flood fencing and said he complied with every federal recommendation.

headline: On Kavanaugh, a Changed America Debates an Explosive Charge
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', '#MeToo Movement', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: The accusations against the Supreme Court nominee are being assessed under different social and cultural conventions than when the episode allegedly occurred.
lead_paragraph: It was 36 years ago. The accusation: There was a party, alcohol. A 17-year-old boy was drunk and started groping a 15-year-old girl, pinning her down and covering her mouth so she couldn’t scream. Today, she doesn’t remember some of the details. He insists it didn’t happen at all.

headline: The Broken Pieces of Middle East Peace
abstract: Forty years after the Camp David accords, we’re again at a fateful moment.
lead_paragraph: This week marks the 40th anniversary of the Camp David accords — the high-water mark of Middle East peacemaking. How far we have fallen since then. It makes you weep.

headline: In Mexico, a Truck Full of Corpses Takes a Mystery Road Trip
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Cadavers']
abstract: When a refrigerated truck used as storage by a morgue in Jalisco State was taken on an unusual, and unexplained, trip, it became a sad symbol of Mexico’s wave of violence.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The morgue had a problem: It had run out of space for fresh corpses. Violence was soaring and new bodies were arriving every day, yet there was no place to store them.

headline: How the Next Downturn Will Surprise Us
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Recession and Depression', 'Credit and Debt', 'Interest Rates', 'Private Equity']
abstract: In their campaign to contain the risks that caused the Great Recession, central bankers may have planted the seeds for the next global economic crisis.
lead_paragraph: After the fall of Lehman Brothers 10 years ago, there was a public debate about how the leading American banks had grown “too big to fail.” But that debate overlooked the larger story, about how the global markets where stocks, bonds and other financial assets are traded had grown worrisomely large.

lead_paragraph: In firefighting it’s called a “rekindle”: A blaze thought to be extinguished that later reignites soon after firefighters have left the scene. Failure to find and douse embers smoldering behind walls and flooring leads to rekindles. The only thing that can prevent a rekindle is a thorough overhaul (tearing apart floors, ceilings and furniture). If a firefighter fails to conduct that overhaul, hours later they will be face to face with a second fire that often burns bigger and hotter than the original blaze.

headline: Finland Saved These Children From War. Did It Hurt Them in the Process?
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Immigration Detention', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: What a study of evacuees tells us about the lifelong health effects of separating kids from their parents.
lead_paragraph: During World War II, the Finnish government evacuated about 70,000 children to protect them from the danger, stress and uncertainty of war. Their parents agreed to send them to foster homes primarily in Sweden. It was one of the largest evacuations of children in the 20th century. And years later, some would consider the program a grave mistake.

headline: House Hunting in … England

Dating to the 17th century, it was built on a large estate called Baynards Park, and was restored in the 1970s. The 16.8-acre property, known as Brooklands Farm, includes an indoor pool, stables, garage and a barn converted to a two-bedroom guesthouse.

keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'States (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Sexual Harassment']

The allegation has also scrambled the political calculations for 10 Democratic senators running for re-election in states won by President Trump, particularly three moderate Democrats who had been weighing a yes vote.

abstract: The houses in this issue aren’t meant to appeal to everyone; they were meant to appeal to their owners, and that is why they appealed to us as well.

One day, once we’d reached a certain level of closeness, I showed him, a little shyly and a little proudly, some photographs of my apartment. I said I wanted his opinion; I was really expecting praise.

headline: From the Director of ‘Call Me by Your Name,’ a New Project: A House
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Textiles', 'Tables', 'Design', 'Furniture', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Luca Guadagnino has long dreamed of being an interior designer. Inside a former silk mill on Lake Como, he got his shot.
lead_paragraph: FIRST, CUT SHARPLY off a two-lane road leading around Italy’s Lake Como and dodge the local stray cats until you hit a cobbled lane lined with scruffy mulberry trees. Follow this to its end. Then, on your left, you’ll see the stucco facade of an apparently anonymous edifice — an ocher two-story rectangle overlooking a simple walled garden and lawn, the lake just beyond them. This is La Filanda (the Mill), the name a nod to the 9,600-square-foot building’s original 19th-century function as a silk-weaving factory. Only a small nameplate — that says simply “housekeeper”— hints at the place’s current residential use. “We felt it was more interesting having something beautiful inside that nobody knows,” says Federico Marchetti, 49, the Milan-based entrepreneur behind the Yoox Net-a-Porter online retail empire. For the past four years, he and his partner, the British journalist Kerry Olsen, 41, have devoted themselves to constructing this privately opulent weekend refuge on a stretch of lakeshore best known for the palaces of American movie stars and Russian oligarchs.

headline: A Smorgasbord Recession? (Wonkish)

headline: Tell Us Your Love Story. Just Keep It Really Short.
abstract: We’re looking for all the emotion that’s fit to print — in no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: What kind of love story can you share in two tweets, an Instagram caption or a Facebook post? Tell us a love story from your own life — happy or sad, capturing a moment or a lifetime — in no more than 100 words. Include a picture taken by you that complements your narrative, whether a selfie, screenshot or snapshot. We seek to publish the most funny and heart-wrenching entries we receive. We call them Tiny Love Stories. They are about as long as this paragraph. They must be true and unpublished.

headline: Luigi Cavalli-Sforza, 96, Who Tracked Genes Through History, Dies
abstract: Before 23andMe and Ancestry.com, he did groundbreaking work exploring how genes reveal where people come from and whom they’re related to.
lead_paragraph: Millions of people in recent years have sent off samples of their saliva to DNA-testing companies like 23andMe and Ancestry.com hoping to find out where their forebears came from and whether they have mystery relatives in some distant land, or even around the corner.

headline: The Exacting Eye of Akris’s Albert Kriemler
abstract: He has helmed the house founded by his grandmother for 40 years. Here, he shares his many inspirations with T.
lead_paragraph: “I grew up to the steady hum of sewing machines,” says Albert Kriemler, the creative director of his family’s 96-year-old company, Akris. Founded in 1922 by his grandmother, Alice Kriemler-Schoch (the company’s name is a sort of acronym of her initials), the Swiss label got its start making polka-dotted aprons in the alpine town of St. Gallen, famous for its embroidery, where the brand’s headquarters are still located. In the ’60s and ’70s, Kriemler’s parents, Max and Ute, expanded Akris’s scope, producing prêt-à-porter for such houses as Ted Lapidus and Givenchy. As a young man, Kriemler would often travel to fabric fairs with his family; on a trip to Paris in 1976, he attended his first Yves Saint Laurent show. “It was then that I knew I was completely infatuated with fashion,” he says. He made plans to study at Paris’s École de la Chambre Syndicale de la Couture, but they were waylaid when, after Akris’s managing director died suddenly, Kriemler’s father convinced him to join the business as creative director in 1980. He was just 19.

headline: A Better Way to Get New York’s Traffic Moving
abstract: The city can fight congestion and raise revenue through parking regulations.
lead_paragraph: Traffic is strangling New York’s economic vitality and quality of life, while the city’s transit system creaks because of chronic underinvestment. One solution, congestion pricing, would undoubtedly reduce traffic and generate desperately needed revenue for transit. But this has proved politically difficult in New York, both when  attempted in 2007 and again this year. Congestion pricing asks people to pay to drive on roads they used to drive on without charge, so the politics won’t get easier anytime soon.

headline: Review: Dancing (not Posing) on Trajal Harrell’s Runway
abstract: Mr. Harrell uses theatrical flair to explore the connection between early modern dance and hoochie-coochie-type Orientalism.
lead_paragraph: Trajal Harrell can turn a stage into a living, breathing painting, just once removed from a runway show. Like a garment, his latest work, “Caen Amour,” is two-sided: visible from the front and the back. As performers glide past silkily, awkwardly or fiercely — all the while teetering on their toes as if they were in heels in a fashion show — they wear and carry costumes, from ordinary scraps of fabric draped to couture perfection to a fantastically voluminous black ruffled dress by the Japanese label Comme des Garçons.

headline: Alone in the Studio in 1983, Prince Is Revealed
abstract: Listening to the nine songs on “Piano & a Microphone 1983,” the first album of material from Prince’s storied vault, feels like eavesdropping on the artist at work.
lead_paragraph: Even when he played alone, Prince thought like a full band. That’s clear from the opening notes of “Piano & a Microphone 1983,” the first album released by the Prince estate with material from his immense archive, the Vault.

abstract: They’re not as shiny as diamonds, but smog free rings are considered sustainable and ethical — and they’re also much more affordable.

lead_paragraph: With about six months to go until Britain quits the European Union, time is short and much is unresolved. But a common goal now binds British Prime Minister Theresa May and her continental counterparts: getting a deal — perhaps any deal — to push withdrawal over the line.

headline: New York Review of Books Editor Is Out Amid Uproar Over #MeToo Essay
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes', '#MeToo Movement', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The editor, Ian Buruma, left after a backlash regarding an essay by a Canadian radio personality who lost his job after sexual misconduct allegations.

headline: Living the American Dream — in Hiding
abstract: In “Dear America,” Jose Antonio Vargas writes about the precarious life he has built in the United States as an undocumented immigrant.
lead_paragraph: Jose Antonio Vargas comes from a family of gamblers, and in his new book, “Dear America: Notes of an Undocumented Citizen,” he’s upping the ante — or maybe, given the current executive’s predilection for travel bans and family separations, he’s going all in. Vargas recalls the enormous wager his family made 25 years ago, when his mother brought him to Ninoy Aquino International Airport in Manila and put him on a flight to California. He was 12 years old, and he would go to America first. Mama, as he calls her throughout his memoir, promised to follow.

headline: Elephant Tusk DNA Helps Track Ivory Poachers
abstract: Researchers are examining the genetic data in seized elephant ivory to trace it back to the animals’ homelands and connect it to global trafficking crimes.
lead_paragraph: Poachers are killing 40,000 elephants a year and with a global elephant population of just 400,000, it doesn’t take a mathematician to figure out that there is an urgent need to stop the killing.

headline: Pakistan Court Releases Nawaz Sharif, Ex-Prime Minister, From Prison
abstract: The decision by Islamabad’s High Court, which also ordered the release on bail of his daughter, signals that the Sharif family may be moving closer to restoring its political might.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Pakistani court on Wednesday ordered that the jailed former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and his daughter and son-in-law be released on bail as they appeal convictions on corruption charges, inching the family closer to restoring their status as political juggernauts in the country.

headline: Alberta Ferretti: Spring 2019
abstract: Alberta Ferretti 2019 Collection
lead_paragraph: Alberta Ferretti 2019 Collection

headline: As Storms Loom, Some Immigrant Families Wonder: Is It Safe to Seek Help?
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Foreign Workers', 'Migrant Labor (Agriculture)', 'Hurricane Florence (2018)', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Floods', 'Deportation']
abstract: For undocumented families living in fear of deportation, Florence presented an extra challenge: Whether to seek government shelter, food or other aid.
lead_paragraph: With Hurricane Florence looming, Lucy, her husband and their twin 16-year-old daughters sat frozen in their living room last week on Johns Island, off the coast of South Carolina, unsure of what to do.

headline: From ’80s Street Art to Graphic Novels. And Back.
keywords: ['Art', 'Posters', 'Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists']
abstract: After 40 years, Richard McGuire’s handmade “Ixnae Nix” street posters come out of the drawer, into the New York Art Book Fair and Alden Projects.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine many people becoming emotional over a nondescript alley in downtown New York. But the illustrator and graphic novelist Richard McGuire sounded downright wistful as he gazed out the back window of his fifth-floor studio at Cortlandt Alley — which once led to the Mudd Club, a much-mythologized dawn-of-the-’80s nightspot. Yet he wasn’t feeling nostalgic for his time onstage there, playing bass with his band Liquid Liquid.

headline: Review: City Ballet, in Turmoil, Shows the Value of What’s at Stake
abstract: On opening night, while a crisis threatens New York City Ballet offstage, “Jewels” demonstrated the beauty and meaning of Balanchine choreography.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, New York City Ballet opened its fall season at the David H. Koch Theater with “Jewels” (1967), by George Balanchine, the company’s founding choreographer. You would not have known from the dancing onstage that there was a deeply disturbing crisis offstage. But you would have seen at once why City Ballet remains singularly important.

headline: Killing of Champion Golfer in ‘Senseless, Random Act’ Stuns Iowa State
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Golf', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Celia Barquín Arozamena, 22, was stabbed to death while playing golf. The suspect had spoken of “an urge to rape and kill a woman,” an acquaintance said.
lead_paragraph: Celia Barquín Arozamena had played some of the best golf courses in the world, but her promising life ended on a humble public course down the road from her college, Iowa State University.

headline: A High-Pressure Countdown for the New York Philharmonic’s New Maestro
abstract: We went behind the scenes with Jaap van Zweden in the weeklong run-up to his first performance as the orchestra’s music director.
lead_paragraph: Opening night was a week away, and Jaap van Zweden had just finished his first day as music director of the New York Philharmonic.

headline: Humans Are Making Hurricanes Worse. Here’s How.
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Hurricane Florence (2018)', 'Hurricane Harvey (2017)', 'Weather', 'Floods', 'Environment']
abstract: We’re making natural disasters unnaturally harmful, scientists say. And the number of ways we’re doing it is fairly astonishing.
lead_paragraph: When hurricane Florence struck the Carolinas last week, humanity played a role in the destruction.

headline: Notes From the Book Review Archives
abstract: In which we consult the Book Review’s past to shed light on the books of the present. This week: an unsigned review of Louisa Alcott’s letters.
lead_paragraph: This week Francine Prose reviews a book about the legacy of Louisa Alcott’s “Little Women,” published 150 years ago. Below is an unsigned 1889 review of a collection of Alcott’s letters and journals.

headline: Voting at Home Will Help Save Our Democracy
keywords: ['Absentee Voting', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Voting Machines']
abstract: All 50 states should follow the example set by Oregon and Washington.
lead_paragraph: The single best way to increase voter turnout?

headline: Why ‘Little Women’ Still Matters, 150 Years On
abstract: In “Meg, Jo, Beth, Amy,” Anne Boyd Rioux seeks to restore a classic to its proper place.
lead_paragraph: MEG, JO, BETH, AMY The Story of “Little Women” and Why It Still Matters By Anne Boyd Rioux Illustrated. 273 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $27.95.

headline: Bloomberg’s Blind Spot on Racial Injustice
abstract: He should acknowledge the error of the N.Y.P.D.’s stop-and-frisk policy.
lead_paragraph: I covered Michael Bloomberg for years and have many stories about him. But this one is my favorite because it reminds me of what a real leader can be.

headline: Mavericks and Mark Cuban Sanctioned by N.B.A. Over Handling of Sexual Harassment
abstract: An investigation determined Cuban could have done more to address misconduct among team officials. The owner agreed to donate $10 million to charities in lieu of a fine.
lead_paragraph: Mark Cuban, the billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks, will pay $10 million to women’s leadership and domestic-violence organizations under an agreement with the N.B.A. announced Wednesday to address sexual harassment and other improper conduct among employees in the team’s front office.

headline: You May Be Surprised to Hear That Restoration Hardware Is Doing Great
abstract: Restoration Hardware seemed doomed. Now, it’s a vast and booming bricks and mortar empire. What gives?
lead_paragraph: On the second Saturday in September, the new RH Gallery opened its doors to the Meatpacking District, looking just as you’d expect: a glowering, 90,000-square-foot landscape of poured concrete flecked with bronze, stone and glass, through which sails a flotilla of enormous gray velvet and white linen sofas. This shopper became entangled in the downy raft of a massive sectional called Cloud, and struggled to right herself. Alongside her, a pair of tween siblings were curled over their devices; when they lurched up and wandered away, sales associates darted in to fluff the pillows. Along the charcoal-colored walls, armies of classical statuary and framed plaster intaglios offered a whiff of the Grand Tour. (“Intaglios can flex modern and classic at the same time,” noted a design associate.)

headline: Crime and Racial Strife Didn’t Stop His Teams. Will a Locked School Door?
abstract: The Flames, a youth basketball program in Brooklyn, has a storied history, but now its founder is fighting the school it has long considered home base.
lead_paragraph: The Flames youth basketball program in Brooklyn has a history like something out of a Spike Lee movie.

headline: Windows on How Cities Change Can Be All Too Captivating
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Maps', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Transit Systems', 'Smartphones', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Transportation']
abstract: Technology is crowding curbs with ride hailers and keeping homeowners fixated on housing values. Here are the tools that Emily Badger, a writer for The Upshot, uses to analyze the ripple effects.
lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Emily Badger, who writes about cities and urban policy for The Upshot in Washington, discussed the tech she’s using.

headline: SeaWorld Agrees to Pay $5 Million in ‘Blackfish Effect’ Case
keywords: ['AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Whales and Whaling', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The S.E.C. says the company and its former chief executive misled investors about the financial impact of the documentary.
lead_paragraph: When the 2013 film “Blackfish” highlighted the story of Tilikum, a captive orca that killed a trainer, it spurred widespread anger over the confinement of the whales by companies like SeaWorld.

headline: Fewer Attacks, but a More Complex Terrorist Threat in 2017, U.S. Says
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Terrorist attacks and deaths declined in 2017 after a concerted push against the Islamic State, but Al Qaeda and militant groups linked to Iran remain deadly.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Foreign terrorist groups and their affiliates had a bad year in 2017 as the United States and other countries fought back against the Islamic State, but Al Qaeda and Iranian-backed militias remain deadly threats, according to an annual government terrorism report that was released on Wednesday.

headline: How Democracy Is Child’s Play
abstract: Readers discuss the ways that play builds cooperation and understanding.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Millions of Carolina Homes Are at Risk of Flooding. Only 335,000 Have Flood Insurance.
keywords: ['Floods', 'Flood Insurance', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Hurricane Florence (2018)', 'Homeowners Insurance']
abstract: Here’s why the federal flood insurance program won’t pick up the slack.
lead_paragraph: Millions of people in the Carolinas are at risk of their homes flooding because of Hurricane Florence. Only about 335,000 homes in the two states have flood insurance.

headline: Maroon 5 to Headline Super Bowl Halftime Show
abstract: The band is scheduled to take the stage for the annual extravaganza on Feb. 3 in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: A band will once again take the stage at the Super Bowl halftime show.

headline: As the Far Right Gains in Germany, Merkel Weakens
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel tried to find a way to fire her intelligence chief, a darling of the far right. In the end, he was promoted, to the outrage of many.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — For nearly two weeks Chancellor Angela Merkel tried to find a way to fire her own domestic intelligence chief, a man who had publicly contradicted her and become the darling of the far right for questioning the authenticity of a video showing angry white men chasing an immigrant.

headline: Man Shoots 4 People Near Pennsylvania Court, Then Is Killed by Police
abstract: The gunman was set to appear in court in Masontown, Pa., in a domestic violence case, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A man walked into a municipal building south of Pittsburgh on Wednesday and shot four people — including a police sergeant — before a police officer fatally shot him outside a courtroom where the gunman was to appear for a hearing in a domestic violence case, the authorities said.

headline: Flooding in North Carolina, as Seen From a Drone
abstract: Aerial footage from North Carolina shows the scale of flooding in the aftermath of Hurricane Florence.
lead_paragraph: Aerial footage from North Carolina shows the scale of flooding in the aftermath of Hurricane Florence.

headline: Debunking 5 Viral Rumors About Christine Blasey Ford, Kavanaugh’s Accuser
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Dr. Blasey has been the target of widespread social media disinformation since she came forward with accusations of sexual assault against Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, the Supreme Court nominee.
lead_paragraph: Just minutes after Christine Blasey Ford, a California-based psychologist, went public with accusations of teenage sexual assault against Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, the Supreme Court nominee, internet investigators began combing her past for clues about her possible motives, and trying to cast doubt on the veracity of her claims.

headline: The Designer Who References Asian Iconography and His Older Sisters’ Clubbing Phase
abstract: In London, A Sai Ta makes vibrantly colorful, innovative women’s wear that explores his mixed heritage.
lead_paragraph: “It’s organized chaos in here,” says the British-Vietnamese designer A Sai Ta, standing in the middle of his tiny north London studio. Among the stacks of overstuffed plastic boxes exploding with garments — skimpy transparent neon tops, a pair of American-flag-patterned pants, scarlet sweaters trimmed with fraying fringe — some eight provisional assistants are busy helping Ta put the finishing touches on his spring 2019 collection. Ta, 30, runs his studio alone, and so his friends have stepped in to help ensure everything gets finished: One volunteer hems tie-dyed fluorescent orange ribbon belts, another carefully glues plumes of sugar-pink and lime-green ostrich feathers to a pair of minimalist ’90s-era strappy sandals.

headline: A Glimpse Inside the Hidden World of Hasidic Women
abstract: Orthodox Jewish women and men live in tightly defined, and separate, spheres. The photographer Sharon Pulwer was given a rare invitation to enter the private world of Brooklyn’s most Orthodox Jewish women.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Pulwer was lost in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, shortly after moving here from Israel to study photography, when she came across the black hats and modest clothes of religious Jews in New York City. A secular Jew, she was momentarily taken aback. “I was very surprised that there was this very vivid part of Jewish life here that I was not aware about.”

headline: Giancarlo Esposito Reads ‘Making a Judgment on Love’
abstract: The “Breaking Bad” and “Dear White People” actor reads an essay about a dying man’s final wish and a judge's compassionate decision.
lead_paragraph: Exhausted after an arduous trial, Lloyd Zimmerman was in no mood to fulfill special requests. In fact, the Minnesota judge just wanted to be left alone. But an unexpected call brought out his compassion. On this week’s Modern Love podcast, Giancarlo Esposito reads Mr. Zimmerman’s moving essay, “Making a Judgment on Love.”

headline: Catholic Bishops Plan a Complaint Hotline for Sex Abuse
abstract: Hoping to rebuild credibility after several bishops were brought down by allegations of sexual abuse, the American bishops’ conference promised a hotline, a new code of conduct and other measures.
lead_paragraph: Responding to a deepening scandal over sexual misconduct in their own ranks, Catholic bishops in the United States say they plan to set up a hotline — run by a third party — to field complaints about bishops who have sexually abused or harassed minors or adults.

headline: Robert Venturi, Architect Who Rejected Modernism, Dies at 93
abstract: To the modernist notion of “less is more,” he retorted, “Less is a bore,” arguing for ornament, historical references and even humor in architecture.
lead_paragraph: Robert Venturi, the influential American architect and theorist whose buildings and best-selling books helped inspire the movement known as postmodernism, in which historic elements enliven contemporary forms, died on Tuesday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 93.

headline: Ryan Coogler and LeBron James Bringing Back ‘Space Jam’
abstract: An oft-rumored sequel to “Space Jam,” with LeBron James, is officially in the works. Ryan Coogler will be a producer and Terence Nance will direct.
lead_paragraph: Everybody get up, it’s time to slam again. We’ve got a real jam going down. Welcome to another “Space Jam.”

headline: Arthur Mitchell: What to Watch and Read
abstract: Watch clips from “Agon” and “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” and read interviews with Mr. Mitchell, ballet’s “godfather of diversity.”
lead_paragraph: Arthur Mitchell broke the color barrier in ballet — twice. He was the first African-American principal dancer at New York City Ballet and the founder of the first major black classical company in America, Dance Theater of Harlem. His roles in George Balanchine’s “Agon” and as Puck in “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” both choreographed specifically for him, earned him a place in ballet history.

headline: Walmart Pulls Soviet-Themed Shirts After Lithuania Objects
keywords: ['T-Shirts (Apparel)', 'Politics and Government', 'International Relations', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The removal of the hammer and sickle T-shirts sold online has ignited a war of words between Russia and the former Soviet republic.
lead_paragraph: Lithuanians have little fondness for Russia. Memories of decades of brutality linger, even more than a quarter century after the fall of the Soviet Union.

headline: On Politics With Lisa Lerer: A Moment for Women
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: Taking stock of the rise of women in politics, and some context around the Kavanaugh confirmation hearings.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: A Year After Mexico Earthquake, Parents Demand Justice
abstract: Twenty-six students and teachers died at the Enrique Rébsamen school during an earthquake. An investigation suggests negligence was partly to blame.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Just five days before a powerful earthquake struck last year, a history teacher at a Mexico City school gave a lecture about the capital’s propensity for this sort of natural disaster.

headline: Overlooked No More: Ana Mendieta, a Cuban Artist Who Pushed Boundaries
abstract: Mendieta’s art, sometimes violent, often unapologetically feminist and usually raw, left an indelible mark before her life was cut short.
lead_paragraph: Since 1851, obituaries in The New York Times have been dominated by white men. With Overlooked, we’re adding the stories of remarkable people whose deaths went unreported in The Times.

headline: Micheline Rozan, a Force Behind a Theater Master, Dies at 89
abstract: She helped the famed director Peter Brook start an influential theater group in Paris and mount major productions like “The Mahabharata.”
lead_paragraph: Micheline Rozan, a behind-the-scenes force who helped the director Peter Brook found the renowned International Center for Theater Research in Paris and produced many of its trailblazing productions, died on Sept. 7 in Paris. She was 89.

headline: For Christine Blasey Ford, a Drastic Turn From a Quiet Life in Academia
abstract: Dr. Blasey, a researcher and statistician, was reluctant to come forward with her allegation that Brett Kavanaugh, President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee, sexually assaulted her.
lead_paragraph: The text message from Christine Blasey Ford this summer worried her college best friend, Catherine Piwowarski.

headline: ‘Still Like Beer’: Examining Kavanaugh’s Comments on Drinking
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Alcohol Abuse']
abstract: As Judge Brett Kavanaugh faces an F.B.I. investigation into the sexual assault accusations against him, his remarks about drinking have come under scrutiny. Here’s what he has said.
lead_paragraph: As Judge Brett Kavanaugh faces an F.B.I. investigation into the sexual assault accusations against him, his remarks about drinking have come under scrutiny. Here’s what he has said.

headline: Anti-Semitic Mailer Dogs Cuomo, Even After Big Victory
abstract: Controversy continues to swirl over a campaign flier that falsely linked Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s opponent, Cynthia Nixon, to anti-Semitism.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo might have assumed that his big win in last week’s Democratic primary would end talk about the last-minute piece of campaign mail that falsely suggested his opponent, Cynthia Nixon, was ambivalent about anti-Semitism.

headline: Why Sexual Assault Memories Stick
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Memory', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Christine Blasey Ford says she has a vivid memory of an attack that took place when she was 15. That makes sense.
lead_paragraph: As a psychiatrist I know something about how memory works. Neuroscience research tells us that memories formed under the influence of intense emotion — such as the feelings that accompany a sexual assault — are indelible in the way that memories of a routine day are not.

headline: The Most Fun (and Useful) Things You Can Do With an Amazon Echo or Google Home
keywords: ['Home Automation and Smart Homes', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Smart home devices will tell you the weather and answer trivia questions, sure, but they can do so much more. Try these tips to streamline your day, relax a little or just have some fun.
lead_paragraph: If you’re an Amazon Echo or Google Home owner, you may only ask your device for the weather or to play music. That’s O.K., but these devices can do so much more — and they can offer more than a few useful tricks to make you feel as if you’re living in the future.

headline: Where and Why Do People Come Together in Your Community?
abstract: Is there a place in your neighborhood, town or city that is especially welcoming to all kinds of people? Is the world running out of places like this?
lead_paragraph: Is there a place in your neighborhood, town or city that is especially welcoming to all kinds of people? A shared space where people connect and spend meaningful time together? Why do people like to gather there?

headline: Come Together: A Thematic Collection of Times Articles, Essays, Maps and More About Creating Community
abstract: We’ve “come together” with the Little Free Library Action Book Club to suggest pieces from The Times on this theme. Read them alone, or paired with literature.
lead_paragraph: Playing soccer, washing dishes, cramming for a math test, eating soft-serve, in church, on the Internet, during a hurricane or at a roller rink: As this collection of pieces shows, we “come together” with others all the time, in all kinds of ways — even as many worry that our shared public spaces are being neglected, that technology is making us more alone, and that democracy is suffering as a result.

headline: Everyone Deserves Better Than This Senate Spectacle
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Forget the political finger pointing. Christine Blasey Ford’s accusation against Brett Kavanaugh needs to be seriously investigated.
lead_paragraph: Whatever becomes of Brett Kavanaugh’s nomination to the Supreme Court, the Senate Judiciary Committee’s process for considering him has been a mockery from the start — a mockery of lawmakers’ constitutional responsibility and of the ideal that the court should be anything more than a political trophy.

headline: Bill Cosby Case Judge Rejects Defense Motion to Step Down
abstract: Mr. Cosby’s lawyer said the judge should have disclosed a prior conflict with a witness, but the judge said the assertion was “without merit.”
lead_paragraph: The Pennsylvania judge scheduled to sentence Bill Cosby next week declined on Wednesday to step away from the case, saying that a defense motion stating he had feuded with a key witness and should recuse himself came too late and was “wholly without merit.”

headline: They Were Seeking Mental Health Care. Instead They Drowned in a Sheriff’s Van.
abstract: After two women voluntarily went to hospitals seeking care, they were committed and transported in a sheriff’s van that drove onto a flooded road.
lead_paragraph: MULLINS, S.C. — Nicolette Green had decided to get better. The medication she was taking to treat her schizophrenia had calmed her and cleared her head. On Tuesday morning, her oldest daughter, Rose, with whom she had spent the weekend waiting out Hurricane Florence, drove her to her regular counseling session.

headline: Marceline Loridan-Ivens, 90, Dies; Wrote of Holocaust’s Enduring Toll
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: An author and filmmaker, she examined the long-term anguish of surviving the death camps as a teenager and challenged attitudes about Jews in France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Marceline Loridan-Ivens, a French filmmaker and writer who explored the long-term anguish of surviving Nazi death camps and challenged her compatriots about their attitudes toward Jews, died on Tuesday in Paris. She was 90.

headline: Read These 3 Books on the Terror of Shark Attacks
abstract: On the list: the original “Jaws.”
lead_paragraph: Shark attacks, though rare, loom large in the American imagination. This weekend, those fears were realized when a 26-year-old man was killed in Massachusetts in the first attack in the state since 1936. Here are three books about sharks and their victims.

headline: 500 Women and Teenagers to Be Bailed Out From Rikers by Human Rights Group
keywords: ['Bail', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Discrimination', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights will spend up to $5 million as part of an effort to highlight the racial and economic disparities of the bail system.
lead_paragraph: More than 500 women and teenagers will be bailed out from Rikers Island as part of a national campaign to dismantle a bail system that activists say discriminates against minorities and the poor.

headline: Alex Cora Has a Blueprint for the Season’s Final Weeks
abstract: Boston’s manager learned a few things about winning a World Series as a bench coach for the Astros last year. Those lessons may come in handy for the Red Sox.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Red Sox have soared through their first season under Manager Alex Cora, rolling into September with the best record in baseball. But as the postseason approaches, it brings a fresh puzzle for the rookie manager.

headline: Of Time, Tides and Trump
keywords: ['Hurricane Florence (2018)', 'Floods', 'Global Warming', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The ocean is rising, but at least we’ve got hot dogs.
lead_paragraph: O.K., I know you’re obsessed about sex and the Supreme Court. But the hurricane flooding in North Carolina has been terrible. Let’s give it some serious thought right now.

headline: What’s at Stake in Fight for Subway Fare-Beating Data
abstract: A lawsuit demands that the Police Department release robust information on fare-evasion arrests, which a councilman says will show “unjustifiable racial disparities” in enforcement.
lead_paragraph: Almost every New Yorker has seen someone hopping a subway turnstile — or done it themselves.

headline: Once ‘99 Percent Against Trump,’ Dean Heller Calls Him ‘Great Leader’
abstract: The Nevada senator, the most endangered Senate Republican up for re-election in November, was unusually effusive in praising the president ahead of Mr. Trump’s rally in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: Senator Dean Heller on Wednesday called President Trump “a great leader” who had revived Nevada’s economy, a striking departure from the arm’s-length approach Mr. Heller took with Mr. Trump in the 2016 campaign and in the first months of his presidency.

headline: The Liberalism of the Religious Right
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Christians and Christianity', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Conservatives who attend church have more moderate views than secular conservatives on issues like race, immigration and identity.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has been a regular speaker at recent Values Voter Summits, and for this year’s event, he will send Vice President Mike Pence to rally the religious right. This will not surprise many people on the left who have questioned the authenticity of social conservatives’ values and their place in the Trump-Pence coalition. They think the religious right has compromised its Christian values in order to attain political power for Republicans.

headline: Review: In ‘The Revolving Cycles,’ What Happened to Terrell?
abstract: A woman hunts for her former foster brother. Was he, like so many young black men, a victim of drugs or police or violence? Or did he just disappear?
lead_paragraph: The short, grim lives of young black men in violent cities are all the rage onstage right now — and I do mean rage. “Pass Over,” “Until the Flood,” “Kill Move Paradise” and “Scraps” (still running at the Flea Theater) are just four recent plays among many that channel the fury of places like Chicago and Ferguson and Cleveland into drama.

headline: When We Are Dancing and You’re Dangerously Near Me
abstract: Sam Ezersky weaves a puzzle that is not for those who are rigid.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I know what you’re thinking. You’re thinking, Deb, it’s hard enough to keep the puzzle theme straight on a Thursday, much less when it wanders all over the place.

headline: Trump Picks Expert on Regulation for Federal Reserve Board
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Economy', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Nellie Liang, nominated on Wednesday to the Fed’s board of governors, is an economist who previously led the Fed’s division focused on monitoring financial stability.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump nominated Nellie Liang, a longtime Federal Reserve staff member who is an expert on financial regulation, on Wednesday to join the Fed’s board of governors.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Crime and Racial Strife Didn’t Stop His Teams. Will a Locked School Door?
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 20, 2018.

headline: The Kavanaugh Charade

abstract: What are Republicans hiding about him? What don’t they want you to know?
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump and Senate Republicans have no interest whatsoever in revealing the whole truth about Brett Kavanaugh.

headline: Luis Severino Stifles Red Sox and Makes His Wild-Card Case
abstract: The Yankees will most likely have to decide who will start in a one-game wild-card playoff, and Severino helped his standing with a strong outing.
lead_paragraph: When the Yankees shuffled their starting rotation to line up their three best pitchers — J.A. Happ, Luis Severino and Masahiro Tanaka — to face the Boston Red Sox, it was with the intent of trying to catch up to their rivals.

headline: M.L.B. Playoff Races: Brewers Take Care of Business
abstract: Milwaukee’s win combined with a Cardinals loss gave the Brewers some cushion in the race for the N.L. wild-card.
lead_paragraph: With less than two weeks remaining in the regular season, 12 teams entered Wednesday’s games within five games of the 10 playoff spots. The Boston Red Sox once again failed to clinch the A.L. East,  the St. Louis Cardinals’  three-game winning streak ended, and the Los Angeles Dodgers won on a Yasiel Puig home run.

headline: Inside Italy’s Shadow Economy
keywords: ['Luxury Goods and Services', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Within a distressed labor market, thousands of low-paid home workers create luxury garments without contracts or insurance.
lead_paragraph: BARI PROVINCE, Italy — In a second-floor apartment in the southern Italian town of Santeramo in Colle, a middle-aged woman sat in a black-padded chair this summer, hard at work at her kitchen table. She stitched carefully at a sophisticated woolen coat, the sort of style that will sell for 800 to 2,000 euros ($935 to $2,340) when it arrives in stores this month as part of the fall and winter collection of MaxMara, the Italian luxury fashion brand.

headline: Household Chores
abstract: Do you think children should help out around the house?
lead_paragraph: Do you think children should do household chores? Or should their time and energy go toward school and extracurricular activities? Why do you think the way you do?

headline: Women Are Increasingly Doubtful That Voters Are Ready to Elect Them

headline: ‘Suicider!’ Came the Warning. For Afghans, Wrestlers’ Deaths Resound.
abstract: The Islamic State killed as many as 30 Afghan wrestlers in a suicide bombing at their gym. The survivors blame the government, too. Now they are rebuilding.
