headline: Playing Golf Alongside Tiger Woods Feels Different Now
abstract: Since his comeback, there has been a slight yet perceptible change in the way Woods, 42, deals with other golfers who play in his groups. That may have on effect on the U.S. Ryder Cup team.
lead_paragraph: SAINT-QUENTIN-EN-YVELINES, France — Bryson DeChambeau began chirping in Tiger Woods’s ear as soon as they walked off the first tee box. It was the third round of the Dell Technologies Championship this month at the TPC Boston and the first time the two had been paired in a tournament. Woods, his stony mask in place, said nothing at first.

headline: What Role Does Instagram Play in Your Life?
abstract: How do you tend to use the app? Has your relationship with it changed over time?
lead_paragraph: As you may have read, Instagram’s co-founders resigned on Monday. Are you on the app? If so, how do you tend to use it? If not, why not?

headline: Novels That Tackle Sexual Assault
abstract: From “Lolita” to “The Luckiest Girl Alive.”
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Christine Blasey Ford, who has accused Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh of sexually assaulting her when they were teenagers, is scheduled to testify before Congress to address the allegations. Since she went public, two more women have come forward with stories of inappropriate behavior by the judge. Stories like theirs have often been explored in literature; here are 14 books that deal with rape and sexual assault.

headline: Bradley Cooper Is Not Really Into This Profile
abstract: In “A Star Is Born,” his directorial debut, Mr. Cooper wrangles with the celebrity industrial complex. So you can imagine how this interview went.
lead_paragraph: Bradley Cooper is not not happy to be on the press tour for “A Star Is Born,” the movie he specifically, exactingly, meticulously, perfectionistically, obsessively directed, co-wrote and stars in. In fact, he’s very not not happy! He worked so hard on this movie. Every detail of it comes from a true thing — something he’s learned, something he’s seen, something he knows for sure. It’s such hard work to try for something true and to get it right, and maybe he’s succeeded.

headline: Learning With: ‘Biased News Media or Biased Readers? An Experiment on Trust’
abstract: What are the biggest challenges that remain in confronting the problem of media bias?
lead_paragraph: Before reading the article:

headline: Poem: Fourteen
abstract: Selected by Rita Dove.
lead_paragraph: Threaded through Laura Swearingen-Steadwell’s collection “All Blue So Late” is a clutch of poems bearing the same title and number of lines: Fourteen. It’s both a nod to the sonnet and to the age of her female protagonist, a biracial “nerd-jock” struggling to fit in as she navigates the bewildering flux of adolescence. This poem deftly volleys between acceptance on the soccer field, where “brown is/an international color,” and anger provoked by racial and sexual slurs encountered in the everyday adult world. Selected by Rita Dove

headline: Judge John Hodgman on What Constitutes a Meal
abstract: Do cheese and crackers count? What about if you add pickles?
lead_paragraph: Brad writes: My wife, Kristena, says her favorite meal is meat, cheese and pickles on a cracker. I believe that is a snack, not a meal. When asked if she would like a special birthday dinner consisting of only that, she said yes! She even claims that this snack becomes a sandwich if another cracker is placed on top. Please bring justice before my wife’s delusions get worse.

headline: Review: In ‘Monsters and Men,’ Racism Disrupts a Neighborhood
abstract: Reinaldo Marcus Green’s ambitious debut feature follows the ripples from a police shooting.
lead_paragraph: The words “black lives matter” are never actually spoken in “Monsters and Men,” but they inform every scene of this ambitious debut feature from the writer and director Reinaldo Marcus Green.

headline: New Sentences: From ‘The New Rules of Coffee’
abstract: Humans will always find a way to overcomplicate even the simplest things.
lead_paragraph: — From “The New Rules of Coffee” (Ten Speed Press 2018, Page 109), by Jordan Michelman and Zachary Carlsen, founders of a coffee-focused media network called Sprudge.

headline: Photographing Past Stereotype
abstract: The evolution of the photographer Cristina De Middel maps the complex process of shedding clichés.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, the Spanish-Belgian photographer Cristina De Middel posed herself an obvious but underasked question. In most photographic projects about sex work, it is the faces and bodies of women we see: their strength, weakness, courage and suffering. Where are the men? De Middel wanted to interview men who had paid for sex and photograph them in the kinds of hotel rooms to which they would take female sex workers. So she put an ad in Extra and O Dia, two local newspapers in Rio de Janeiro. She was astonished by the volume of response: More than 100 men showed interest.

headline: Deborah Eisenberg, Chronicler of American Insanity
abstract: Over three decades of short fiction, the writer has managed to capture, with hilarious tenderness, the dysfunction of daily life in this country.
lead_paragraph: It takes Deborah Eisenberg about a year to write a short story. She works at a desk overlooking the gently curving stairwell in her spacious, light-soaked Chelsea apartment. A small painting of a brick wall, suspended from the high ceiling by two slender cables, hangs at eye level in front of the desk, a sardonic reminder of the nature of her task. For Eisenberg, coming up against a brick wall is what writing often feels like. At 72, she has been conducting her siege on the ineffable for more than four decades, and yet the creative process remains almost totally opaque to her. “You work and you work and you work and you work,” she told me recently, her delicate, quavering voice an audible testament to the endless hours of labor. “And for months or years on end, you’re just a total dray horse, and then you finally finish something, and the next day you look at it and you think, How did that get there? What is that? Why were those the things that I seemed to need to say?”

headline: Readers Respond to the 9.16.18 Issue
abstract: Here’s what they had to say about Maya Rudolph, and American workers being shut out of the profits they help generate.
lead_paragraph: RE: MAYA RUDOLPH’S TRANSCENDENT COMEDY

headline: What We’ve Learned About Undecided Voters Heading Into the Midterms
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Our polling suggests they could help Democrats in the Sun Belt and Republicans in the North.
lead_paragraph: We don’t tend to talk much about undecided voters in political analysis. Sometimes, you can gloss over them altogether by referring to a candidate’s polling lead, such as “Dems plus-5.”

headline: 36 Hours in Montreal
abstract: Canada’s second-largest city has an atmospheric Old Town that everyone flocks to, but there are also outlying neighborhoods to explore, along with natural wine bars, street art and pop-up markets.
lead_paragraph: Its cobblestone streets and French architecture make Old Montreal, the original settlement on the St. Lawrence Seaway, compelling. But the second largest city in Canada, now 376 years old, also has much to offer in its surrounding neighborhoods. From the new restaurants of Gay Village to the annually updated murals of the Plateau and the trendy shopping of Mile End, the city’s districts make a strong case for buying a subway pass. Street festivals, outdoor performances, pop-up markets: Montreal so likes to mingle that even tourism boosters call it “the smoking and drinking section of Canada.” Come for the innovative food and drink — namely, the recently opened natural wine bars, speakeasies and restaurants serving Quebecois small plates — and stay for the culture, especially the new mural tours, digital light shows and symphonic experiments.

headline: ‘Ohio’ as the Locus of 21st-Century Rust Belt Despair
abstract: In Stephen Markley’s debut novel, former classmates reunite to witness the toll contemporary American realities have taken on them all.
lead_paragraph: OHIO By Stephen Markley 484 pp. Simon & Schuster. $27

headline: How to Actually Eat Like a Local While Traveling
abstract: Everyone says you should follow the lead of locals when traveling, but actual suggestions on how to do that tend to be vague. Here are our tips.
lead_paragraph: When looking for restaurant recommendations at home, we rely on friends, magazines and review sites. Yet when abroad, we fantasize about a mystical “local,” someone who will guide us to the best meal of our lives, preferably somewhere “authentic” and “off the beaten path.” Though we would never expect this of a stranger on the street at home, we expect it abroad from citizens just like us.

headline: Giving Voice to Homer’s Women
abstract: In “The Silence of the Girls,” Pat Barker channels the voices of the women in the “Iliad,” treated as sexual treasure to be raped by conquering warriors.
lead_paragraph: THE SILENCE OF THE GIRLS By Pat Barker 293 pp. Doubleday. $27.95.

headline: America Ferrera: By the Book
abstract: The actor and editor of the new anthology “American Like Me: Reflections on Life Between Cultures” would love to see Harry Potter get the “Game of Thrones” treatment: “I’m here for 80 hours of a darker and more detailed adaptation.”
lead_paragraph: The actor and editor of the new anthology “American Like Me: Reflections on Life Between Cultures” would love to see Harry Potter get the “Game of Thrones” treatment: “I’m here for 80 hours of a darker and more detailed adaptation.”

headline: ‘Our Obligation Is to Give Readers Relevant News’: How and Why We Reported the Rosenstein Scoop
abstract: Times editors answer readers’ questions regarding how we cover sensitive stories, including a recent report on Rod Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general.
lead_paragraph: A New York Times article reporting that Rod J. Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general, had discussed invoking the 25th Amendment to remove President Trump from office and secretly recording him in the Oval Office led to a passionate discussion among our readers about how we handle stories that rely on anonymous sources.

headline: Moving into a Changing Prospect-Lefferts Gardens
abstract: After watching Harlem slip out of their budget, a couple finds a home in a part of Brooklyn that is very new to them.
lead_paragraph: Emmett Murphy arrived in New York nearly 30 years ago, and spent much of that time living with roommates. Six years ago, he rented a two-bedroom in a modern Harlem building with his partner, Robert Balaguer.

headline: Five Places to Go in San José, Costa Rica
abstract: The city center of San José has transformed into the capital’s premier cultural and restaurant zone.
lead_paragraph: In the last few years, the urban core of San José has undergone a revival. For decades, the city center has felt a bit abandoned and sometimes seedy as well-heeled locals gravitated toward modern suburbs like Escazú and Santa Ana, home to American-style malls and restaurant chains. But lately, expatriates and Costa Ricans have returned home after years abroad, infusing fresh life into neglected 19th-century buildings and old houses in the city center. These recent arrivals have opened creative businesses, including design shops and hostels with co-working spaces, turning a few adjoining neighborhoods east of the Parque Central into the city’s premier cultural and restaurant zone.

headline: Updates From the Riveting Testimonies of Christine Blasey Ford and Brett Kavanaugh
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: They took turns before the Senate Judiciary Committee, moving from sad certitude to angry umbrage.
lead_paragraph: • Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee, came out swinging in the early moments of his testimony to senators, saying, “This confirmation process has become a national disgrace.”

headline: Male, Female or ‘X’: The Push for a Third Choice on Official Forms
abstract: New York City is the latest place to offer gender-neutral birth certificates. But after someone changes the sex to “X,” things get complicated.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Arrowood does not identify as male or female. So in January, when a new New York City law takes effect, they plan to modify the sex recorded on their birth certificate to one that fits: “X,” a gender-neutral option.

lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Chinatown, Midtown and Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn

headline: Samantha Bee Slams Kavanaugh’s Defenders
abstract: Bee pushed back against the argument made by some Republicans that rejecting Judge Brett Kavanaugh from the Supreme Court would ruin his life.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: In KFC’s China Ads, Nuggets Are Served With Patriotism
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government', 'Fast Food Industry']
abstract: The fast food chain’s campaign celebrates the country’s four-decade rise from rural poverty to the world’s second-largest economy.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China began an audacious experiment four decades ago to inject free-market thinking into its rigid, Communist-controlled political system, beginning a process that would lift hundreds of millions of people out of poverty and create the world’s second-largest economy.

headline: Former N.F.L. Cheerleaders Hope to Quicken Change by Shedding Their Anonymity
keywords: ['Cheerleaders', 'Football', 'Women and Girls', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', '#MeToo Movement']
abstract: Rebecca Cummings and Allison Cassidy were among five former Washington Redskins cheerleaders whose accounts of harassment on the job led to change. But, they say, not enough.
lead_paragraph: Some of their former teammates publicly called them liars and traitors and attention-seekers who disrespected every woman who had ever worn the Washington Redskins cheerleading uniform.

headline: Brett Kavanaugh, China, Octopus: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: This Hearing Is Stacked Against Christine Blasey Ford
abstract: It is almost unthinkable that there will be a second Supreme Court justice taking his seat under suspicions of perjury and sexual misconduct.
lead_paragraph: There is a reason Thursday’s Senate Judiciary Committee hearing will be short and feature only two witnesses, the Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett Kavanaugh and his accuser Christine Blasey Ford. Republicans have designed the hearing to end in a “he said, she said” stalemate. No matter how credible Dr. Blasey is, isolating her as a lone accuser is the most effective political strategy for confirming Judge Kavanaugh.

headline: Today’s Hearing: Trial or Job Interview?
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', '#MeToo Movement', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republicans and Democrats are expected to take very different approaches to the questioning of Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh and Dr. Christine Blasey Ford.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Their Relationship Morphed From Dislike to Inseparable
abstract: “We are very devoted to pleasing each other, that’s the secret to our marriage.”
lead_paragraph: Because marriage is an ever-evolving experience, we constantly shift, change and, in some cases, start over. In It’s No Secret, couples share thoughts about commitment and tell us what they have learned along the way.

headline: The Hot Property That’s Next on Tech’s Agenda: Real Estate
keywords: ['Venture Capital', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Start-ups', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Venture capitalists are racing to pour money into technology for real estate — or what Silicon Valley is now calling proptech.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Opendoor, a start-up that flips homes, attracted attention in June when it announced it had raised $325 million from a long list of venture capitalists. The financing valued the four-year-old company at more than $2 billion.

headline: This Revolution, Too, Will Eat Its Children
abstract: What this frenzied national inquest means for our civic culture.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t long ago that Brett Kavanaugh’s nomination to the Supreme Court hinged, as it must, on his qualifications as a judge. Then, necessarily, it became a question of his fitness as a man.

headline: The Messy Reality Inside the Pentagon, Captured in Fiction
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: Kathleen McInnis discusses her new novel, which looks at the Pentagon’s civilian force, its work-life balance and the American national-security system.
lead_paragraph: A conversation with Kathleen McInnis, author of “The Heart of War: Misadventures in the Pentagon” (Post Hill Press, 2018).

headline: Today’s New York News: Honoring Ruth Bader Ginsburg
abstract: Thursday: A petition to rename a building and looking back on a flu pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this nebulous Thursday.

headline: Why I Applaud the Unpopular Mr. Macron
abstract: The French have soured on their wunderkind president. He’s aloof and tone-deaf, it’s said. What else is new?
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French, it seems, have soured on President Emmanuel Macron, the wunderkind who swept to power 16 months ago. His poll numbers have slumped as the gloss on the 40-year-old upstart has faded. The consensus is in: He’s aloof, Jupiter-like, tone-deaf, devoted to coddling the rich.

headline: We Still Haven’t Learned From Anita Hill’s Testimony
abstract: In the great awakening around sexual harassment, race was politely ushered offstage. That problem persists.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-seven years after Anita Hill testified in front of the Senate Judiciary Committee that Clarence Thomas sexually harassed her, and as Christine Blasey Ford prepares to testify that Brett Kavanaugh sexually assaulted her when they were teenagers, we still have not learned our mistakes from that mess in 1991.

headline: Two European Favorites Take to the Paris Stage
abstract: Thomas Ostermeier and Krystian Lupa present works at the city’s major playhouses at the beginning of a new theater season.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On paper, the theater directors Krystian Lupa and Thomas Ostermeier have much in common. They are heavyweights of the European stage: Mr. Ostermeier is the director of the famous Schaubühne theater in Berlin, while Mr. Lupa’s productions have long been revered beyond his native Poland. Both are renowned for their pin-sharp direction of actors as well as their willingness to tackle onstage the rise of extremist forces.

headline: The Infatuation Gets $30 Million Investment From Hollywood Mogul Jeffrey Katzenberg
abstract: The restaurant reviews site, which bought Zagat earlier this year, has won the backing of the media holding company co-founded by Jeffrey Katzenberg.
lead_paragraph: Over nine years, The Infatuation has grown from an upstart restaurant recommendation service to the buyer of the restaurant review company Zagat.

headline: DealBook Briefing: Does Facebook Have Room for More Than One Founder?
abstract: The social network pays big bucks for start-ups. But founders seem uncomfortable with what happens afterward.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday. (Want this by email? Sign up here.)

headline: Japan’s Embrace of Bilateral Trade Talks With U.S. Spares It From Tariffs
abstract: Japan may have given President Trump a chance to declare victory, but in the short term it has escaped damaging tariffs on its auto industry.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — When Japan agreed to enter into bilateral trade talks with the United States during meetings at the United Nations General Assembly on Wednesday, the country’s prime minister, Shinzo Abe, appeared to have finally said “yes” after two years of saying “no.”

headline: Review: ‘Smallfoot’ Struggles to Leave an Impression
abstract: Channing Tatum plays a yeti who prefers the examined life in this animated film.
lead_paragraph: An urgent warning against the comforts of epistemological bubbles, “Smallfoot” is a children’s animated feature set in a village of yetis. The yetis — Bigfoots — live according to strict rituals and laws, codified in stone and preached by a leader called the Stonekeeper (voiced by Common).

headline: Review: In ‘306 Hollywood,’ an Excavation — at Grandma’s House
abstract: This documentary argues that everyone’s life is worth archiving.
lead_paragraph: A family portrait that plunges into what will strike many viewers as T.M.I. territory, the documentary “306 Hollywood” makes for morbid, at times insufferable viewing. But its solipsism is part of its message.

headline: Review: In ‘Free Solo,’ Braving El Capitan With Only Fingers and Toes
abstract: This invigorating portrait of the free climber Alex Honnold presents an engaging study of a perfect match between passion and personality.
lead_paragraph: Showcasing a dedication and prowess that seems superhuman, “Free Solo,” Elizabeth Chai Vasarhelyi and Jimmy Chin’s invigorating portrait of the free climber Alex Honnold, is an easy sell to extreme sports enthusiasts. More sedentary viewers, though — perhaps less focused on the technical niceties of defying gravity — might discover something arguably even more fascinating in this layered documentary: A cautionary study of what can happen when you don’t hug your children.

headline: Review: ‘Black ‘47,’ a Revenge Thriller Set During the Irish Famine
abstract: A quiet soldier turns into a 19th-century killing machine in Lance Daly’s new film.
lead_paragraph: A soldier returns home from a faraway war he didn’t understand, to a country he no longer recognizes. Seeking no more than peace for himself and his loved ones, he is denied. Soon the only family he has left is violently taken from him. He then transforms into an avenging berserker who will stop at nothing to punish the men who have deprived him of all he holds dear.

headline: Review: ‘Bad Reputation’ Argues for Joan Jett’s Importance
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: A new documentary looking at Ms. Jett’s long career — from her all-girl band, the Runaways, in the 1970s to today — casts her as a feminist heroine.
lead_paragraph: Too many people do not think of the rocker Joan Jett as an important artist, and I doubt Ms. Jett thinks of herself quite that way either. “Bad Reputation,” a documentary on her life and work directed by Kevin Kerslake (the title comes from one of Ms. Jett’s hits), convincingly makes the case that she is very much that. And that she is a feminist heroine as well.

headline: U.N. General Assembly: Criticism and Praise for Trump Administration
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: World leaders gathered in New York for the United Nations General Assembly, after two days dominated by President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister of Israel Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and his Palestinian counterpart, President Mahmoud Abbas, both spoke in front of world leaders on Thursday, offering diametrically opposing views on the causes of the protracted Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: Review: ‘Cruise’ Rides Around the ’80s, With Affection
abstract: The movie, directed by Robert Siegel, finds Spencer Boldman chasing Emily Ratajkowski through the 1987 streets of Queens.
lead_paragraph: A nit-picker might say that “Cruise” contains enough clichés for three films. And that its plot has been recycled countless times. And that its characters are only a notch above cardboard cutouts.

headline: Review: In ‘Scaffolding,’ Graduation Is Near. But the Real Lessons Are Ahead.
abstract: A bullheaded 17-year-old is the focus of this coming-of-age film from Israel.
lead_paragraph: The protagonist of “Scaffolding,” an Israeli coming-of-age film, isn’t really ready to come of age — not that he seems to know it.

headline: Review: ‘Matangi/Maya/M.I.A.’ Melds a Rapper’s Music and Activism
abstract: From a childhood in Sri Lanka to an appearance in the Super Bowl halftime show, a new documentary explores M.I.A.’s eventful life and career.
lead_paragraph: It’s hardly unusual for commercially successful pop musicians to engage in political activism. But M.I.A., the 43-year-old electronic-hip-hop artist, seems to get a lot more headaches for her endeavors than many others, at least according to this documentary. Titled “Matangi/Maya/M.I.A.” for, in order, the Hindu god for whom she is named, the diminutive her friends call her and her stage persona, the film is directed by Stephen Loveridge, her longtime friend.

headline: Chloé: Spring 2019
abstract: Chloé 2019 Collection.
lead_paragraph: Chloé 2019 Collection.

headline: A Connecticut Woman Was Killed While Jogging. A Confession Came Four Years Later.
abstract: A woman was murdered in Simsbury, Conn., in 2014. It was a cold case until last week, when a man confessed to stabbing her once, and then fleeing.
lead_paragraph: The killing of Melissa Millan in 2014 shocked the town of Simsbury, Conn. An insurance executive and mother of two, Ms. Millan, 54, was stabbed while jogging and was found bloodied on a boulevard.

headline: Teaching English as a Foreign Language With The New York Times as the Textbook
abstract: A tutor in Beijing suggests three ways to develop conversation skills using articles, images and read-alouds.
lead_paragraph: As a private English-language tutor in Beijing, Sarah E. Elia is always searching for ways to get her students excited about conversing in English.

headline: Checking 6 Claims From Trump’s News Conference
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Sexual Harassment', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: President Trump made a host of inaccurate claims during a news conference at the United Nations on Wednesday, including about accusations of sexual misconduct, his share of the women’s vote, trade, judicial nominations and hostages.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Trump said he was accused of sexual misconduct by four or five women “who got paid a lot of money to make up stories about me," and whom he claimed he had never met. He then contradicted himself and said that he “knew them a long time ago. Fifteen years ago, 20 years ago.”

headline: At This Theater, All of the Directors Will Be Women
abstract: Anna Bergmann begins her role as the playhouse director of the Badisches State Theater in Germany with an all-female-directed season.
lead_paragraph: KARLSRUHE, Germany — Pushing a stroller toward the rehearsal space of the Badisches State Theater in Karlsruhe, a pleasant city in southwest Germany, Anna Bergmann stopped to comfort her 2½-year-old son, whose sunny demeanor had suddenly dissolved into heart-rending sobs. Luckily, the prospect of a chase around the fountain soon cheered him up again. “It really puts rehearsal terror in perspective,” said Ms. Bergmann, the theater’s new playhouse director, shaking her head.

headline: Joan Jett: ‘My Lot in Life Is to Battle’
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: After 40-plus years in rock, the singer and guitarist is as fierce and defiant as ever. A new documentary charts her pathbreaking rise.
lead_paragraph: Joan Jett has worked. That’s one message of “Bad Reputation,” a documentary chronicling her 40-plus years in the music business, first as a founder of the Runaways, the seismic teen girl rockers of the ’70s, then as the frontwoman and guitarist for the Blackhearts, her enduring band. Her drive was to keep playing, no matter the consequences; even when women were sidelined, she persevered.

headline: What Readers Want to Ask Kavanaugh
abstract: You told us what questions you’d like to hear the Supreme Court nominee address at his hearing today.
lead_paragraph: In “Questions Brett Kavanaugh Needs to Answer,” The Times Editorial Board recommended  questions for the Senate Judiciary Committee to ask Judge Brett Kavanaugh at a hearing today to address the sexual assault accusations made by Christine Blasey Ford.

headline: Review: In ‘Summer ’03,’ Coming of Age Is More Bitter Than Sweet
abstract: The movie’s meanspirited humor is out of place with the perky conventionality of its film style.
lead_paragraph: When Jamie (Joey King) enters the pivotal summer of her adolescence in the far-off past of sunny 2003, she is a jaded teenager whose fantasies of love and sex have yet to be tested by experience. The death of her grandmother, Dotty (June Squibb), puts weekend keggers and girlish gossip on pause, but unexpectedly for Jamie, Dotty authorizes a teenage rebellion. Her final words of wisdom ring coarse and clear: Abandon your mother’s Judaism, and learn the secrets of oral sex.

headline: Review: Shakespeare + Chekhov = ‘Uncle Romeo Vanya Juliet’
abstract: The Bedlam show, stitched together from parts borrowed from Chekhov and Shakespeare, should perhaps be credited to Chekspeare.
lead_paragraph: In the early 2000s, mash-ups had a cultural moment. Mad studio scientists would combine two (and sometimes more) completely different songs to create a new one. The trend peaked with Danger Mouse’s full-length “The Grey Album,” which fused the Beatles’ White Album with Jay-Z’s “The Black Album.”

headline: Jonathan Saunders Captures a Whirlwind Week in London, in Polaroids
abstract: The Scottish designer returns to the city to launch a collection of rugs, finesse his coming furniture line and visit 10 Downing Street.
lead_paragraph: The Scottish designer Jonathan Saunders has always had a knack for color. At his eponymous women’s wear brand, much mourned since its shuttering in 2016, he dreamed up shades at once dazzling and subtle: deep mineral greens, sunset pinks that teetered on orange, yellows both buttery and acidic. More recently, he created vibrantly printed and color-blocked dresses as the chief creative officer at DVF. Though he left the company last year, Saunders has remained in New York, where he is now focusing on his first love: furniture design.

headline: Review: ‘All About Nina,’ a Funny Lady (With Issues)
abstract: Mary Elizabeth Winstead, who plays a stand-up comic in Eva Vives’s ragged feature debut, is so good that she shows you what the movie could have been.
lead_paragraph: Mary Elizabeth Winstead suckers you right into “All About Nina.” As Nina Geld, a stand-up with an attractively pugnacious persona and a stated preference for hookups, Ms. Winstead makes unruliness into a female virtue, an offensive strategy that is also a good defense. Leading with a sly smile, she easily talks dirty but also lets you see the fissures in Nina’s demonstrative belligerence, making you wonder where real life ends and the act begins. Ms. Winstead is so good that she even shows you the movie that could have been, one without the clichés and therapy talk.

headline: Killer Whales Face Dire PCBs Threat

lead_paragraph: Most people thought the problem of polychlorinated biphenyls — known as PCBs — had been solved. Some countries began banning the toxic chemicals in the 1970s and 1980s, and worldwide production was ended with the 2001 Stockholm Convention.

headline: Hidden Kingdoms of the Ancient Maya Revealed in a 3-D Laser Map
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Mayans', 'Maps', 'Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)']
abstract: Using technology known as lidar, a team of archaeologists found evidence beneath the jungle canopy in Guatemala of how the Mesoamerican civilization altered its landscape.
lead_paragraph: Hidden pyramids and massive fortresses in the jungle. Farms and canals scattered across swamplands. Highways traversing thickets of rain forest. These are among more than 61,000 ancient Mayan structures swallowed by overgrowth in the tropical lowlands of Guatemala that archaeologists have finally uncovered using a laser mapping technology called lidar.

Kavanaugh and his accuser faced off Thursday in an extraordinary, emotional day of testimony that ricocheted from a woman’s tremulous account of sexual assault to a man’s angry, outraged denial, all of which played out for hours before a riveted nation and a riven Senate.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: My relationship with bugs is probably a lot like yours: antagonistic but resigned to an extended leery détente, with occasional hostilities on both sides. The mosquito buzzes; I swat it aside. But insects also exert a queasy fascination — they’re so alien, and so ubiquitous, that they become ideal subjects for scientific study, and for books. In “Underbug,” one of our recommended titles this week, the journalist Lisa Margonelli takes a close look at termites and the entomologists who love them. Bonus for curious but grossed-out readers: The book includes no photos.

headline: Review: An Opera Reaches the American Dream’s Brooding Heart
abstract: “Proving Up,” composed by Missy Mazzoli, with a libretto by Royce Vavrek, is about a settler family struggling for survival on the Nebraska plains.
lead_paragraph: A tense and creepy journey into the heart of Manifest Destiny’s darkness, the opera “Proving Up” instructs us, teeth clenched, that the American dream eludes even — especially — those who give everything to gain it.

headline: Christine Blasey Ford’s Riveting, Persuasive Testimony
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: She was afraid. She was strong. She was human.
lead_paragraph: Christine Blasey Ford didn’t try to play it cool. She didn’t worry about being perfectly composed. When she needed caffeine, she asked for caffeine. When nerves got the better of her, she giggled nervously. She smiled at odd times, the way all of us smile at odd times.

abstract: The United Nations body is trying to expedite criminal prosecutions of Myanmar military leaders over a brutal campaign against Rohingya Muslims.

headline: E.P.A. to Eliminate Office That Advises Agency Chief on Science
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It's the latest step by the Trump administration that appears to diminish the role of scientific research in policymaking.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency plans to dissolve its Office of the Science Advisor, a senior post that was created to counsel the E.P.A. administrator on the scientific research underpinning health and environmental regulations, according to a person familiar with the agency’s plans. The person spoke anonymously because the decision had not yet been made public.

headline: Hedi Slimane’s Friends and Collaborators Remember His Breakout Show
abstract: Ahead of the designer’s Celine debut, his inner circle reflects on how his first collection for Dior Homme forever changed men’s fashion.
lead_paragraph: On January 28, 2001, a rising Tunisian-Italian designer named Hedi Slimane showed his first collection for Dior Homme. Staged at the Galerie de Botanique in the Jardin des Plantes in Paris, the event effectively rebranded the fashion houses’s men’s line, and caused a seismic shift in the typically staid world of men’s fashion. At a time when baggy tailoring was the prevailing aesthetic in men’s wear, a relative newcomer made a case for a precisely crafted razor-slim silhouette. The Times’s fashion critic at the time, Cathy Horyn, singled it out as “the most anticipated show of the fall 2001 men’s season.” Tomorrow, some 17 years later, Slimane will make another buzzy debut, unveiling his first collection for Celine as the French brand’s artistic, creative and image director, a role created specifically for him. Since his arrival at Celine in January — where he took over from Phoebe Philo, who announced her departure last year — Slimane has been remaking the house in his own image. When the brand introduces men’s wear for the first time this season, with couture to follow next January, Slimane will showcase not only his sprawling powers of imagination but also what he is capable of when starting from a blank slate.

headline: Public Service Debt Relief Is Broken
abstract: The program that’s supposed to help teachers and others with their loans isn’t working.
lead_paragraph: This summer, student debt reached a record $1.5 trillion in the United States. To put that in perspective, student loan borrowers in this country are carrying debt equal to Russia’s gross domestic product in 2017. Over half say it’s preventing them from saving for retirement or for an emergency; more than 10 percent of borrowers are in default because they can’t pay their minimum balance.

headline: A Nation Transfixed by the Kavanaugh Drama

headline: Our N.F.L. Week 4 Picks Against the Spread
abstract: The Dolphins are underdogs despite an undefeated start, Baker Mayfield tries to get the Browns on a winning streak, and Khalil Mack tries to end FitzMagic.
lead_paragraph: With the Rams and Vikings facing each other on Thursday night, and the Chiefs not playing until Monday, Sunday will have an excitement deficit that the N.F.L. has avoided so far this season. The Dolphins will be the lone undefeated team in action on the league’s main day of action, though there should be plenty of reason to tune in to other games, with Baker Mayfield making his first start, Carson Wentz trying to go 2-0 and Ryan Fitzpatrick trying to rekindle FitzMagic while running away from Khalil Mack.

headline: Film Club: ‘Dulce’
abstract: A mother guides her daughter through a rite of passage in their small Colombian village — learning to swim.
lead_paragraph: “Dulce” is a 10-minute film that touches on themes of growing up and the interdependence of people and nature. It profiles Dulce, an 8-year-old girl, as her mother guides her through a rite of passage in her small Colombian village — learning to swim.

headline: ‘Hang the Whites,’ French Rapper Declares. Now He May Face Jail.
keywords: ['Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Few had heard of Nick Conrad, a rapper from a Paris suburb. Then his music video started making the rounds, outraging French lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A little-known French rapper’s violent music video that intones “hang the whites” amid calls for killing “the white babies” has created a small uproar in France, with politicians rushing to condemn it, anti-racism groups denouncing it and the Paris prosecutor’s office opening an investigation.

headline: Mark Judge Says He’ll Talk to the F.B.I. Here’s What We Know About Him.
abstract: Two women have identified Mr. Judge, a high school friend of Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, as a key witness to sexual misconduct decades ago.
lead_paragraph: Mark Judge, who has been named by two women as being a key witness to sexual misconduct by Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, said Friday that he would cooperate with any law enforcement agency “assigned to confidentially investigate” the accusations.

keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a lawsuit Thursday that accused Mr. Musk, the electric-car manufacturer’s chief executive, of making false and misleading public statements.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, Tesla’s chief executive, was accused by federal regulators on Thursday of misleading investors with false public statements, a move that could force him out of the company’s leadership.

headline: At 7 Art Galleries, the Ecstatic Flow of Paint and the Stories It Can Tell
abstract: Seven new exhibitions show us the many ways that liquidity figures in the postwar history of painting.
lead_paragraph: Few truths about paint are more basic than this: it tends to go on wet, whether on canvas, furniture or buildings, and then it dries. Once dried, it can preserve a sense of its original fluidity to greatly varying degrees. In the postwar years it became a sure sign of modernity and freshness. It’s dynamic, at times volcanic, like artistic genius is supposed to be, but it can also have a comedic, even ironic quality. It conveys immediacy, material reality, improvisation as well as flamboyance and glamour, savoir faire.

headline: David Wong Louie, Who Probed Ethnic Identity in Fiction, Dies at 63
abstract: In a writing career hampered by illness, Mr. Louie created acclaimed stories that drew on his experiences as an American son of Chinese immigrants.
lead_paragraph: David Wong Louie, an American writer who drew on his experiences as the son of Chinese immigrants to create stories that explored identity, alienation and acceptance, died on Sept. 19 at his home in Venice, Calif. He was 63.

headline: New York’s Forgotten Waterways
abstract: Some of New York’s scenic byways are navigable only by canoe. But if you’re willing to brave the ticks, poison ivy and potential teenage make-out spots, the vistas are something else.
lead_paragraph: New York likes to think of itself as a city of skyscrapers and mighty avenues, but at another level it’s really just a sloshing ground for muskrats and local waterfowl. Nathan Kensinger discovered how watery the city is when he started photographing New York’s hidden landscapes.

headline: Same Burgers, Glitzier Restaurant
abstract: Burger Heaven, a family business in Midtown since 1943, went through a name change and a renovation, but customers are loyal and the sandwiches remain the same.
lead_paragraph: The weekday lunch scene at Burger Heaven Kitchen & Bar was a crowded affair. Remixes by David Guetta, a French D.J., played while diners chatted throughout the modern-meets-mod, bi-level space, located on 49th Street, between Madison and Fifth Avenues.

headline: The Urbanist Guide to Wild Apples
abstract: The orchards of New York City are long gone, but there are plenty of apple trees, provided you’re not looking for Red Delicious.
lead_paragraph: It’s about that time: New Yorkers will be spending the next several weekends heading to orchards upstate for the increasingly overcrowded ritual of apple picking.

headline: What to Read Before Heading to Movie Theaters This Fall
abstract: Of the various book-to-film adaptations, these eight titles — including “If Beale Street Could Talk,” “The Sisters Brothers” and “The Hate U Give” — are worth reading before you watch.
lead_paragraph: Of the year’s non-franchise, non-superhero films, some of the most popular have been adapted from books, including “A Wrinkle in Time,” “Crazy Rich Asians” and the Netflix teenage romance “To All the Boys I’ve Loved Before.” One of the latest, “Bel Canto,” based on Ann Patchett’s novel and starring Julianne Moore and Ken Watanabe, was released on Sept. 14. Books, replete with emotional depth and rich character development, are ripe for onscreen interpretation, even if, for some readers, the end result isn’t always as rich in the visual telling. This fall brings a new batch of adaptations for readers to anticipate. Here are eight titles worth reading before you watch.

headline: New York’s Next Nickname: The Big Sponge?
abstract: The city is partnering with Copenhagen to plan open spaces that can absorb or store rainwater from intense storms.
lead_paragraph: New York City has its nicknames: the Empire City, Fun City, the city that never sleeps. Now, because of a partnership between New York and Copenhagen, another might join the list: Sponge City.

headline: 2-Second Rule for Distracted Driving Can Mean Life or Death
keywords: ['Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: While people will always find a way to distract themselves, the industry is dreaming up new ways to keep drivers’ eyes on the road.
lead_paragraph: The large rubber strip that I was speeding toward on the Ventura Freeway near Los Angeles looked easy enough to avoid. I swerved, but not enough.

headline: Finding Common Ground at El Museo del Barrio
abstract: Two shows attempt to bridge the rift in a museum’s mission: to honor its Barrio roots — and reach a global audience.
lead_paragraph: Location, location, location. In real estate, place determines value. Sometimes it can for art too. El Museo  del Barrio originated in 1969 in classrooms, storefronts and a repurposed fire station in what was then the predominantly Puerto Rican neighborhood of East Harlem. The museum was a product of pride and necessity. In local public schools, young artist-activists, often working free, taught children the virtues of cultural self-expression and communal self-sufficiency. And they taught from experience. At the time, no mainstream art institution in the city would show their art. They needed a museum of their own and, collectively, they created one.

headline: Kavanaugh Hearings on TV Offer Riveting Drama to a Captive Nation
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The coverage of the testimony of Christine Blasey Ford and Brett Kavanaugh reflected a nation bitterly divided, but also produced a rare collective civic moment.
lead_paragraph: The Senate testimony of Christine Blasey Ford and Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh unspooled over nearly nine hours on Thursday — about the length of a prestige mini-series, binged Netflix-style in one wrenching, riveting sitting.

headline: GoFundMe Campaign for Christine Blasey Ford Takes Off After Testimony
abstract: In the hours after Dr. Blasey mentioned that GoFundMe campaigns had been created on her behalf, one campaign drew more than $200,000.
lead_paragraph: A GoFundMe campaign set up on behalf of Christine Blasey Ford drew more than $200,000 in donations in the hours immediately after she mentioned it during her  testimony to the Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday, more money than it had gained in the past eight days.

headline: ‘As a Rape Survivor, I Was Shaking in My Chair’ as Christine Blasey Ford Testified
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Anxiety and Stress']
abstract: Readers tell us how their experiences with sexual assault and trauma affected their viewing of the Kavanaugh hearing during which Dr. Blasey testified.
lead_paragraph: As Christine Blasey Ford testified Thursday before the Senate Judiciary Committee, laying bare the details of the sexual assault she accuses Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh of committing against her, Americans gathered in conference rooms, on couches, in airport terminals and at diners to watch. Among them were many for whom Dr. Blasey’s testimony evoked memories of their own experiences with sexual trauma.

headline: Caffeine May Increase Pain Tolerance
abstract: A plant-based diet may also help you withstand pain.
lead_paragraph: Consuming caffeine regularly may increase the ability to withstand pain, a small study suggests.

headline: Many Changes in the Ryder Cup Over 25 Years, and the Americans Seek One More
abstract: Not since 1993 has the United States beaten the European team on its home soil.
lead_paragraph: ST.-QUENTIN-EN-YVELINES, France — The last time the United States won a Ryder Cup on the road, Davis Love III was a fresh-faced American rookie instead of a savvy two-time captain, and Ian Poulter, the future leader of the European team, was a teenage fan spending his nights in a tent.

lead_paragraph: In this week’s issue, the New York Times staff book critics discuss the history, meaning and limits of the Nobel Prize in Literature. Below is a 1923 review by Ernesto Montenegro of “Desolación,” by Gabriela Mistral, the first Latin American to win the award.

headline: Republicans Take the Hypocrite’s Oath
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: On health care, a determination to deceive voters as much as possible.
lead_paragraph: On graduation, most medical students swear some version of the ancient Hippocratic oath — a promise to act morally in their role as physicians. Human nature being what it is, some will break their promise. But we still expect those who provide health care to behave more ethically than the average member of society.

headline: Expecting Women to Describe How Sexual Assault Affected Them Creates Barriers to Reporting It
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Women and Girls', 'Research', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: The idea that one needs to articulate the personal effects of sexual assault as clearly as Christine Blasey Ford keeps many victims from reporting what happened to them.
lead_paragraph: “Can you tell us what impact the events had on you?” Senator Dianne Feinstein asked Christine Blasey Ford during Thursday’s Senate Judiciary Committee hearing.

headline: Art Dealer Sentenced to 18 Months in Prison for Fraud
abstract: Ezra Chowaiki sold artwork without his clients’ permission and misused money that had been designated for making purchases for them.
lead_paragraph: Ezra Chowaiki was sentenced Thursday in federal court in Manhattan to 18 months in prison and three years of supervised release for defrauding art dealers and collectors of millions of dollars. He was also ordered to give up his interest in more than 20 works of art involved in the fraud, including pieces by Picasso and Alexander Calder.

headline: Doing Right by Sick 9/11 Workers
keywords: ['Paid Time Off', 'September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Employee Fringe Benefits']
abstract: Efforts to give paid sick leave to government workers who have had 9/11-related illnesses are incomplete.
lead_paragraph: Government officials can face difficult decisions. Here’s one that isn’t: choosing to give unlimited paid sick leave to public workers made ill by their service after the Sept. 11 attacks.

keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']

headline: 28,000 Public Servants Sought Student Loan Forgiveness. 96 Got It.
abstract: The Education Department has significantly mismanaged a debt relief program for public workers, according to a government audit.
lead_paragraph: A program intended to wipe away the student loans of qualifying public servants has rejected more than 99 percent of those who applied, according to a government audit that found that “fragmented” management and “piecemeal” operating instructions had contributed to the failure to forgive more debt.

headline: Israeli Leader Claims Iran Has ‘Secret Atomic Warehouse’
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Benjamin Netanyahu said intelligence agents had found the facility in Tehran, setting up a challenge to Iran to prove it’s not violating the nuclear deal.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told the United Nations on Thursday that his intelligence agents had discovered a “secret atomic warehouse” in downtown Tehran, escalating a growing confrontation with Iran and setting up a direct challenge to its government to open the facility to inspectors and prove it is not in violation of the 2015 nuclear deal.

headline: On Politics With Lisa Lerer: He Litigated. She Persuaded.
abstract: Two witnesses, two wildly different styles; a visit to a smaller protest; and how the hearings played on TV.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Meet the Woman in Charge of Building the Best-Selling Pickup Truck in America
abstract: Responsible for overseeing a Ford F-150 plant that she calls “a little city,” Debbie Manzano holds the rare status of being a woman at the helm of a major American production facility.
lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — Straight out of college, statistics degree in hand, Debbie Manzano started working for Ford keeping an eye on the glass production process at the company’s massive Rouge complex in Michigan.

headline: Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson Look to Conquer Their Joint Jinx
abstract: For all their experience in the Ryder Cup, neither has sampled victory in the tournament when it is held in Europe. Now comes another chance, starting Friday.
lead_paragraph: SAINT-QUENTIN-EN-YVELINES, France — Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson have combined for 123 PGA Tour victories and 19 major championships. They are regulars in Forbes’s list of highest-grossing athletes, with followings that could rival those of a boy band. But for all their acclaim and accomplishments, their careers contain an Atlantic Ocean-sized gap: Neither has been part of a winning Ryder Cup team on foreign soil.

headline: Furious Lindsey Graham Calls Kavanaugh Hearing ‘the Most Unethical Sham’
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Continuing to shed his maverick credentials, the South Carolina Republican told his Democratic Senate colleagues, “What you want to do is destroy this guy’s life.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Lindsey Graham, the blunt-speaking South Carolina Republican, vented to reporters on Thursday outside the hearing room where the Senate Judiciary Committee was hearing explosive testimony about sexual assault allegations against Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, President Trump’s embattled Supreme Court nominee.

headline: Vote to Reinstate Russia Exposes Rifts in Antidoping Community
abstract: When World Anti-Doping Agency voted last week to take Russia off the list of noncompliant countries, it expected a backlash, but probably nothing like this.
lead_paragraph: The vote last week by the World Anti-Doping Agency to allow Russia to return to the international sports fold has laid bare the deep fissures within the community of athletes and officials who oversee the world’s competitions.

headline: Christine Blasey Ford's Heartbreaking Desire to Please
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: ‘Is this good?’
lead_paragraph: Whether you believed her or not, whether she was assaulted or not, whether she was unambiguously offered the chance to testify in California or Washington or Timbuktu, Christine Blasey Ford made one thing painfully clear in her testimony to the Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday, and that was her genuine, almost desperate desire to please.

headline: M.L.B. Playoff Races: David Dahl and the Rockies Stay Hot
abstract: The Colorado slugger homered for a fourth consecutive game in a win over Philadelphia, and the Yankees increased their lead over Oakland.
lead_paragraph: There was plenty of action in the open playoff races despite a limited schedule of games on Thursday, with Colorado increasing its lead in the National League West, and the Yankees reducing their magic number for securing home-field advantage in the wild-card game to one.

headline: Israeli-Palestinian Divide Deepens, With No Sign of Compromise at U.N.
abstract: In their General Assembly speeches, the Palestinian and Israeli leaders offered starkly opposing appraisals of an intractable dispute.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli and Palestinian leaders gave diametrically different appraisals of their protracted conflict on Thursday, with speeches at the United Nations General Assembly that suggested the dispute is more intractable than ever.

headline: C.C. Sabathia’s Loyalty to a Teammate Costs Him $500,000
abstract: A retaliatory hit-by-pitch resulted in Sabathia’s ejection, but the veteran left-hander was more concerned about the message he sent than the bonus he lost.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Granted, C. C. Sabathia has earned more than $250 million over his long, distinguished and lucrative career — enough to paper over a baseball diamond many times over with dollar bills.

headline: Washington Rolls Back Safety Rules Inspired by Deepwater Horizon Disaster
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Oil Spills']
abstract: New rules will no longer require oil companies to design gear for “most extreme” conditions, such as violent weather or heavy pressure within undersea wells — a key factor in the deadly 2010 blowout.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has completed its plan to roll back major offshore-drilling safety regulations that were put in place after the Deepwater Horizon oil rig disaster in 2010 that killed 11 people and caused the worst oil spill in American history.

headline: A High-Stakes Hearing Raises Two Voices, One Quiet, One Loud
abstract: The political and gender divide in America played out on TV not just in what Christine Blasey Ford and Brett Kavanaugh said, but how they said it.
lead_paragraph: It came down to she said, he screamed.

headline: Your Beliefs Here: A Look at Advocacy Advertising in The Times
abstract: A recent print ad in support of Christine Blasey Ford is part of a long history of advertisements in the paper whose main purpose is to forward a cause.
lead_paragraph: You may have noticed a bold advertisement in The New York Times on Wednesday: a full page with the names of 1,600 men, in a tiny font, surrounding a box in the center stating: “We believe Anita Hill. We also believe Christine Blasey Ford.”

headline: Christine Blasey Ford’s Sacrifice
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Her testimony was heroic. Will it be pointless?
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Christine Blasey Ford testified to the Senate Judiciary Committee, and the world, that Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh sexually assaulted her when they were both teenagers. Her soft voice cracked as she spoke. She smiled a lot; her attempts to make everyone see how agreeable and reasonable she is were heart-rending. But she was also poised and precise, occasionally speaking as an expert — she’s a psychology professor — as well as a victim. Watching her push through her evident terror was profoundly inspiring.

headline: As Senator Collins Weighs Vote, Maine Women Size Up Blasey and Kavanaugh
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “He does not to me sound like he’s lying, and neither did she.” Maine Democrats and Republicans watched the daylong testimony and came away torn.
lead_paragraph: BANGOR, Me. — Darcey Fraser, a farmer who opposes abortion rights, suspected a partisan motive. Andrea Irwin, a survivor of sexual abuse, was an ardent champion. And Katrina Petersen, who has registered with neither party, purposely avoided cable news before the hearing to keep an open mind.

headline: With Caffeine and Determination, Christine Blasey Ford Relives Her Trauma
abstract: Surrounded by her lawyers, publicists and a sisterhood of friends who had convened to support her and zealously protect her privacy, Dr. Blasey said her piece.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — She was terrified. She did not want to be there. She was badly in need of caffeine.

headline: Two Voices Pierce Washington: ‘I Am Terrified.’ ‘I Am Innocent.’
abstract: Tears, rage, partisanship: The Senate Judiciary Committee hearing of Christine Blasey Ford and Brett Kavanaugh was part trial, part theater, part therapy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The voices carried everywhere, quavering but firm.

headline: A Nation Transfixed as Emotional Testimony in Kavanaugh Hearing Unfolds
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: As Christine Blasey Ford and Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh gave their accounts in eight hours of tears, anger and exasperation, it seemed the country could not look away.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Travelers on airplanes cried as they watched it on their seatback televisions. College students holed up all day at library computers and streamed it on their phones, drowning out their lectures. Friends sat together, stunned and still, on living room couches. Television screens at nail salons, sports bars and hotel lobbies were tuned to nothing else.

headline: Why Brett Kavanaugh Wasn’t Believable
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: And why Christine Blasey Ford was.
lead_paragraph: What a study in contrasts: Where Christine Blasey Ford was calm and dignified, Brett Kavanaugh was volatile and belligerent; where she was eager to respond fully to every questioner, and kept worrying whether she was being “helpful” enough, he was openly contemptuous of several senators; most important, where she was credible and unshakable at every point in her testimony, he was at some points evasive, and some of his answers strained credulity.

headline: Review: Great Pretenders Pocket Laughs in ‘The Nap’
abstract: Richard Bean’s comedy about a wayward attempt to fix a snooker match tickles its audiences into contentment.
lead_paragraph: When you’re feeling burned-out, fed-up and generally disgusted — like now, maybe? — there’s nothing more therapeutic than a tickling session at the theater. Relax, it involves no squirmy physical contact.

headline: Watching Her Speak for Us All
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: On Thursday, Christine Blasey Ford was the voice for those of us who are still haunted by decades-old assaults — including me.
lead_paragraph: One of the most telling moments of Thursday’s Senate hearing for me — a survivor of rape at a drunken high school party when I was 16 — came during a reply to one of Senator Patrick Leahy’s questions for Christine Blasey Ford. He asked her to describe her strongest memory of the sexual assault she experienced at age 15.

headline: 4 Key Takeaways From the Blasey and Kavanaugh Hearing
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Sex Crimes', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: In a stunning hearing on Thursday, Christine Blasey Ford told her story in raw and gripping testimony as Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh fought to clear his name and salvage his confirmation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two weeks of chaos clouding Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh’s Supreme Court confirmation process culminated Thursday in a hearing that was stunning, even in a town notorious for partisan pageantry and intrigue.

lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Beyoncé, Paris Hilton, and Odin walk into a bar. “That gives me an idea!” says Kameron Austin Collins, with his fizzy gin drink.

headline: Man, Seal, Octopus
abstract: One viewer responded to this viral video, “Some days I’m the man. Some days I’m the seal. Most days I’m the octopus.” Who are you right now, and why?
lead_paragraph: Have you seen this viral video? A Times article about it, headlined “Don’t You Hate When a Seal Slaps You in the Face With an Octopus?,” begins, “The octopus was fighting for its life. The seal was fighting for its lunch. Kyle Mulinder just happened to be there.”

headline: The Red Carpet Hasn’t Changed. Don’t Blame the Stars. They’re Just Working.
keywords: ['#MeToo Movement', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Women and Girls', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Movies', 'Television', 'Golden Globes (Awards)', 'Emmy Awards']
abstract: For a few fleeting moments earlier this year, it seemed as if the red carpet had magically changed course.
lead_paragraph: With awards season approaching, stylists are at fashion weeks, scoping out looks for their clients, readying them to be at their best for months of parading down scads of red carpets. Harvey Weinstein may be banished, but the awards campaign machine he helped create grinds on.

headline: How Alliances Made Athens Great
abstract: The ancient Athenians manipulated their allies, spreading democracy and providing protection, always with their own interests first. Trump could learn something.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — In his declared intention to “Make America Great Again,” President Trump appears set on destroying the foundations of American greatness. The multinational organizations and agreements that established peace and stability, and encouraged economic growth for some seven decades, were designed principally by Americans. They organized the world pretty much the way that suited them, and they reaped the benefits of dominating it through a complex network of organizations and treaties.

headline: Rory McIlroy Is the Golfer Who Juggles. Or Is it Vice Versa?

It is a lot to balance, and this year he has sometimes staggered under the weight of expectations, even taking up juggling at the advice of a doctor friend, who suggested it as a stress-relieving, focus-sharpening exercise.

headline: Is This the End of Governors Island?
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Zoning', 'Ferries', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: The wild, ragged days of Governors Island are over, and development is coming. Will it retain its artistic spirit? Or will the hotels and high-rises kill it?
lead_paragraph: After a long, steamy summer, the weather was starting to change on Governors Island. A wind had kicked up and it looked as if it might rain, dark clouds loitering on the horizon and threatening to ruin the coming weekend’s OctFest. (Held, despite its name, in September.) Beer trucks, ice trucks and all kinds of vehicles were making their way onto the famously vehicle-free island for the second annual beer and music festival.

headline: Nursing Juliet
keywords: ['Dogs', 'Love (Emotion)', 'Death and Dying', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: In a world that relentlessly enforces limits, the love of a pet is a refuge for unconstrained emotion, especially for a child.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the moment when I knew. Juliet — the wiry lab-mutt we’d recently adopted from the pound — raced into our bedroom. In her enthusiasm, her gangly paws entangled a loose rug and she lost her footing. She catapulted through the air, an ebony mass of fur soaring toward the bed where our three-week old infant was lying flat as a Kansas pancake. It happened so quickly that all I could do was watch in fear as she plowed toward our 7-pound baby.

headline: Original, Handwritten Manuscripts of ‘The Picture of Dorian Gray’
abstract: An earlier version of Oscar Wilde’s controversial novel contains homoerotic undertones which he edited out for the final book.
lead_paragraph: “He can write for none but outlawed noblemen and perverted telegraph boys,” one critic wrote of Oscar Wilde in The Scots Observer in July 1890, responding to the first serialization of “The Picture of Dorian Gray” in Lippincott’s Magazine. This was just one of “hundreds of entries of vituperation in the press when it came out,” Wilde’s grandson Merlin Holland recently told The Times, and Wilde spent the next year revising his aestheticist tale of a double life for publication in book form, removing certain homoerotic passages. A new book of Wilde’s handwritten manuscripts, THE PICTURE OF DORIAN GRAY (SP Books, $250), grants readers unfiltered access to lines of pure, unadulterated affection that the author was compelled to omit if he ever wanted the story to become the literary success it did. “It is quite true that I have worshipped you with far more romance than a man should ever give to a friend,” the painter Basil tells Dorian in the magazine edition, but not the final novel. “Somehow I had never loved a woman. I suppose I never had time. … I quite admit that I adore you madly, extravagantly, absurdly.” Such sentences led Lippincott’s readers to deem this, in Holland’s words, “a disgusting, sodomitical novel.” (He added that the full text would later be used in court as “circumstantial proof that Wilde was homosexual” — a charge that sent him to prison.) Holland, who wrote the new book’s foreword, considers this “the urtext of ‘Dorian Gray,’” revealing raw passions the writer intended to evoke before the world was yet ready to read them. “He was standing up for his right as an artist to write about whatever he pleased,” Holland said of his grandfather. “He had the right to create the characters he wanted to create.”

headline: Kids’ Fantasy Novels That Make Heroes Out of Underdogs
abstract: In new books from Daniel José Older, M.T. Anderson and more, readers can root for orphans, apprentices, elves and goblins as they battle evildoers.
lead_paragraph: There’s undeniable entertainment in watching an all-powerful Superman dish out justice to the bad guys. But it can be even more satisfying to see the job done by a hero without laser vision or invincibility or even much in the way of muscles. This is why underdogs work so well in children’s literature, where, to the target readership, everything from a school bully to a burdensome homework assignment can feel as overwhelming as a supervillain.

headline: An Italian Hotelier Mixes Opulence and Wellness (O.K., Plus More Opulence)
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Family Business', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: SD Hotels is capitalizing on the hype around two distinct travel trends.
lead_paragraph: At the breakfast buffet of Borgo Egnazia, a high-end resort in Fasano on Italy’s eastern coast, there’s a carafe of a substance unlikely to be found at any similarly luxurious hotel elsewhere in the world: siero di latte e cacao, or milk serum and cocoa. It looks like hot chocolate but tastes like seaweed, pungent enough that it might trigger the gag reflex of a consumer more accustomed to starting the morning with something from Starbucks. A centuries-old breakfast staple in this part of the world, the drink is essentially a protein shake made with the whey that remains after milk has been curdled and strained.

headline: Only the Truth Can Save Us Now
abstract: Before we accept a permanent division over the Kavanaugh Affair, here are some ways to make a last bid for greater clarity.
lead_paragraph: The day before Thursday's endless, grueling, moving, infuriating hearings, which mostly provided an exhibit in the case for the dissolution of our Senate, I argued that we would all probably have to learn to live with uncertainty about the truth of this nightmarish affair. Nothing about the appearances of Christine Blasey Ford and Brett Kavanaugh changed that basic reality — not the undeniable power of her account, not the sob-swallowing anguish of his attempt at self-exculpation, and certainly not the relics and opportunists croaking and preening and shouting from a decaying institution’s bench.

headline: Afghan War Casualty Report: Sept. 6-27
abstract: This first entry of the Afghan War casualty report goes back to Sept. 6, when 400 Afghan soldiers and police officers were reportedly killed in one week.
lead_paragraph: Beginning in September, the Times bureau in Kabul mobilized all of its stringers and Afghan reporters to record every attack on the Afghan security forces that they could find, as a daily chronicle of the war. This first entry goes back to the week of Sept. 6, a period when 400 Afghan soldiers and police officers were reportedly killed, a record number. The average this year, officials say, is between 30 and 40 deaths per day. Many local Afghan officials say they have been told not to cooperate with the press in reporting casualties, so this accounting is necessarily incomplete.

headline: It’s Bad Enough That My Mom Died. Now My Dad Is Dating Her Nurse?
abstract: A reader tries to navigate grief and anger at the same time.
lead_paragraph: My mother died after a two-year battle with cancer. Her palliative care nurse (for much of that time) helped me wash and dress her body, and signed her death certificate. Now, my father has revealed that he began a sexual relationship with the nurse shortly after my mother died. I feel the nurse betrayed her patient, acted unprofessionally and preyed on my father at a vulnerable time. I despise her! This has caused a huge rift with my father. What to do?

headline: Robert Redford Isn’t Going Anywhere, for Now
abstract: Mr. Redford talks about his latest — but perhaps not his last — role, in “The Old Man & the Gun.”
lead_paragraph: This started as an article about the end of a career. But somewhere between announcing his retirement from acting in early August and the New York premiere in late September of what was to be his last film, “The Old Man & the Gun,” Robert Redford seemingly had a change of heart.

headline: In ‘Pretty Poison’ and ‘Gun Crazy,’ Femmes Fatales With Deadly Firepower
abstract: Tuesday Weld in “Pretty Poison” and Peggy Cummins in “Gun Crazy” are fresh-faced, trigger-happy young women in two films that attained cult status.
lead_paragraph: “Pretty Poison,” starring Anthony Perkins and Tuesday Weld, was hardly the greatest Hollywood movie of 1968. As a film about delusional young folk run murderously wild, and the subject of critics’ debates, it was however one of that turbulent year’s quintessential stories.

headline: Sharing a Site-Specific Secret
abstract: A romantic garden. A Chinese opera. And a select audience, wandering under Californian stars.
lead_paragraph: Only 40 people a night get to see “Nightwalk in the Chinese Garden,” a site-specific production staged beneath the evening sky at the Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens in San Marino, Calif.

headline: Theaters Fight Over ‘Harry Potter’ and ‘Evan Hansen’ in San Francisco
abstract: Nederlander of San Francisco asked a judge to prevent a rival theater from staging the popular shows.
lead_paragraph: The biggest commercial theater presenters in San Francisco are trying to block productions of “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child” and “Dear Evan Hansen” from opening at a competing venue.

headline: Children Learn a Hard Lesson in ‘The Hate U Give’
abstract: The director George Tillman Jr. discusses a scene in which a father teaches his children how to handle themselves in an encounter with police officers.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Jeff Flake Is Confronted on Video by Sexual Assault Survivors
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', '#MeToo Movement']
abstract: The two women stopped the senator in an elevator and described their own trauma. “I wanted him to feel my rage,” one said later. Read the transcript.
lead_paragraph: The scene was striking: Two women blocking an elevator door, angrily demanding to be heard as a senator stood by, listening quietly, nodding and looking away.

headline: Introducing The New York Times Fellowship: A New Program
abstract: Seeking to cultivate journalism's next generation, The New York Times is thrilled to announce a new fellowship for recent college graduates and postgraduates.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to cultivate journalism's next generation, The New York Times is thrilled to announce a new fellowship for recent college graduates and postgraduates.

headline: Elon Musk’s Fans Just Took a Big Hit as Tesla Shares Tank
abstract: The stock tumbled nearly 14 percent Friday. The S.E.C.’s lawsuit against Mr. Musk is putting the spotlight on a company in turbulence and celebrity C.E.O.s.
