headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Embrace the end of the season, and make one last great tomato salad.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Tejal Rao’s about to move to California for us, bound for a life of restaurant criticism across the state. We’re excited, too, that she’ll keep writing about cooking for The New York Times Magazine, as she has this week for an “Eat” column devoted to the joys of making and eating the last great tomato salad of the year. Tejal adapted her recipe (above) from one made by the San Francisco chef Preeti Mistry and, if you’re lucky, you’ll be able to make it a few times before the season turns and the tomatoes are all gone.

headline: In Erdogan’s Charm Offensive, Germans Find Offense
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Extradition', 'Political Prisoners', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: A three-day state visit by the Turkish president was supposed to help repair relations. It has fallen short.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A three-day state visit to Germany by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey was supposed to be aimed at repairing relations at a time of a looming economic crisis at home.

headline: For Progress on Vaccine Development
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Immune System', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome']
abstract: A researcher says we need a moonshot-level effort.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: So You’ve Frozen Your Credit Files. Here Are Tips on Unfreezing Them.
abstract: A new law allows consumers to lift a security freeze without charge when they want to apply for a credit card or a car loan.
lead_paragraph: People who froze their credit files before September may notice some changes when the time comes to thaw the files.

headline: How Wet Clothes Become Translucent
abstract: When water replaces air in a fabric, the material itself reflects less light.
lead_paragraph: A. Cloth, like paper, is made up of discrete strands of fiber with air between them. Light hitting the dry material is somewhat scattered within it, but a good share is reflected to the eye. This renders the material visible.

headline: Why the Senate Must Seek the Truth
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It is impossible to justify the lack of a neutral investigation into the allegations against Brett Kavanaugh.
lead_paragraph: Twice as a reporter, I’ve interviewed women who have accused men of sexual assault and the men they accused. In both cases, the women looked me in the eye and told me about how they’d been raped, and then the men looked me in the eye and told me they’d never raped anyone. All four people spoke with force and emotion. In the moment, I wanted to believe each one. It’s uncomfortable to imagine that someone who seems wholly sincere is not. It’s confusing — it seems unfeeling — to turn away from someone who makes a vehement claim of truth.

headline: To Get to the Boston Marathon, Run Faster, and Faster
abstract: Are top marathoners of every age getting faster? Judging by how much harder it is getting to qualify for Boston, it sure seems like it.
lead_paragraph: For thousands of runners, that dream of running in the Boston Marathon just got a little more far-fetched.

headline: A Pasta as Versatile and Reliable as Your Pantry
abstract: Most pantry pastas aren’t as interesting as the larders they come from. This is an exception.
lead_paragraph: Most pantry pasta recipes assume that you have a pretty bare larder. Made entirely from ingredients you’re likely to have on hand, the recipes are usually some minimalist combination of garlic, olive oil, bread crumbs, chile flakes, and possibly anchovies or Parmesan, or both. Delicious, absolutely, but not reflective of the breadth of even a moderately well-stocked pantry.

headline: 5 Takeaways on President Trump’s Foreign Policy From the U.N. General Assembly
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Palestinians']
abstract: President Trump and American officials clarified their policy in a range of hot spots: North Korea, Syria, Iran, Israel and China. Oh, and Canada.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — This week’s gathering of the annual United Nations General Assembly was dominated by President Trump.

headline: China Censors Bad Economic News Amid Signs of Slower Growth
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Censorship', 'News and News Media']
abstract: New directives betray a mounting anxiety among Chinese leaders that the country could be facing a worsening slump as the trade war with the United States intensifies.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China has long made it clear that reporting on politics, civil society and sensitive historical events is forbidden. Increasingly, it wants to keep negative news about the economy under control, too.

headline: Life With No Males? These Termites Show That It’s Possible
keywords: ['Termites', 'Gender', 'Reproduction (Biological)', 'Research', 'Women and Girls', 'Men and Boys', 'Genetics and Heredity']
abstract: A discovery among termite colonies in Japan suggests that males can be discarded from advanced societies in which they once played an active role.
lead_paragraph: Termites are often dismissed as nothing but home-destroying pests, less charismatic than bees, ants or even spiders.

headline: A Delicate Treatment for a Just-as-Delicate Fish
abstract: Mild and sweet-tasting flounder and other flatfish benefit from a quick brown-butter sauce.
lead_paragraph: When you head to the fish market, you may find small thin fillets of flounder, fluke, sole or plaice, or thick halibut fillets. As different as they may be in size, they are all related, part of the flatfish family — and delicate, mild and sweet tasting, with tender white flesh.

headline: Instagram Is Too Big Not to Mess With
abstract: With the photo app’s founders gone, Facebook is likely to change it significantly.
lead_paragraph: On the face of it, there’s nothing surprising about Instagram's founders leaving six years after the company was sold. Mike Krieger and Kevin Systrom’s tenures at Facebook were longer than that of most Facebook employees, where the average is 2.5 years. And Instagram has come a long way since Facebook bought it in April 2012 for a reported $1 billion. In the past six years, Instagram has grown from 50 million users to more than a billion users, and it currently employs more than 700 people. Today, its estimated worth is over $100 billion.

headline: S.E.C. Goes After Musk With Its ‘Ultimate’ Penalty. Here’s Who Else Has Been Barred.
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking to bar Mr. Musk from ever serving as an officer or director of a public company.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission has accused Elon Musk, Tesla’s chief executive, of committing fraud when he said on Twitter: “Am considering taking Tesla private at $420. Funding secured.” The S.E.C. says Mr. Musk had not had specific conversations about financing when he made that announcement, and so his tweet amounted to a false public statement with the potential to harm investors. It is seeking to prevent Mr. Musk from ever serving as an officer or director of a public company again, which is the most serious penalty the regulator can seek. (Criminal charges, if any, would be brought by the Department of Justice in a separate case.)

headline: Tsunami and Earthquake in Indonesia Kill Nearly 400, Officials Say
abstract: Hundreds were killed in the city of Palu alone, and it was feared that the toll could rise further still.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Indonesian officials said Saturday that nearly 400 people had been killed in a strong earthquake and a tsunami on the central island of Sulawesi. Rescue workers had yet to reach some areas thought to have been affected, and it was feared that the toll could still rise.

headline: Should They Stay or Should They Go? Pop Stars and Retirement
abstract: Why do some artists stick around and others choose to retreat?
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, “Egypt Station,” a new solo album by Paul McCartney, made its debut at the top of the Billboard album chart. Mr. McCartney is 76 and shows no apparent signs of slowing down — on this album, he worked with Greg Kurstin and Ryan Tedder, and recently he collaborated with Kanye West, a sign of an artist who’s as curious as ever.

headline: Raised in South Central, Joe Ide Expands the Territory of L.A. Noir
abstract: The third entry in the IQ crime series, “Wrecked,” comes out this month.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The crime writer Joe Ide sat in a car at the corner of San Pedro and Adams in South Central Los Angeles and memories of his boyhood returned — mostly in the form of characters. “The winos used to sit out there on orange crates and drink Thunderbird all day,” he said, pointing at the graffiti streaked storefront of what is now a pupuseria. There was one “wino,” tall, immaculate and dapper in a homburg hat “with a little feather in it,” who used to escort Mr. Ide’s mother onto the bus everyday, like a butler.

headline: Fast Favorites
abstract: When the days get busy, make some well-loved recipes, like Melissa Clark’s sheet-pan chicken, eggs in purgatory and cacio e pepe.
lead_paragraph: Hello again, and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. I’m finding myself in the mood for chicken — roast chicken in particular, something juicy and salty and soul-anchoring. One of my absolute favorites from NYT Cooking is on the list below, Melissa Clark’s sheet-pan chicken with arugula, yogurt and potatoes. I fell back on a lot of my favorites this week, as the days gathered steam and things got too busy: salad with green goddess dressing, pasta, eggs and more eggs, delicious and pleasing and practically made from muscle memory. Here are a few of those recipes, along with others I love and imagine you might too. Any weeknight favorites you want to tell the world about? Please start with me! I’m at dearemily@nytimes.com.

headline: Sign up for The Campaign Reporter
abstract: Get messages from our politics correspondent Alex Burns as he covers the biggest races this election season. Along the way, he’ll take your questions and help you understand what’s at stake on Nov. 6.
lead_paragraph: Get messages from our politics correspondent Alex Burns as he covers the biggest races this election season. Along the way, he’ll take your questions and help you understand what’s at stake on Nov. 6.

headline: Pret A Manger Allergy Labeling Ruled ‘Inadequate’ After Teen’s Death
abstract: Natasha Ednan-Laperouse had a severe allergy to sesame. The baguette she picked up at the sandwich chain carried no mention of the seeds baked into its dough.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On the way to a vacation in France with her father, Natasha Ednan-Laperouse picked up a sandwich at a Pret A Manger store in Heathrow Airport. She read the label carefully, because she had a severe sesame allergy.

headline: A Mother and a Legislator
abstract: A former New Hampshire state legislator tells how she successfully combined both roles.

headline: Doubts Mount in Botswana Over Charity’s Claim of Elephant ‘Poaching Frenzy’
abstract: Critics say that Elephants Without Borders made exaggerated claims to try to influence the government, which is considering rolling back a hunting ban.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — It was a shocking story that attracted global attention this month: A “poaching frenzy” in northern Botswana left 87 elephants dead, slaughtered for their tusks to feed Africa’s growing illicit ivory trade.

headline: Canada’s Parliament Moves to Strip Honor for Myanmar’s Leader
abstract: Canada’s House of Commons voted to revoke the honorary citizenship of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi for not criticizing violence by Myanmar’s military against the Rohingya.
lead_paragraph: Eleven years after Canada granted honorary citizenship to Myanmar’s civilian leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the House of Commons voted unanimously to revoke it.

lead_paragraph: GRAZ, Austria — “Tormented by your Nazi grandfather’s hat in the attic? Unsure what to do about it? Too ashamed to sell, too emotional to burn?”

headline: Duncan Hunter Airs Ad Suggesting Opponent Is Terrorist Sympathizer
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Political Advertising', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The California Republican, battling charges that he misused campaign funds, said his opponent, Ammar Campa-Najjar, is “infiltrating Congress.’’
lead_paragraph: Representative Duncan Hunter, the California Republican whose re-election campaign has been imperiled by a federal indictment, has released a startling attack against his Democratic challenger, suggesting that he is an Islamic terrorist sympathizer and national security risk.

headline: Republicans See Kavanaugh and the Court as Worth the Risk
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Despite Democratic claims that Republicans are needlessly rushing the nomination, Republicans see an opportunity for a conservative court.
lead_paragraph: With his disputed nomination headed to the Senate floor, Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh himself may have best summed up the reason Republicans are so eager to move him on to the Supreme Court despite a toxic struggle over his confirmation.

headline: Facebook Security Breach Exposes Accounts of 50 Million Users
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Privacy']
abstract: The attack added to the company’s woes as it contends with fallout from its role in a Russian disinformation campaign.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook, already facing scrutiny over how it handles the private information of its users, said on Friday that an attack on its computer network had exposed the personal information of nearly 50 million users.

headline: Midterm Election Poll: Michigan’s 8th District, Bishop vs. Slotkin
abstract: This district includes Democratic-leaning areas near the state capital and Michigan State University, and  extends to the Republican-leaning outer suburbs of Detroit.
lead_paragraph: This district includes Democratic-leaning areas near the state capital and Michigan State University, and  extends to the Republican-leaning outer suburbs of Detroit.

headline: In Germany, a Social Democrat Who Welcomes Trump’s Bluster
abstract: The country’s new finance minister, Olaf Scholz, says the president’s anti-globalist policies are acting as a catalyst for European integration.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Olaf Scholz took over as Germany’s finance minister in March. Since then, President Trump has threatened to slap tariffs on German cars, called Europe a “foe” and dispatched an ambassador to Berlin who takes selfies with far-right politicians eager to bring down the German government.

headline: ‘The Simpsons’ at 30: Six Era-Defining Episodes
abstract: Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa and Maggie: Since 1989, they haven’t aged a day. But they have evolved, as the culture has with them.
lead_paragraph: For the past three decades, there has been one constant in America’s comedy landscape: “The Simpsons.” With that animated sitcom now approaching the start of its 30th season, on Sept. 30, it’s a good time to reflect on how “The Simpsons” has evolved during its unparalleled run, and how each era in that evolution has reflected — or failed to reflect — the state of comedy, and of the culture, as a whole.

headline: How to Help Guide Young Women in the Workplace
abstract: Some women at the start of their careers told The Times what they think companies can do to reform the workplace environment.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the #MeToo movement and calls to make workplaces more inclusive, employers are evaluating which opportunities are being offered to women, how to improve career development and how to help women succeed. To further that discussion, some women at the start of their careers told The New York Times what they thought companies could do to reform the workplace environment.

headline: Representation as Resistance in São Paulo
abstract: The photographer Gabriela Portilho examines personal style as a statement of identity, culture and strength on the streets of São Paulo, Brazil.

headline: Fall Galas at Lincoln Center
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic and the High Line held benefit galas.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic and the High Line held benefit galas.

headline: What Happened in Pop Culture This Week? Your Cheat Sheet
abstract: What you need to know from today’s TV, music and movie news.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to your new weekly breakdown of the movie, TV and pop music news you should know about, curated from The New York Times and across the web.

headline: The Playlist: Lady Gaga Dives Into a Fresh Era, and 15 More New Songs
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Country Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Jazz']
abstract: Hear tracks from Lil Wayne, Barbra Streisand, Thelonious Monk and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Vulnerable New Jersey Republican Defends Kavanaugh, Jolting Race
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Representative Leonard Lance, a Republican, was heard on a recording saying “I tend not to believe the charges” against Brett M. Kavanaugh. Mr. Lance said his comments were taken out of context.
lead_paragraph: WESTFIELD, N.J. — The deep divide over the nomination of Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh and the emotional testimony of Christine Blasey Ford is jolting a closely watched, tight congressional race in New Jersey.

headline: House Republicans to Meet Privately With Rod Rosenstein
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Twenty-Fifth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: The deputy attorney general agreed to meet with House Republicans to address the revelations that he suggested secretly recording President Trump and possibly removing him from office.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans plan to privately question the deputy attorney general, Rod J. Rosenstein, about discussions last year where he suggested secretly taping President Trump to expose a chaotic White House and removing him from office under the 25th Amendment.

headline: The ‘Tight Rope’ of Testifying While Female
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Christine Blasey Ford’s testimony was a stark reminder of the gender dynamics, and mental gymnastics, required of women who speak up.
lead_paragraph: She dressed modestly, in a navy suit and dark-rimmed glasses. No flashy jewelry, little makeup.

headline: Gender Politics 101: Teaching Refugees About Sex and Consent in Sweden
abstract: Refugees who are settling in Sweden are learning how to become members of Swedish society. For many newcomers from the Middle East, that means shifting thinking about sex and relationships.
lead_paragraph: Refugees who are settling in Sweden are learning how to become members of Swedish society. For many newcomers from the Middle East, that means shifting thinking about sex and relationships.

headline: Missing: Female C.E.O.s
abstract: Boards choose leaders. If they are not attuned to the importance of diversity, and diverse themselves, there is little hope for meaningful change.
lead_paragraph: When Indra Nooyi steps down on Wednesday as chief executive of PepsiCo after a successful 12 years at the helm, there will be one less woman running a major American company. Her successor, Ramon Laguarta, is a man.

headline: What Men Should Know About #MeToo: It’s About Them
keywords: ['#MeToo Movement', 'Men and Boys', 'Women and Girls', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Women “are laying themselves bare to awaken us, so we can do better,” said Wade Davis, a former N.F.L. player.
lead_paragraph: “Here’s what men don’t get about the #MeToo movement: It is not about women, it’s about us,” Wade Davis, a former N.F.L. player turned educator and activist, said at the summit. By “us” he meant men.

headline: In ‘The Mile-Long Opera,’ All the High Line’s a Stage
abstract: This opera, opening Oct. 3, has a cast of 1,000 and a team of A-listers including the architect Liz Diller and the composer David Lang.
lead_paragraph: “You always step into this life cycle of the city, whether it’s declining or being reborn, and you don’t even understand how you’re a part of it,” the famed architect Liz Diller said earlier this week on the High Line, a modern triumph of her firm, Diller Scofidio + Renfro.

headline: Trudeau Sought Support From Mexico’s President on Nafta
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'Automobiles', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: The telephone conversation between the two leaders, came as the United States and Mexico were poised to release text of the trade pact reached last month that excludes Canada.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada appealed to President-elect Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico this week to help salvage a three-country North American Free Trade Agreement as the White House prepared to send Congress a bilateral trade deal with Mexico.

headline: In the Nursing Home, Empty Beds and Quiet Halls
keywords: ['Nursing Homes', 'Elder Care', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Home Health Care']
abstract: Fewer patients are winding up in nursing homes, and hundreds of the facilities are closing each year.
lead_paragraph: For more than 40 years, Morningside Ministries operated a nursing home in San Antonio, caring for as many as 113 elderly residents. The facility, called Chandler Estate, added a small independent living building in the 1980s and an even smaller assisted living center in the 90s, all on the same four-acre campus.

headline: At Elite Colleges, Racial Diversity Requires Affirmative Action
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Endowments', 'Minorities', 'Nepotism', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: Getting more low-income students into elite colleges is an important goal. But most poor applicants are white, so race-based criteria are needed.
lead_paragraph: Getting more low-income students into elite colleges like Harvard and Stanford is an important goal. But it can’t replace race-based affirmative action.

headline: The Man Who Taught a Generation of Black Artists Gets His Own Retrospective
abstract: When he died in 1979, Charles White had been influential, both in and outside of the art world. Now, a coming show at MoMA resurrects the American master.
lead_paragraph: AT THE TIME of his death in 1979, Charles White was the most famous black artist in the country. As the painter Benny Andrews said in Whiteʼs obituary in The New York Times, “People who didnʼt know his name knew and recognized his work.” He was a public figure who ranked in the imagination of black Americans alongside such figures as Harry Belafonte — a friend, collector and portrait subject — and Sidney Poitier, who eulogized the artist at his memorial service.

headline: Make T Something | Adam Selman
abstract: The fashion designer accepts T’s challenge to make something in less than one hour with only a few select items — and creates an entirely new persona for himself.
lead_paragraph: The fashion designer accepts T’s challenge to make something in less than one hour with only a few select items — and creates an entirely new persona for himself.

headline: ‘We, the Dancers’: At City Ballet’s Gala, Affirming Ballet’s Honor
abstract: In a moving speech before the gala’s three new ballets, Teresa Reichlen spoke of the dancers’ commitment to “dignity, integrity and honor.”
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night at the David H. Koch Theater, the curtain rose to show the dancers of New York City Ballet, assembled to face the audience. Then Teresa Reichlen, standing center front, delivered a speech — written by her and Adrian Danchig-Waring, another principal — that began with the words, “We the dancers of New York City Ballet.” The unlikely occasion was the company’s fall fashion gala.

headline: How to Get (Fake) Six-Pack Abs, With Adam Selman
abstract: In the latest episode of “Make T Something,” the fashion designer pays homage to the Instagram-famous bodybuilder Jujimufu.
lead_paragraph: The fashion designer Adam Selman is never not working on a craft project. “My boyfriend is always like, ‘No, you can’t put patches on that chair!’ ” he says; recently, at the apartment the couple shares in New York, Selman decoupaged the drawers of his antique dresser with cutouts from vintage porn magazines (“I call it ‘Grandma’s Dresser’ ”). He was an obvious candidate for T’s video series “Make T Something,” in which participants create something in under an hour using only a few select items and one object of their choosing.

headline: A Bitter Nominee, Questions of Neutrality, and a Damaged Supreme Court
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Experts in the law said it would be hard for Judge Kavanaugh, if he is confirmed, to set aside his bitter experience in Senate hearings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the first round of his Supreme Court confirmation hearings early this month, Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh kept his cool under hostile questioning, stressed his independence, and exhibited the calm judicial demeanor that characterized his dozen years on a prestigious appeals court bench.

headline: Dr. Lois Jovanovic, 71, Dies; Helped Diabetic Women Have Babies
abstract: A third-generation diabetic herself, she upset conventional wisdom in finding that women whose blood sugar level was controlled could safely give birth.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Lois Jovanovic, who redeemed a childhood pledge when she pioneered a medical procedure that enabled more women with diabetes to deliver healthy babies, died on Sept. 18 at her home in Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 71 and had herself been treated for diabetes since giving birth decades ago.

headline: Review: The Philharmonic Puts a Young Composer’s Twist on Bruckner
abstract: On Thursday, the orchestra presented the premiere of Conrad Tao’s “Everything Must Go,” intended as a curtain-raiser for Bruckner’s Eighth Symphony.
lead_paragraph: Conrad Tao, the 24-year-old composer and brilliant pianist, charmingly admitted earlier this year that he didn’t know Bruckner’s sprawling Eighth Symphony when he was asked by the New York Philharmonic to write a short piece as a sort of prelude for it. Yet Mr. Tao emphasized at the time that the proposal enticed him, and that he was eager to get to know the Bruckner.

headline: Would You Hire Kavanaugh?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', 'Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: If a third of the men on the Supreme Court had faced allegations of sexual misconduct, what would that do to the court’s legitimacy?
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: Review: Sit Still and Watch the Dance Revolve
abstract: RoseAnne Spradlin’s “Y” is like a kinetic sculpture that shifts its orientation eight times.
lead_paragraph: Now and again, a complex bit of choreography can provoke a desire for instant replay, another chance to notice more. In “Y,” the RoseAnne Spradlin work that had its debut at New York Live Arts on Thursday, that desire is fulfilled abundantly. The opening section is repeated no less than eight times.

headline: ‘She’s a Class Act. You’re Not’: Attacks on Families Heat Up N.Y. Governor’s Race
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has suggested that a job held by his opponent’s wife at an architecture firm with county contracts might be unethical.
lead_paragraph: As his voice cracked with emotion, Marcus Molinaro, the Republican candidate for governor in New York, delivered an unusual warning to the incumbent, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: The Wild Alaskan Whales Will Perform at Noon
abstract: There’s nothing like a long ocean cruise among the icebergs to make you realize you are not a cruise person.
lead_paragraph: I just got back from my first cruise, and I must tell you that if you have been feeling bored, jaded, indifferent to the banquet of life, nothing is more invigorating — not of spending time on a cruise ship, but getting off.

headline: In the Hunt for Quants, One Hedge Fund Held a Global Talent Contest
abstract: Big tech has tempted many math and science graduates away from finance and toward Silicon Valley, so the search for new staff is expanding.

headline: Who Wants to Eat a Gooey Jellyfish? Pretty Much Everyone in the Ocean.
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Jellyfish', 'Food', 'Marine Biology']
abstract: Scientists had long assumed that few creatures dined on these gelatinous animals. But new research suggests that jellyfish may be an important part of the ocean’s food supply.
lead_paragraph: For a hungry fish in search of a meal, a jellyfish would seem to be a huge disappointment. These gelatinous animals are 95 percent water. As a result, a cup of live jellyfish provides just five calories — one-third the amount in a cup of celery.

headline: Inge Feltrinelli Dies at 87; Publishing Titan Started With a Camera
abstract: Early on she photographed Hemingway, Garbo, Picasso and others. Then she married a publisher and later took over the house, one of Italy’s most important.
lead_paragraph: In 1953, Ernest Hemingway’s German publisher sent the young photojournalist Inge Schönthal to Cuba to discuss a new translation of the writer’s books. She had been looking for a way to meet Hemingway and had asked the publisher for help.

headline: For Tiger Woods, a Frustrating Morning and an Afternoon Off
abstract: Woods’s recent success on tour didn’t carry over to the Ryder Cup on Friday. After a loss in the morning, he was a spectator in the afternoon.
lead_paragraph: ST-QUENTIN-EN-YVELINES, France — Patrick Reed was Tiger Woods’s 13th Ryder Cup partner, and the 2018 United States captain, Jim Furyk, who had been one of the previous 12, felt optimistic about the pairing’s prospects for success. As Furyk explained, Reed relishes performing in front of large crowds and Woods attracts fans like lint.

keywords: ['Social Security (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: Every two years, voters — whether they already count on the program, expect to or question paying into it — try to make sense of competing claims about it. It’s that time again.
lead_paragraph: It’s no wonder that Social Security is politically contentious. The program’s reach is vast: More than 175 million workers contribute to it with every paycheck, and about 43 million retirees collect monthly benefits. For three in five older Americans, those checks account for more than half their income.

headline: Geta Bratescu, Adventuresome Romanian Artist, Is Dead at 92
abstract: The creator of experimental, often humorous works, she had been a prolific artist for decades in her own country. But the West discovered her only recently.
lead_paragraph: Geta Bratescu, a Romanian artist who made experimental, often humorous works even during the most oppressive years of Communism and of Nicolae Ceausescu’s regime, but who remained largely unknown outside Romania until she was in her 80s, died on Sept. 19 at her home in Bucharest. She was 92.

headline: Joe Masteroff, Playwright of ‘Cabaret’ Fame, Is Dead at 98
abstract: The winner of a Tony for his evocation of decadent prewar Berlin, he is also remembered for another acclaimed Broadway musical, “She Loves Me.”
lead_paragraph: Joe Masteroff, the playwright who won a Tony and international renown for “Cabaret,” the often-revived 1966 Broadway musical about soulless lovers lost in the decadence of a seedy Berlin nightclub and the rising fascism of prewar Germany, died on Friday in Engelwood, N.J. He was 98.

headline: The Bill Cosby Case: Glimpses of a Downfall

lead_paragraph: Bill Cosby’s incarceration for sexual assault marks the end of a nearly three-year criminal proceeding that featured two trials and searing testimony from his accuser and other women who say they were assaulted by him. While Mr. Cosby’s defenders, including his wife, depicted the prosecution as racist and unjust, the final victory of the Montgomery County District Attorney’s office sparked jubilation by those who hailed his conviction as the first major victory in the #MeToo movement.

headline: Harvard’s Endowment Grew 10% Last Year, but Some Rivals Did Better
abstract: In the second year of an overhaul by a new investment chief, the world’s largest university endowment trailed returns of 13.5 percent at M.I.T. and 12.9 percent at Penn, for example.
lead_paragraph: Harvard University’s endowment, the world’s largest, grew 10 percent in the most recent fiscal year to $39.2 billion, officials said on Friday. That was slightly better than the previous year, when Harvard began to revamp the endowment under a new investment chief, but fell short of returns reported recently by several other large universities.

headline: ‘Felicity’ 20 Years on: A Look Back at the 10 Best Episodes
abstract: Before Keri Russell was a cutthroat spy on “The Americans,” she played a fresh-faced college kid in this series from J.J. Abrams and Matt Reeves.
lead_paragraph: J.J. Abrams and Matt Reeves had only collaborated once — for the 1996 movie “The Pallbearer” — when they sold “Felicity” to the WB network 20 years ago this weekend. It wound up an outlier in their careers, which went on to include genre series like “Alias” and “Lost”; scary movies like “Cloverfield” and “Let Me In”; and big-screen reboots of “Star Wars” and “Planet of the Apes.” “Felicity,” by contrast, was a modest, character-driven TV drama about an introverted high school student (Keri Russell) who follows her dream guy, Ben (Scott Speedman), to college in New York City.

headline: Pam Henry, the Last Poster Child for Polio, Dies at 68
abstract: Ms. Henry was part of the last March of Dimes publicity campaign against the disease. She later became one of the first female TV reporters in Oklahoma.
lead_paragraph: Doctors discovered that Pam Henry had polio in 1951, when she was just 14 months old. At the time, the disease infected tens of thousands of children in the United States every year, permanently disabling many of them.

headline: Just Say ‘No’ to Cuomo: Secret Emails Reveal de Blasio’s Gripes and Grudges

headline: Why I Love Reality Television
keywords: ['Reality Television', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Women and Girls', 'Dating and Relationships']
abstract: Shows like “Love & Hip Hop” offer nuanced portrayals of women of color. They’re not a guilty pleasure.
lead_paragraph: Why do people call reality television a guilty pleasure? Why do so many reject the possibility that the trashiest of shows, like VH1’s “Love & Hip Hop,” might have a lot to tell us about society, women and power? Shows like this aren’t fluff — they’re subversive, self-aware and capable of depicting the complexities of women of color in nuanced ways.

headline: An Injudicious Man, Unfit for the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: This was a job interview, not a criminal trial. Kavanaugh, in his fury and pathos, failed the test.
lead_paragraph: What America saw before the Senate Judiciary Committee was an injudicious man, an angry brat veering from fury to sniveling sobs, a judge so bereft of composure and proportion that it was difficult not to squirm. Brett Kavanaugh actually got teary over keeping a calendar because that’s what his dad did. His performance was right out of Norman Rockwell with a touch of “Mad Men.”

headline: Yankees Book Another Wild-Card Playoff for the Bronx
abstract: By beating the Red Sox, the Yankees assured they would host Oakland in a single-elimination showdown on Wednesday. A thrilling 2017 postseason run for the Yankees began with a wild-card win at home.

It did not turn out that way, because the Red Sox had nothing to play for after reaching every possible regular-season goal days earlier.

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’ Will End Its Broadway Run in April

abstract: We traveled to seven rail depots in the nation’s middle. The stations, some remade and others crumbling, reflect the trajectories of their towns.

headline: Hedi Slimane’s Celine: Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again
abstract: Rejecting the female gaze for baby doll poufs and skinny suits — and other clothes we’ve seen before.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On Friday night in Paris, as the moon rose over the gold dome of Napoleon’s tomb in Les Invalides and a giant black box specially constructed in its backyard loomed in the shadows, Hedi Slimane, the much-admired, much-decried designer who left Yves Saint Laurent in 2016 and whose ghost had been haunting fashion ever since, made his return to the catwalk.

headline: Turkey Clamps Down on a Group Erdogan Once Championed: Grieving Mothers
keywords: ['Kurds', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: A group of mothers held weekly vigils for missing sons for years, and Recep Tayyip Erdogan once vowed to help. But the government recently banned the rallies, a sign, critics said, of rising authoritarianism.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — In a narrow side street of Istanbul the riot police, with gas masks pushed up on their heads, advanced on a small band of demonstrators marching in silence.

headline: How We Cover Your Hometown: From Denver to London to Bangkok
abstract: “The people we’re writing about read our pieces instantaneously, look for inaccuracies and tell us we’re full of baloney. This is not glamorous,” writes Ellen Barry, a Times correspondent based in London. “But it is basically a good thing. It makes us better.”
lead_paragraph: In an effort to shed more light on how we work, The Times is running a series of short posts explaining some of our journalistic practices. Read more from this series here.

headline: In Small-Town Maine, a Restaurant Both Reverent and Innovative
abstract: Elda, in off-the-summer-tourist-track town of Biddeford, combines many of the markers of modern American restaurants with distinctly Maine touches.
lead_paragraph: When I first discovered Elda in off-the-summer-tourist-trail Biddeford, Me., I was surprised. It seemed like a restaurant that belonged on Manhattan’s Lower East Side, or at least in Portland’s bustling restaurant scene, 25 minutes up I-95. Immediately, I sent a note to a friend who grew up in a similarly sleepy town near Portland. “What is happening to Maine?” He replied. “I can’t believe there’s a good restaurant in Biddeford.”

headline: The Most Important Least-Noticed Economic Event of the Decade
abstract: A localized recession in manufacturing-heavy areas can explain a lot of things.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the most important economic events announce themselves with huge front-page headlines, stock market collapses and frantic intervention by government officials.

headline: In Vienna, Affordable Luxury Comes at a Price
abstract: The Ruby Lissi Hotel is a stylish spot, convenient to many of the city’s top attractions. But it may take its “lean luxury” theme a little too seriously.

headline: On Politics: This Week’s Biggest Stories
abstract: The Kavanaugh hearings weren’t the only news in a busy week for American politics. Here are some of the biggest stories this week (and some links, if you want to read further).
lead_paragraph: From the gripping Kavanaugh hearings  to developments at the United Nations General Assembly, it’s been a busy week in American politics. Here are some of the biggest stories this week (and some links, if you want to read further).

headline: Is Your Salad Habit Good for the Planet?
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Compost', 'Containers and Packaging', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: Popular fast-casual chains brag of sustainability, as customers toss their compostable and recyclable bowls into the trash with wild abandon.
lead_paragraph: Every weekday, shortly after 11 a.m., a line forms at the Broadway and 38th Street location of Sweetgreen, the eco-conscious salad chain. By noon, the line has usually tripled in size. It often takes more than 15 minutes to get to the front.

headline: An ‘Ancestral Memory’ Inscribed in Skin
abstract: In Alaska and other areas of the circumpolar north, women have been working in the last decade to revitalize a tattooing tradition.
lead_paragraph: Grete Chythlook dreamed of the tattoo before she had ever seen one in person: a few fine lines drawn from the bottom lip down to the tip of the chin.

headline: Lady Bunny Is Still the Shadiest Queen Around
abstract: Three decades after landing in New York with RuPaul, Lady Bunny rules as New York’s reigning drag queen, even as a younger generation nips at her heels.
lead_paragraph: “Testes, testes, one, two, three!” a voice rasped over the sound system in a cheeky Southern drawl.

headline: How to Know if You Should Spend Forever Together
abstract: A love story.
lead_paragraph: Romance is an act of imagination, fueled by fear. My perfect future husband and I don’t know that yet, as we begin planning our first trip to Europe, scrutinizing blurry photos of hotel rooms in Le Marais and San Sebastián to discern if they’re the suitable mix of sophisticated and scrappy, skimming menus and considering attractions, packing ordinary clothes for these extraordinary places. We have faith that we will become extraordinary on the beaches at Biarritz. We are certain that, in the gorgeous corridors of Barcelona, his eyes will sparkle, my hair will form a luxurious, fluffy frame around my sun-dappled face. As we plan for romance, we are sure that romance will elevate us to a higher level of consciousness and gorgeousness and confidence. We are in love, after all. We have found our person. This is the start of a whole new life. All former selves — intractable, lumpy, ungrateful, repetitive, needy — will be left behind.

headline: Chidera Eggerue Has Some Tips (and Hashtags) for Self-Love
abstract: Her first book, “What a Time to Be Alone,” is an antidote to traditional self-help books, which she says often speak only to “privileged people from the first world.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Chidera Eggerue was 14, she went for a bra fitting and realized that her breasts looked nothing like those of the model on the packaging. She began to believe there was something wrong with her body. As a teenager she even started saving up to have plastic surgery.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: Padma Lakshmi on her rape and why she kept silent. Joan Jett on her lot in life. Joe Ide writes again. Remembering summer and the Village Voice. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. It was a hard week newswise. So take a breath. Maybe do some yoga or eat some chocolate, visit with a neighbor, call your mom, whatever your thing is. Or have some tea and indulge in some fantastic journalism.

lead_paragraph: For voting members of the Baseball Writers’ Association of America, the end of the regular season brings a fun but serious ritual: selecting the winners of the annual awards. Other organizations honor players and managers, too, but the writers’ awards have the longest tradition and retain the strongest resonance throughout the game.

headline: Can I Force My Landlord to Fix a Broken Outlet?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords', 'Home Repairs and Improvements']
abstract: There are several routes to resolution when a repair is needed. The right one often depends on your relationship with your landlord.
lead_paragraph: Q: My friend and I are subletting a co-op apartment in Manhattan from a family friend. On move-in day, we noticed some broken or damaged items, and immediately requested repairs. Over the past few weeks, they fixed everything (with some prodding), except for a broken outlet in my roommate’s bedroom. Rather than fix it, the owners suggested we use a power strip with a different outlet. But the only other outlet in the room is behind a heavy dresser, and we’ve been told not to move the furniture. Do we have grounds to demand they fix it?

headline: Our 15 Best Vegetarian Soups and Stews
abstract: Butternut squash soup, red bean stew and more recipes for the weekend.
lead_paragraph: We’re embracing fall with warming recipes. If you’re abstaining from meat, we can help out. Try Melissa Clark’s vegetarian skillet chili (above), charred cauliflower stew or Julia Moskin’s black bean soup. Click the “Veggie Soups and Stews” collection below for more.

headline: Kavanaugh Could Help G.O.P. in Senate Midterms. But Not in House Races.
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Sex Crimes', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: Republicans believe Judge Kavanaugh’s confirmation would cause a backlash among women and independent voters, hurting G.O.P. chances in House races.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By agreeing to delay Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh’s nomination in the short term, President Trump and Senate Republicans are making two long-term bets: that a drawn-out confirmation battle will secure a conservative majority on the Supreme Court, and that the fight will give them a better chance of keeping control of the Senate in the midterm elections.

headline: Housing Market Slows, as Rising Prices Outpace Wages
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Wages and Salaries', 'United States Economy', 'Interest Rates', 'Building (Construction)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: Even in attractive, fast-growing cities like Denver, New York and Seattle, selling prices are rising more slowly and asking prices are being slashed.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — By nearly any measure, this city is booming. The unemployment rate is below 3 percent. There is so much construction that a local newspaper started a “crane watch” feature. Seemingly every week brings headlines about companies bringing high-paying jobs to the area.

headline: Why We Can’t Stop Rooting for Tiger Woods
abstract: He’s the most talented golfer ever to play the game. But more than ever he’s showing he’s also a human being.
lead_paragraph: Our book, “Tiger Woods,” a biography of the grittiest and most mysterious athlete either of us has encountered in our over 50 years covering sports, came out in March. The final chapter, set in early 2018, sets the scene for Woods as he prepared to return to golf after his fourth back surgery. The last sentence read: “A changed man, he stood poised to show his children — and a fresh generation of golf pros and fans — just what a living legend looks like.”

headline: Autumn Means More Than Wet Socks and Gourd Tea
abstract: My favorite time of the year is finally here!
lead_paragraph: Summer is fine, but it’s nothing like fall. So keep your sunscreen and your beach balls: I’m ready to hop on a hayride, flip on the corn blinkers and lawfully merge right into autumn. Here are just a few of my favorite things about fall:

headline: Kavanaugh and the Blackout Theory
keywords: ['Alcohol Abuse', 'Sex Crimes', 'Brain', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: It is both easy and common to drink, act and then have no memory of it.
lead_paragraph: One of the trickiest things about blackouts is that you don’t necessarily know you’re having one. I wrote a memoir, so centered around the slips of memory caused by heavy drinking that it is actually called “Blackout,” and in the years since its 2015 release, I’ve heard from thousands of people who experienced them. No small number of those notes contain some version of this: “For years, I was having blackouts without knowing what they were.” Blackouts are like a philosophical riddle inside a legal conundrum: If you can’t remember a thing, how do you know it happened?

headline: More Evidence That Nutrition Studies Don’t Always Add Up
keywords: ['Research', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Food', 'Academic and Scientific Journals', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: A Cornell food scientist’s downfall could reveal a bigger problem in nutrition research.
lead_paragraph: Not too long ago, Brian Wansink was one of the most respected food researchers in America.

headline: In Praise of Mediocrity
abstract: The pursuit of excellence has infiltrated and corrupted the world of leisure.
lead_paragraph: I’m a little surprised by how many people tell me they have no hobbies. It may seem a small thing, but — at the risk of sounding grandiose — I see it as a sign of a civilization in decline. The idea of leisure, after all, is a hard-won achievement; it presupposes that we have overcome the exigencies of brute survival. Yet here in the United States, the wealthiest country in history, we seem to have forgotten the importance of doing things solely because we enjoy them.

headline: My Friend Wrote a Book Before He Died. Could I Read His Handwriting?
abstract: Sam’s legacy depended on my ability to decipher his notebook pages.
lead_paragraph: I knew my friend Samuel Park’s handwriting well, its curves and spikes and looping lowercase g’s and y’s. I’d first become acquainted with both him and his handwriting in college, when we worked together on the school newspaper. We were co-editors of the arts and entertainment section, and we would mark up the pages by hand and leave notes for each other. We shared a desk — sometimes we shared it sequentially, and sometimes we shared it simultaneously, sitting side by side.

headline: How Do Christians Fit Into the Two-Party System? They Don’t
abstract: The historical Christian positions on social issues don’t match up with contemporary political alignments.
lead_paragraph: What should the role of Christians in politics be? More people than ever are asking that question. Christians cannot pretend they can transcend politics and simply “preach the Gospel.” Those who avoid all political discussions and engagement are essentially casting a vote for the social status quo. American churches in the early 19th century that did not speak out against slavery because that was what we would now call “getting political” were actually supporting slavery by doing so. To not be political is to be political.

headline: He Got Schizophrenia. He Got Cancer. And Then He Got Cured.
abstract: A bone-marrow transplant treated a patient’s leukemia — and his delusions, too. Some doctors think they know why.
lead_paragraph: The man was 23 when the delusions came on. He became convinced that his thoughts were leaking out of his head and that other people could hear them. When he watched television, he thought the actors were signaling him, trying to communicate. He became irritable and anxious and couldn’t sleep.

headline: We Can’t Just Let Boys Be Boys
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Parenting', 'Sex Crimes', 'Men and Boys', 'Dating and Relationships']
abstract: Locker rooms are not the place to learn about sexual ethics. Neither is the internet.
lead_paragraph: One of the most stunning moments in a week of stunning moments leading up to the decision to delay the Senate vote on whether to confirm Judge Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court came Friday morning, when two women confronted Senator Jeff Flake as he stood trapped in an elevator, eyes averted. If he let the nomination advance, one of them said, her voice ragged, he would be “telling all women that they don’t matter.”

headline: Depressed About the Future of Democracy? Study History
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Freedom of the Press', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: The liberal project has faced far greater challenges before.
lead_paragraph: On my first day as United States ambassador in Prague in 2011, I found, branded beneath the surface of an antique table in my official residence, a small black swastika. It was one of many swastikas hidden throughout the palace, relics of the days when it was occupied by the Nazis.

headline: Why Trump Will Win a Second Term
abstract: Reality TV has always been the guidebook for this presidency. And most popular series last for six seasons.
lead_paragraph: When Mike Fleiss, the creator of “The Bachelor” and “Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire?” helped pioneer reality television in the early 2000s, he quickly realized that for any show to work, the audience needed to feel invested. “Whenever you’re developing one of these shows, you have to find stakes — true love or a million dollars,” Mr. Fleiss said.

She acknowledged her terror, but remained calm, and cited her scientific expertise in how the brain responds to trauma.

keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Myanmar’s civilian leader, once a democracy icon, has become known as an enabler for the ethnic cleansing of Rohingya Muslims and a foe of the free press.

In one post, without naming her, he suggested that she was a “power-mad prostitute.”

headline: A Promising Step in Tackling Childhood Cancer
abstract: A child’s chance of survival shouldn’t hinge on where he or she is born.
lead_paragraph: Like most of the boys in his San Salvador neighborhood, Gabriel Alessandro Mayorga Hernandez — Gabo, to his family and friends — loves soccer. But in 2014, just before he turned 12, he found himself exhausted by even a short game. Eventually he became too tired to play at all and started having headaches so severe they made him vomit. When he developed chest pains and difficulty breathing, his grandmother took him to the doctor, where X-rays and blood work indicated that he had acute lymphoblastic leukemia, or A.L.L., a blood cancer that develops most often in young children.

headline: Didier Deschamps Doesn’t Care About Style Points
abstract: A grinding champion as a player has become a grinding champion as a coach leading France’s national soccer team. And he has no plans to change what’s working.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Among the awards passed out at FIFA’s annual celebratory gala earlier this month was one for the year’s top coach. The shortlist’s star power was provided by Zinedine Zidane, who signed off as Real Madrid’s coach with a third straight Champions League title. Then there was Zlatko Dalic, the previously little-known manager who led Croatia on its improbable journey to the World Cup final.

headline: Elon Musk Steps Down as Chairman in Deal With S.E.C. Over Tweet About Tesla
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Boards of Directors']
abstract: After walking away from a deal, Tesla’s chief agreed to give up the chairmanship for three years and pay a $20 million fine.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, under pressure from his lawyers and investors of Tesla, the company he co-founded, reached a deal with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Saturday to resolve securities fraud charges. The settlement will force Mr. Musk to step aside as chairman for three years and pay a $20 million fine.

headline: Yankees Send Two Over the Fence and Into the Record Book
abstract: Gleyber Torres’s two-run blast in the fourth inning was the Yankees’ 265th home run, breaking the record for the most by a major league team in a season. Giancarlo Stanton added No. 266 in the seventh.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — As the ball landed safely in the Red Sox bullpen on Saturday, Gleyber Torres waved his right fist in the air, glanced toward the Yankees dugout and smiled as he rounded the bases. It was a small gesture to commemorate a big moment.

headline: Sleep on It
abstract: Natan Last says we can do this puzzle, then take a nap.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This grid is a dream to solve. You’ll need to burn the midnight oil on this one. There’ll be no rest for the wicked. Insert sleep idiom of your choice.

headline: For Phil Mickelson at Ryder Cup, One Last Chance to Deliver
abstract: Mickelson was a spectator on Saturday. In Sunday’s singles, the United States will need him to produce.
lead_paragraph: ST-QUENTIN-EN-YVELINES, France — While roars erupted around him, Phil Mickelson wordlessly pounded ball after ball with his driver, like a player possessed. It was midway through Saturday’s morning session at the 42nd Ryder Cup at Le Golf National, and Mickelson was the only United States player on the practice range.

headline: For David Luiz and Chelsea, Everything’s Perfect. Until Suddenly It’s Not.
abstract: A late Liverpool goal turned a Chelsea win into a draw.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Muttering under his breath, shaking his head in regret, David Luiz was the last player to disappear from the field. He had taken his time after the final whistle. As Liverpool’s players went over to celebrate with their fans, and as his Chelsea teammates trudged disconsolately toward the tunnel, Luiz lingered.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Hit Men and Power: South Africa’s Leaders Are Killing One Another
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Sept. 30, 2018.
lead_paragraph: “If you understand the Cosa Nostra, you don’t only kill the person, but you also send a strong message.”

headline: Red Tide, Take Warning
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'ALGAE', 'Sugar', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Fertilizer', 'Coastal Areas']
abstract: Perhaps the disaster that struck Florida’s southwest coast this summer will cause residents to rethink the way they live.
lead_paragraph: SANIBEL ISLAND, Fla. — As the Spanish cartographer Juan López de Velasco sailed along southwest Florida in 1575, he was greeted by a sight that became odiously familiar this summer to those on the peninsula he mapped for the Spanish Empire so long ago. “The coast is all in ruin,” he wrote in his journal, “because in these four or five leagues of sea there is barely 1.5 fathoms of water where many fish are dying.”

headline: Otis Rush, Influential Blues Singer and Guitarist, Is Dead at 83
abstract: Mr. Rush was part of a circle of late-1950s performers whose music heralded a new era for Chicago blues and influenced a generation of rock musicians.
lead_paragraph: Otis Rush, a powerful blues singer and innovative guitarist who had a profound influence not just on his fellow bluesmen but also on rock guitarists like Eric Clapton and Led Zeppelin’s Jimmy Page, died on Saturday. He was 83.

headline: On Crowded London Streets, Councils Fight a Flood of Phone Boxes
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Local Government', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: Proposals for hundreds of public phones plastered with ads have set off a battle over Britain’s public space.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British telephone box is not dead yet. In parts of central London, a box stands sentinel every 100 feet — and if phone companies got their way, they’d plant one every 50 feet.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Says 2020 Presidential Run Is On the Table
abstract: Senator Warren, a liberal Democrat from Massachusetts, has been one of her party’s most aggressive critics of President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts declared on Saturday that she would “take a hard look” at running for the White House in 2020 once the midterm elections are over, and called on the country to elect a female president to fix the “broken government” in Washington.

headline: Hit Men and Power: South Africa’s Leaders Are Killing One Another
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Politics and Government', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: About 90 politicians have been killed in South Africa since 2016. And in most cases, African National Congress officials are killing one another.
lead_paragraph: UMZIMKHULU, South Africa — Their fear faded as they raced back home, the bottle of Johnnie Walker getting lighter with each turn of the road. Soon, Sindiso Magaqa was clapping and bouncing behind the wheel of his beloved V8 Mercedes-Benz, pulling into familiar territory just before dark.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Has Matt Damon Play Brett Kavanaugh in Season Premiere
abstract: Meanwhile, the musical guest, Kanye West, drew attention for his extensive post-show remarks.
lead_paragraph: A complaint often made about “Saturday Night Live” over the last year or so is that, in its signature political sketches, the show essentially treats its cast as bench warmers while giving the key roles to an expanding roster of celebrity guests. It’s a roster that started, more or less, with Alec Baldwin as President Trump, and it has grown to include Scarlett Johansson as Ivanka Trump, Ben Stiller as Michael Cohen and Robert De Niro as Robert Mueller, among many others.

headline: Migrant Children Moved Under Cover of Darkness to a Texas Tent City
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Children and Childhood', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The federal government has been moving hundreds of children a week to a tent city on the Mexican border in West Texas where there is no school.

headline: The Economic Future Isn’t What It Used to Be (Wonkish)
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Unemployment', 'Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)']
abstract: Long run economic prospects fell sharply after the Great Recession
lead_paragraph: Lehman failed ten years and two weeks ago; this coming Wednesday will be the 10th anniversary of the enactment of the Troubled Asset Relief Program, aka the bailout. In honor of the anniversary, there have been approximately 1,000,000,000 pieces reflecting on the 2008 financial crisis and its effects. Many have suggested, rightly, that the political fallout continues to shape our world today. But as far as I can tell, surprisingly few have focused on the long-run economic effects.

headline: The Bells of St. Martin’s Fall Silent as Churches in Harlem Struggle
abstract: Two Harlem churches have buildings that have deteriorated. They also own nearby brownstones or vacant lots. Now they are debating whether to sell some of their real estate.
lead_paragraph: In a tower above Malcolm X Boulevard in Harlem are more than 40 large bells that were fabricated in the Netherlands — they form the carillon of a once-proud church, St. Martin’s, and are one of only three carillons in New York City. The queen mother of the Netherlands attended a dedication ceremony in the 1950s. The current Episcopal bishop of New York says it was “a giant big deal” that she was there.

headline: The Comedy Master Who Hasn’t Gotten Her Due: Elayne Boosler
abstract: A new box set makes the case that the pioneering female stand-up should be considered in the same class as David Letterman and Andy Kaufman.
lead_paragraph: In books, TV series and documentaries, stand-up comics of the 1970s have become nearly as mythologized as the auteurs of the New Hollywood. If Richard Pryor, David Letterman and Andy Kaufman were the Martin Scorsese, Steven Spielberg and Francis Ford Coppola of the club scene, then Elayne Boosler is the Hal Ashby, the misunderstood master who never got proper due.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Start this week off with a Sunday roast before ending it stunningly, with a beer-can chicken.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I am sorry to be this guy today, coming in hot on a Sunday morning when maybe all you’d like to be doing is spacing out or reading the new Robert Galbraith novel from J.K. Rowling. But really, today is the day to deep-clean your fridge after a summer of berries and ribs, endless new cheeses for August soirees, kombucha spills and leaking containers of sambal oelek and maple syrup. Look and see: three bottles of ketchup; two of mayonnaise; two of pickled jalapeño. When did you buy that sour cream? Are those … radishes in the back of the crisper?

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and Canada reached a last-minute deal to salvage the North American Free Trade Agreement on Sunday, overcoming deep divisions to keep the 25-year-old trilateral pact intact.

headline: Trump Administration Prepares a Major Weakening of Mercury Emissions Rules
keywords: ['Mercury (Metal)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Air Pollution', 'Environment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Global Warming', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: The proposal is designed to provide legal justification for weakening not only the rules on mercury emissions from coal-burning power plants, but also other pollution controls as well.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration has completed a detailed legal proposal to dramatically weaken a major environmental regulation covering mercury, a toxic chemical emitted from coal-burning power plants, according to a person who has seen the document but is not authorized to speak publicly about it.

headline: A Quiet Docket May Be Just the Right Medicine for the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Federal Courts (US)', 'Double Jeopardy', 'Capital Punishment', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A lack of blockbuster cases offers the justices a chance to bridge ideological divides that have flared in the confirmation process of Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the shadow of a titanic confirmation fight, the Supreme Court will return to the bench on Monday with a docket that offers an opportunity to lower the temperature.

headline: U.S. Marine’s Son Wins Okinawa Election on Promise to Oppose Military Base
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Elections']
abstract: Denny Tamaki’s victory is a setback to plans to transfer a busy Marine air base to a less-populated coastal area on the island.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Denny Tamaki, the son of a Japanese mother and a United States Marine, became the first mixed-race governor in Japan on Sunday after winning a close election in Okinawa, a southern archipelago heavily populated by American military installations.

headline: ‘Night School’ and Its Real-Life Comedians Beat the Animated ‘Smallfoot’
abstract: Starring Tiffany Haddish as a teacher and Kevin Hart as one of her adult students, “Night School” earned $28 million in North America to be No. 1.
lead_paragraph: The competition for the top spot at this weekend’s box office was a showdown between a live-action comedy and a star-studded animated musical, both in their opening weekends. In the end, it was the flesh-and-bone comics who won.

headline: George Kolombatovich, Fencing Coach at Columbia and the Met, Dies at 72
abstract: Mr. Kolombatovich taught sword fighting to the casts of “Otello,” “Carmen” and “Don Giovanni,” and led Columbia to five N.C.A.A. fencing championships.
lead_paragraph: George Kolombatovich, who coached Columbia University fencers to five N.C.A.A. championships and taught sword fighting to cast members of “Otello,” “Carmen” and “Don Giovanni” at the Metropolitan Opera, died on Sept. 19 in a hospital in Sarasota, Fla. He was 72.

headline: James Comey: The F.B.I. Can Do This
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Despite limitations and partisan attacks, the bureau can find out a lot about the Kavanaugh accusations in a week.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. is back in the middle of it. When we were handed the Hillary Clinton email investigation in 2015, the bureau’s deputy director said to me, “You know you are totally screwed, right?” He meant that, in a viciously polarized political environment, one side was sure to be furious with the outcome. Sure enough, I saw a tweet declaring me “a political hack,” although the author added, tongue in cheek: “I just can’t figure out which side.”

headline: For David Wright and Mets Fans, One Last Night to Remember
abstract: Too many injuries prevented Wright from having a more illustrious career, but he received a glowing and deserved send-off in his final appearance as a Mets player.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, I roamed a pregame locker room during the Mets’ improbable sprint to the playoffs and World Series. The game was hours away, and several Mets were playing cards and joking and snapping on one another, and David Wright, already hurting, already past his prime, joined in their jokes and laughter.

headline: Democrats Denounce Limits on F.B.I.’s Kavanaugh Inquiry as a ‘Farce’
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Witnesses', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Even Democratic senators who knew the investigation would be limited expressed disappointment as investigators planned to interview only four witnesses, at least initially.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. moved on Sunday to quickly complete an abbreviated investigation into allegations of sexual misconduct against Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, even as Democrats demanded more information about the inquiry’s scope, warning that its apparent constraints could make it a “farce.”

headline: The Rules of the Workplace, Then and Now
abstract: A conversation between women journalists of two different generations shows how women workers have, and haven’t, progressed.
lead_paragraph: Susan Chira, a former New York Times deputy executive editor  and Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter on gender issues, and Jessica Bennett, The Times’s gender editor, sat down recently to talk about #MeToo, the recent Christine Blasey Ford, Brett M. Kavanaugh hearings and what has changed for working women.

headline: Removing the Barriers for Women Around the Globe
abstract: The head of the world’s largest and most influential charitable foundation on why she’s promoting gender equity for women and girls around the globe.
lead_paragraph: Melinda Gates, co-chairwoman, Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, in conversation with Nicholas Kristof, a New York Times opinion columnist, at the New Rules Summit. The questions and answers have been edited and condensed.

headline: Taking Action for Women and Girls
abstract: Among the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals, No. 5 is near to Melinda Gates’ heart: “Achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls.”
lead_paragraph: New Rules Summit organizers invited Melinda Gates to contribute action points as a follow-up to her conversation with Nicholas Kristof.

headline: How Samantha Bee and Cecile Richards Overcome Self-Doubt
abstract: You just do the thing and you block out everybody else. You get over yourself.
lead_paragraph: Samantha Bee, the first woman to host a late-night satirical show, “Full Frontal with Samantha Bee,” week after week cuttingly and eloquently attacks politicians and policies. But she isn’t what she appears.

headline: The Effect of Intersectionality in the Workplace
abstract: A feeling of having to protect against bias or unfair treatment, of always having to be on guard.
lead_paragraph: The concept of intersectionality — referring to the complex and cumulative way different forms of discrimination like racism, sexism and classism overlap and affect people — seems have popped up relatively recently.

headline: The Old Rules of the Workplace Aren’t Working. At Least Not for Women.
abstract: The number of female chief executives in Fortune 500 companies is 5 percent and has actually declined over the past year.
lead_paragraph: Despite clear gains by women in so many aspects of society over the decades, their progress in the workplace seems to have stalled. It is as easy to find a man named John walking the corridors of American power as it is to find a woman.

headline: With a Murdoch in Charge, a Start-Up Leads the Way on Mobile Video
keywords: ['Web-Original Programming', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Mobile Applications', 'Social Media']
abstract: Vertical Networks, founded by Elisabeth Murdoch, has become a major supplier of app-centric video series that are drawing young viewers on Snapchat, Facebook and YouTube.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Calif. — A young actor with a bushy goatee, cast as a Satanist on a murder-mystery show called “Solve,” sat facing a camera on a stuffy, no-frills set in July. Six tenderfoot crew members stood sweating in the shadows nearby. One was staring at his iPhone’s stopwatch.

headline: Are More Women in the Future of JPMorgan Chase?
abstract: Jamie Dimon, chief executive of the world’s most valuable bank, talks about the value of women in the work force.
lead_paragraph: At the New Rules Summit, Rebecca Blumenstein,  a deputy managing editor of The New York Times, interviewed Jamie Dimon, chief executive and chairman of JPMorgan Chase, about opportunities for women at his company and beyond. Here are excerpts from their onstage conversation. They have been edited and condensed.

headline: How Jeff Flake May Have Saved Republicans From Themselves
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The extended F.B.I. investigation wasn’t what Republicans wanted, but it could end up easing the way for Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh’s Supreme Court confirmation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At first blush, Senator Jeff Flake’s last-minute decision to force a new F.B.I. investigation into accusations that Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh sexually assaulted a teenage girl when they were both in high school appeared to be a disaster for Republicans.

headline: Indonesia Tsunami’s Power After Earthquake Surprises Scientists
abstract: Catastrophic tsunamis often result from quakes that move vertically along a fault. Friday’s was different, moving mostly horizontally.
lead_paragraph: Scientists expressed surprise at the size of the tsunami that devastated the Indonesian city of Palu on Friday, saying an earthquake like the one that preceded it would not necessarily spawn such destructive waves.

headline: A Penthouse Made for Instagram
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Millennial Generation', 'Photography', 'Online Advertising']
abstract: Spotless walls, a “millennial pink” sofa, a spa-style bathtub that’s waiting to be filled with flowers — and every inch of its 2,400 square feet is free from the clutter of everyday life.
lead_paragraph: This penthouse apartment in Manhattan’s SoHo neighborhood is awash in natural light, with high ceilings, gleaming hardwood floors and a rooftop deck. The living room area includes a sofa in the rosy hue known as millennial pink, the kitchen comes equipped with a floor-to-ceiling wine fridge, and the library nook is filled with books chosen for their appearance, not their contents. The white walls are spotless, and there is never any clutter.

headline: Meat Labs Pursue a Once-Impossible Goal: Kosher Bacon
abstract: A rabbi at the world’s largest kosher certification agency is leading an effort to determine if and how meat grown from animal cells can satisfy Jewish law.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Rabbi Gavriel Price has thousands of years of Jewish religious law to draw on when he is on the job, determining whether a new food item can get a kosher certification from his organization, the Orthodox Union.

headline: Displaced Turks, Promised New Homes, Can Only Protest on an Empty Lot
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: The economy has stalled Turkey’s grand renewal plans for cities like Istanbul. Residents whose properties were razed are tired of waiting.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A group of residents have been protesting for more than 70 days at an empty building site in eastern Istanbul.

keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The decision to withdraw from an important annual meeting shows how tensions over an escalating trade war are spreading to other arenas.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China canceled an important annual security meeting planned for mid-October with Defense Secretary Jim Mattis in Beijing, saying a senior Chinese military officer would not be available to meet him, an American official said on Sunday.

headline: Inside China’s Predatory Health Care System
abstract: Homemade cancer drugs, violence in hospitals, doctor shortages: We take you inside China’s broken health care system to reveal how dire the situation is for over a billion people.

headline: Democrats Turned Up in Record Numbers. But One Man Held All the Power.
