lead_paragraph: A former Democratic state senator banged the gavel to start the meeting as a man in the packed auditorium yelled: “We’re going to take power from you.”

headline: Once Around the Track
abstract: Monday already?! Chuck Deodene’s puzzle ought to cheer us up.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — One of my favorite types of gratification felt when solving a puzzle is getting a genius joke that a constructor came up with to use in a grid. I feel included and savvy, and, as cheesy as it sounds, I get a little glow of gratitude toward whoever shared that eureka moment — in this case, Chuck Deodene. Thank goodness we’ve had a good run of these lately — a puzzle like today’s is like a mini vacation for a wrung-out brain, in my opinion.

headline: China’s Health Care Crisis: Lines Before Dawn, Violence and ‘No Trust’
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Doctors', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: China is trying to relieve its overwhelmed system by introducing more family doctors. But in a country where people rush to hospitals for a fever, change won’t be easy.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Well before dawn, nearly a hundred people stood in line outside one of the capital’s top hospitals.

headline: Shark Attacks a Teenager Diving for Lobsters Off the California Coast
abstract: The teenager had traumatic injuries to his torso but was expected to fully recover. It was the latest shark attack on the coasts of the United States.
lead_paragraph: A shark attacked a 13-year-old who was diving for lobsters at a beach in California early on Saturday morning, leaving him with traumatic injuries to his torso, the authorities said.

headline: Both Sides Claim Victory in Macedonia’s Vote on Changing Its Name
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Over 90 percent of ballots cast were in favor of the name change. But more than half of eligible voters stayed home from the polls.
lead_paragraph: The results of Macedonia’s referendum on Sunday about changing the country’s name were resoundingly inconclusive — leading both sides to claim victory.

headline: In Ryder Cup, Europe Leaves Egos at Door. Those of U.S. Slam the Door.
abstract: A news conference after another American loss on foreign soil lays bare recriminations that again reflect a team divided.
lead_paragraph: ST.-QUENTIN-EN-YVELINES, France — Tommy Fleetwood sat at one end of the dais on Sunday night and blew kisses across the table to Francesco Molinari, who emerged, with Fleetwood’s help, as the leading man in Europe’s Ryder Cup victory against the United States. Molinari, who sealed his 5-0 record with a 4-and-2 victory against Phil Mickelson in the singles round, was fielding a question about becoming a folk hero after following his victory in July’s British Open with his star turn here.

headline: Using Drones to Tell the Story of Climate Change
abstract: How Josh Haner’s drone photography captured a serious threat to the world’s most precious cultural sites.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: Car Explosion Kills Three Men in Pennsylvania, Officials Say
abstract: Officials said three men were killed in the explosion, which they called “an isolated incident.”
lead_paragraph: Three men were killed after a car exploded on Saturday night in Allentown, Pa., prompting the evacuation of nearby residents, the authorities said.

headline: Trump Targets Tehran
abstract: Iran is in, North Korea is out as the subject of the president’s threats.
lead_paragraph: President Trump raged at Iran for much of his annual address at the United Nations last week. He also praised Kim Jong-un, a sweeping redirection after last year pledging during the same speech to “totally destroy” North Korea.

headline: Victimizing the Victims, Again
abstract: In the Kavanaugh hearings, Republicans made it clear that the old, male-dominated order will prevail.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is on the case.

headline: Trump Can’t Win the War on Demography
abstract: A proposed citizenship question on the 2020 census reveals the dependency between older white voters and America’s growing young minority population.
lead_paragraph: Since the early days of his campaign, from his proposal to build a wall along the Mexican border to his discredited committee on voter fraud, President Trump has declared war on America’s changing demography. His administration has followed through on that strategy with a proposal to add a question to the 2020 census asking about citizenship. If the question remains on the form, millions of households, particularly Hispanic and Asian-American, could skip the census, leading to an overrepresentation of white Americans during this once-a-decade count.

headline: Indonesia Searches for Survivors Amid Destruction
abstract: At least 832 people had been confirmed dead by Sunday, but officials fear that the death toll from the earthquake and tsunami on the island of Sulawesi could be higher.
lead_paragraph: At least 832 people had been confirmed dead by Sunday, but officials fear that the death toll from the earthquake and tsunami on the island of Sulawesi could be higher.

headline: Executions With an Extra Dose of Cruelty
abstract: Inmates on Tennessee’s death row favor a firing squad over a torturous, deadly injection.
lead_paragraph: In August, four death row inmates filed a federal lawsuit in which they made an extraordinary argument: The state’s new lethal-injection protocol is so inhumane that execution by firing squad would be preferable. They even pointed out the practicality of this plan, noting that “the Big Buck Shooting Range is located on the grounds of Riverbend Maximum (Security) Institution and can easily accommodate the equipment required for an execution.”

headline: No Corrections: October 1, 2018
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, October 1, 2018.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, October 1, 2018.

headline: Yankees March to Playoffs With Two Rookies on the Field, and One in the Dugout
abstract: The rookies Miguel Andujar and Gleyber Torres are expected to play key roles in the postseason. Oh, and there’s also that first-year manager.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — C. C. Sabathia can still vividly recall the nerves from that day 17 years ago. As a rookie for the Cleveland Indians, Sabathia was making his first postseason start, and adrenaline was pumping through his veins.
